List of Intellectual Property Assets ________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ Program Design & Frameworks: scaling models, theories of change, volunteer formation ladder. ‚Ä¢ Training & Values Materials: manuals, curricula, handbooks, seminar guides, evaluation tools. ‚Ä¢ Branding Elements: logos, slogans, taglines, uniforms, insignias, templates. ‚Ä¢ Digital & Knowledge Systems: monitoring dashboards, volunteer tracking apps, databases. ‚Ä¢ Research & Policy Products: studies, impact reports, policy papers, case documentation. ________________________________________ 2. Registration & Legal Protections________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ Copyright Filings: all written, digital, and audiovisual training materials. ‚Ä¢ Trademark Applications: official logos, slogans, insignias, and branded templates. ‚Ä¢ Patent/Software Registrations (if applicable): for proprietary digital platforms and monitoring systems. ‚Ä¢ Confidentiality Agreements: for staff, partners, and volunteers with access to restricted information. ‚Ä¢ International Protection: filing with WIPO and other relevant agencies to safeguard global expansion. ________________________________________ 3. Licensing & Usage Agreements________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ Standard MOA/MOU Templates: for LGUs, CSOs, FBOs, and international partners using ABMPD content. ‚Ä¢ Licensing Clauses: o Scope of use (training, advocacy, governance support). o Time-bound authorization with renewal conditions. o Prohibition of rebranding, modification, or resale without approval. ‚Ä¢ Non-Transferability: licensed entities may not delegate usage rights to third parties. ‚Ä¢ Revocation Clause: ABMPD Holding reserves the right to revoke licenses in cases of misuse, distortion, or violation of terms. ________________________________________ 4. Monitoring & Enforcement System________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ Central Oversight: ABMPD Holding‚Äôs Legal & Governance Subsidiary serves as the IP compliance authority. ‚Ä¢ Audit Protocols: annual compliance reviews of materials used by VFAs, LGUs, and partner organizations. ‚Ä¢ Incident Reporting: community-level channels for Heroes, VFAs, or citizens to report IP misuse. ‚Ä¢ Corrective Measures: written notices, revocation of rights, blacklisting of violators. ‚Ä¢ Legal Action: pursuit of civil or criminal remedies against entities committing serious infringements. ________________________________________ 5. International Replication Safeguards________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ Cross-Border Licensing Agreements: standardized templates for diaspora groups, INGOs, and global partners. ‚Ä¢ Global Registry of Partners: database of authorized foreign implementors with verified licenses. ‚Ä¢ Cultural Integrity Clause: requires adaptation to local contexts without diluting ABMPD‚Äôs moral and Filipino identity. ________________________________________ 6. Sample IP Usage Agreement (Outline)________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ Parties: ABMPD Holding Company & Partner Institution. ‚Ä¢ Scope of Rights: use of training modules, branding, and systems for defined projects. ‚Ä¢ Obligations of Partner: adherence to ABMPD standards, reporting compliance, acknowledgment of ownership. ‚Ä¢ Restrictions: no unauthorized reproduction, transfer, or commercialization. ‚Ä¢ Duration & Termination: defined term with renewal process; revocation for violations. ‚Ä¢ Dispute Resolution: arbitration or legal remedies under Philippine law, extendable to international law if abroad. ________________________________________ üëâ This annex ensures that ABMPD‚Äôs intellectual assets are protected, responsibly shared, and globally scalable without compromising integrity. It functions as both a legal reference and an operational manual for program partners. ‚ÄÉ Annex D ‚Äì Organizational Chart & Ecosystem Map________________________________________ Purpose: To illustrate the governance and operational ecosystem of the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP, showing how the central program authority (ABMPD Holding Company) connects with subsidiaries, affiliate cooperatives, volunteer structures, and partner organizations. This annex provides a structural blueprint that ensures coherence, accountability, and scalability from barangay-level initiatives to global replication. ________________________________________ 1. Central Program Authority These are the principal governance bodies that form the core command and custodial structure of the ABMPD Ecosystem. They define the vision, moral standards, and institutional policies that guide all strategic, operational, and spiritual functions of the Program. Rooted in the divine vision originally entrusted to Posporo, the prophetic author and visionary originator of the ABMPD Masterplan, these central institutions embody the transformation of that calling into a living institutional reality through the establishment of the KDMC Holding Company ‚Äî now serving as the moral governance custodian and parent institutional body of the entire ABMPD Ecosystem. Operating under unified moral governance principles, these central authorities ensure coherence, accountability, and integrity from national to global execution. ________________________________________ 1. KDMC Holding Company Role: Parent Moral Governance Holding Company ‚Ä¢ Custodian of all ABMPD Intellectual Property (IP), brand, modules, and digital systems. ‚Ä¢ Defines the overall vision, policy, and moral standards of the entire ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Approves institutional charters, grants licenses, releases funds, and maintains veto authority for any moral or governance deviation. ‚Ä¢ Supervises all affiliated entities to ensure alignment with divine moral governance principles. ‚Ä¢ Oversees the international moral governance agenda, diaspora linkages, and global fund integration. ‚Ä¢ Functions as the spiritual and administrative covering for the ABMPD Holding Company (Central Brain) ‚Äî institutionalizing the vision originally authored by Posporo into a moral governance structure. ________________________________________ Subsidiaries under KDMC Holding: 1. KDMC Training Institute (Moral Governance Formation) ‚Ä¢ Provides leadership and moral governance training for institutional heads, coordinators, and national partners. ‚Ä¢ Develops the curriculum framework for moral governance leadership, serving as the foundation of ABMPD formation modules. ‚Ä¢ Conducts certification and continuing formation programs for executives and field leaders. 2. KDMC International Relations & Donor Engagement Subsidiary Parent Level (Global Policy & Partnership Oversight) Role & Scope: ‚Ä¢ Handles global partnerships and international funding at the policy and institutional level. ‚Ä¢ Negotiates macro-partnerships (UN, ADB, World Bank, large NGOs, intergovernmental donors). ‚Ä¢ Sets international moral governance standards and protocols for all global alliances. ‚Ä¢ Provides clearance and endorsement for ABMPD international engagements. ‚Ä¢ Serves as the spiritual and diplomatic gatekeeper for the ABMPD ecosystem globally. ________________________________________ 2. ABMPD Holding Company (OPC) ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe Central Brain‚Äù Role: Strategic Anchor and Institutional Custodian ‚Ä¢ Serves as the official program owner and national directorate of the ABMPD Moral Recovery Program. ‚Ä¢ Governs all strategic, operational, and financial systems under the moral governance oversight of KDMC Holding Company. ‚Ä¢ Issues Central Brain Directives that authorize the creation and activation of NGOs, associations, subsidiaries, and volunteer networks under the ABMPD Ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Maintains the Moral Ecosystem Registry, ensuring that all institutions, partners, and programs operate under one unified governance and ethical code. ‚Ä¢ Acts as the institutional custodian and strategic integrator, ensuring that all components of the ecosystem ‚Äî from policy to grassroots implementation ‚Äî remain coherent, accountable, and morally aligned. ‚Ä¢ Supervises and coordinates all Strategic Arms (NGOs & Associations), Institutional Subsidiaries, and Volunteer Governance Networks, ensuring seamless system regeneration from national to local levels. ________________________________________ 3. ABMPD Foundation Philippines ‚Äì Fund Custodian and Development Arm The ABMPD Foundation Philippines serves as the official fund custodian and development arm of the ABMPD Ecosystem. Role & Scope: ‚Ä¢ Manages all philanthropic, CSR, donor, and crowdfunding resources mobilized through the ABMPD network. ‚Ä¢ Allocates and disburses funds to strategic NGO arms, subsidiaries, and provincial programs based on approved ABMPD directives. ‚Ä¢ Ensures transparency, financial integrity, and alignment with the ABMPD MEL (Monitoring, Evaluation & Learning) framework. ‚Ä¢ Acts as the institutional bridge between the ABMPD Holding Company (Central Brain) and its implementation networks, guaranteeing that every fund flow, program activity, and project output remains morally aligned and accountably executed. ‚Ä¢ Operates under the moral governance oversight of the ABMPD Holding and policy alignment of KDMC Holding (Parent Custodian). ________________________________________ 2. Strategic Arms (NGOs and Associations under Central Brain Instruction) These are the officially mandated organizations established through Central Brain Directive under the ABMPD Holding Company. Each serves a distinct functional mandate contributing to the overall moral and institutional ecosystem. ________________________________________ 1. Kingdom Chronicles Inc. (KCI) ‚Äì Lead Implementor Role: Ground-Level Operational Arm ‚Ä¢ Translates the ABMPD Masterplan into community action through partnerships with LGUs and local institutions. ‚Ä¢ Leads volunteer training, program rollout systems, and on-ground implementation. ‚Ä¢ Develops pilot models and field prototypes for nationwide replication and scaling. ________________________________________ 2. Unified Faith-Based Organizations (UFBO) ‚Äì Moral Formation Arm Role: Spiritual and Values Integration Body ‚Ä¢ Umbrella network for faith-based organizations, churches, and interfaith partners (e.g., NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance, CBCP, Islamic councils). ‚Ä¢ Guides moral recovery, faith formation, and spiritual mobilization across communities. ‚Ä¢ Validates the moral and theological alignment of ABMPD modules, values education, and community programs. ________________________________________ 3. Alliance of Prophetic Builders for ABMPD Global Mission (APB‚ÄìABMPD) Role: Faith-Based Mobilization and Crowdfunding Arm ‚Ä¢ Serves as the frontline mobilization and support movement uniting local and global prophetic communities for ABMPD expansion. ‚Ä¢ Leads faith-driven crowdfunding, donor engagement, and intercessory partnerships for moral governance missions. ‚Ä¢ Supports the opening of new provinces and international rollouts through resource activation, prayer, and prophetic unity. ________________________________________ 4. Unified Civil Society Organizations (UCSO) ‚Äì Civic Engagement Arm Role: Civil Society Mobilization and Community Service Network ‚Ä¢ Integrates CSOs, NGOs, and cooperatives engaged in civic service, livelihood, and volunteerism. ‚Ä¢ Coordinates with VFAs for joint moral and developmental community initiatives. ‚Ä¢ Ensures civic participation and social innovation align with ABMPD‚Äôs moral and governance framework. ________________________________________ 5. Volunteer Formation Associations (VFAs) ‚Äì Volunteer Governance Network Role: Grassroots Volunteer and Leadership Body ‚Ä¢ Implements community-based moral recovery, household mentoring, and civic volunteerism. ‚Ä¢ Operates under KCI and LGU partnership structure for local coordination and monitoring. ‚Ä¢ Forms the living moral backbone of the ABMPD transformation model across barangays, municipalities, and provinces. ________________________________________ 3. Functional Subsidiaries (Core Management Units) These are the institutional and technical divisions established under the ABMPD Holding Company to ensure operational efficiency, compliance, and sustainability of the entire ecosystem. Each subsidiary fulfills a specialized management function ‚Äî from finance, research, and training to digital systems and manpower deployment ‚Äî enabling the Program to function as an integrated moral governance enterprise. ________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ Finance & Compliance Office ‚Äì ensures transparent fund management and reporting. ‚Ä¢ Research, Monitoring & Evaluation (RME) Office ‚Äì validates program effectiveness, tracks KPIs, and manages the dashboard system. ‚Ä¢ Training & Capacity-Building Center ‚Äì develops and delivers values formation, leadership, and livelihood modules. ‚Ä¢ Operations & Logistics Office ‚Äì standardizes mobilization, events, and volunteer deployment. ‚Ä¢ Legal & Governance Office ‚Äì safeguards IP, oversees contracts, ensures compliance with laws. ‚Ä¢ Communications & Media Office ‚Äì manages branding, advocacy, and unified messaging. ‚Ä¢ Resource Mobilization & Partnerships Office ‚Äì sustains linkages with private sector, diaspora, and global partners. ‚Ä¢ Software & Systems Development Office ‚Äì Manages the digital backbone of the ABMPD ecosystem, including dashboards, mobile apps, data security, integrated reporting systems, and digital ID/attendance tracking. ‚Ä¢ Human Resource & Staffing Office ‚Äì Focuses on corporate staffing needs, handling recruitment, training, and welfare of regular employees for the Holding Company and its subsidiaries. ‚Ä¢ Staffing Cooperative (Affiliate Manpower Partner) ‚Äì A CDA-registered cooperative that oversees recruitment, training, deployment, and welfare of facilitators, trainers, coordinators, and volunteer leaders, providing flexible community-based staffing support for grassroots program implementation. ________________________________________ 4. Volunteer & Governance Ecosystem This component represents the grassroots foundation of the ABMPD Program ‚Äî the living moral framework where transformation is carried out through people, not just systems. It connects volunteerism, moral governance, and civic partnership through a dual structure of VFAs (Volunteer Formation Associations) and PGOs (Program Governance Offices). ________________________________________ 1. Volunteer Formation Associations (VFAs) Serve as the mobilization and leadership units driving community participation in moral recovery and civic service. ________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ BVFA (Barangay VFA) ‚Üí Drives family- and community-level volunteerism. ‚Ä¢ MVFA (Municipal VFA) ‚Üí Consolidates and supports barangay VFAs. ‚Ä¢ PVFA (Provincial VFA) ‚Üí Oversees municipal VFAs and bridges to the regional level. ‚Ä¢ RFVA (Regional VFA) ‚Äì Integrates provincial VFAs and links them to the national framework. ‚Ä¢ NVFA (National VFA) ‚Üí Consolidates volunteer movements nationwide and represents volunteers at the policy level. ________________________________________ 2. Program Governance Offices (PGOs) ‚Äì official governance partners at each tier: Serve as the official coordination and accountability offices ensuring governance linkage from local to national levels. ________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ BMRPFO (Barangay Moral Recovery & Program Field Office) ‚Äì Barangay-level coordinating office. ‚Ä¢ MMRPO (Municipal Moral Recovery & Program Office) ‚Äì Municipal oversight and coordination. ‚Ä¢ PMRPO (Provincial Moral Recovery & Program Office) ‚Äì Provincial-level monitoring and consolidation. ‚Ä¢ RMRPO (Regional Moral Recovery & Program Office) ‚Äì Regional integration of provincial offices and alignment with national directives. ‚Ä¢ NMRPO (National Moral Recovery & Program Office) ‚Äì National integration and policy linkage. ________________________________________ 5. Partner Institutions These represent the multi-sectoral partnerships and alliances that expand the reach and legitimacy of the ABMPD Ecosystem. Each partner group contributes unique expertise, resources, and networks that reinforce the moral, civic, and institutional objectives of the Program ‚Äî ensuring a whole-of-society approach to moral recovery. ________________________________________ ‚Ä¢ Faith-Based Organizations (FBOs): NCCP, PCEC, dioceses, Islamic councils, local churches/mosques, and national ministries such as The 700 Club Asia act as moral anchors. ‚Ä¢ Faith-Based Media Partners: FEBC Philippines and similar media ministries strengthen advocacy and spiritual formation through broadcast and digital platforms. ‚Ä¢ Civil Society Organizations (CSOs): Cooperatives, NGOs, and civic groups align their initiatives with ABMPD values. ‚Ä¢ Government Agencies (NGAs): DILG, DepEd, TESDA, DOH, DSWD, etc., integrate ABMPD into development frameworks. ‚Ä¢ Academic & Research Partners: ISU, AIM, and others provide policy incubation, knowledge management, and capacity-building. ‚Ä¢ Private Sector & CSR Partners: Corporate foundations, microfinance institutions, and SMEs support sustainability and livelihood pilots. ‚Ä¢ International Partners & Diaspora: UN agencies, INGOs, diaspora councils expand ABMPD into global platforms. ________________________________________ 6. Ecosystem Lifecycle (Stage-based Functionality) The Ecosystem Lifecycle illustrates how the ABMPD institutional structure evolves in phases, aligning organizational activation with program maturity ‚Äî from preparation to global expansion. Each stage activates specific entities within the ecosystem to ensure that growth is strategic, data-driven, and morally grounded. ________________________________________ This section identifies which entities are activated and functional during each stage of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP‚Äôs development. A. Pre-Implementation Stage (Preparation & Structuring) ‚Ä¢ ABMPD Holding Company ‚Äì established; serves as the central authority. ‚Ä¢ Kingdom Chronicles Inc. (KCI) ‚Äì functioning as strategic standards and knowledge base partner. ‚Ä¢ Partners (Academe, initial FBOs, initial LGUs) ‚Äì engaged for baseline research, framework review, and program incubation. B. Pilot Rollout Stage (Field Testing & Early Operations) ‚Ä¢ KDMC Holding (Parent) ‚Äì formally built; provides overarching strategic direction and governance. ‚Ä¢ ABMPD Holding Company ‚Äì oversight and governance. ‚Ä¢ ABMPD Foundation ‚Äì initial structuring for fund mobilization and resource strategy. ‚Ä¢ Select Core Subsidiaries (Legal, Research & M&E, Training, Communications) ‚Äì activated for groundwork and pilot design. ‚Ä¢ Staffing Cooperative (Affiliate Manpower Partner) ‚Äì mobilized for training facilitators and barangay-level workers. ‚Ä¢ VFAs & PGOs (Barangay + Municipal levels) ‚Äì established in pilot areas to test structure. ‚Ä¢ Partners (NGAs, LGUs, FBOs, Private Sector, Faith-Based Media such as The 700 Club Asia and FEBC Philippines) ‚Äì engaged for advocacy, moral reinforcement, and program awareness. C. Full Implementation Stage (National Scaling & Saturation) ‚Ä¢ KDMC Holding (Parent) ‚Äì formally built; provides overarching strategic direction and governance. ‚Ä¢ BMPD Holding Company ‚Äì remains as strategic authority. ‚Ä¢ ABMPD Foundation + All Subsidiaries ‚Äì fully operational; fund management, logistics, systems, HR, partnerships, software, communications, etc. ‚Ä¢ Staffing Cooperative ‚Äì scaled for national deployment of manpower. ‚Ä¢ VFAs & PGOs (Barangay ‚Üí Municipal ‚Üí Provincial ‚Üí Regional ‚Üí National) ‚Äì fully rolled out nationwide. ‚Ä¢ Partners (FBOs, Faith-Based Media, CSOs, NGAs, Academe, Private Sector, International) ‚Äì consolidated for nationwide reinforcement and international expansion. ________________________________________ 7. Governance Chain Summary The Governance Chain defines the formal flow of moral authority, operational management, and institutional accountability within the ABMPD Ecosystem. It illustrates how moral governance is translated into organizational coherence ‚Äî from the Parent Moral Authority (KDMC Holding) down to grassroots implementation through the ABMPD Holding, ABMPD Foundation, Strategic NGOs, and Volunteer Networks. This chain ensures unified policy, transparent accountability, and consistent moral standards across all institutional and community levels ‚Äî harmonizing spiritual mandate with systemic governance. ________________________________________ Structural Flow of Authority and Coordination KDMC Holding Company ‚Üì ABMPD Holding Company (Central Brain) ‚Üì ABMPD Foundation Philippines (Official Fund Custodian and Development Arm) ‚Üì Strategic NGO Arms: ‚Ä¢ Kingdom Chronicles Inc. (KCI) ‚Ä¢ Unified Faith-Based Organizations (UFBO) ‚Ä¢ Alliance of Prophetic Builders for ABMPD Global Mission (APB‚ÄìABMPD) ‚Ä¢ Unified Civil Society Organizations (UCSO) ‚Ä¢ Volunteer Formation Associations (VFAs) ‚Üì Institutional Subsidiaries: (Infrastructure, Compliance, Training, Research, and Development Units operating under ABMPD Holding and Foundation supervision) ‚Üì Volunteer and Governance Networks: (VFAs and Program Governance Offices ‚Äì PGOs at Barangay, Municipal, Provincial, Regional, and National levels) ‚Üì Collaborative Partners and Stakeholders: (Government Agencies, Academic Institutions, Faith-Based Alliances, Civil Society Groups, Private Sector, and International Organizations) ________________________________________ Explanatory Summary 1. KDMC Holding Company ‚Äì Serves as the Parent Moral Governance Authority of the entire ecosystem. Defines moral standards, approves charters, and maintains global policy oversight for all ABMPD institutions and affiliates. 2. ABMPD Holding Company (Central Brain) ‚Äì Functions as the Strategic Directorate and Operational Command Center of the ABMPD Program. Issues directives, ensures institutional coherence, and safeguards the integrity of the Moral Recovery Masterplan. 3. ABMPD Foundation Philippines ‚Äì Acts as the Official Fund Custodian and Development Arm of the ecosystem. Oversees fundraising, financial disbursement, donor relations, and program-based resource allocation, ensuring that all mobilized funds are morally aligned and transparently managed. 4. Strategic NGO Arms ‚Äì These officially mandated organizations (KCI, UFBO, APB‚ÄìABMPD, UCSO, and VFAs) serve as implementation and mobilization bodies that translate moral governance principles into field-level action. 5. Institutional Subsidiaries ‚Äì Professional and regulatory units that provide technical, logistical, research, legal, communications, and operational support, ensuring program sustainability and nationwide scaling. 6. Volunteer and Governance Networks (VFAs & PGOs) ‚Äì Represent the grassroots moral and civic backbone of ABMPD. Operate as moral governance linkages from barangay to national levels, ensuring community participation and field accountability. 7. Collaborative Partners and Stakeholders ‚Äì Encompass government agencies, academe, private sector, civil society, and international alliances that reinforce the ABMPD‚Äôs mission through multi-sectoral cooperation and shared advocacy for moral recovery. ________________________________________ Visual Concept (Layered Ecosystem Map) To be represented as a layered organizational map: ‚Ä¢ Core (Center): KDMC Holding & ABMPD Holding Company ‚Ä¢ Inner Ring: ABMPD Foundation + KCI + UFBO + UCSO + Subsidiaries ‚Ä¢ Middle Ring: VFAs and PGOs (Volunteer & Governance Networks) ‚Ä¢ Outer Ring: Partners (Faith-Based, Civic, Government, Academic, Private, International) ________________________________________ Summary Statement The ABMPD Governance Chain embodies a living hierarchy of conscience and coordination ‚Äî where every decision flows from moral authority to operational reality. It ensures that moral regeneration does not end at formation, but evolves into a sustained system of accountability, transformation, and nation-building. ________________________________________ üìå In this visual form, this ecosystem will be presented as a layered organizational map: ‚Ä¢ Core (Center): KDMC Holding & ABMPD Holding Company. ‚Ä¢ Inner Ring: KCI, UFBO, UCSO, Foundation + Subsidiaries (functional arms). ‚Ä¢ Middle Ring: VFAs + PGOs (implementation structures). ‚Ä¢ Outer Ring: Partners (faith-based, civic, government, academic, private, international). ________________________________________ ‚ÄÉ Annex E‚ÄìStrategic Objectives Framework (Matrix Form)________________________________________ Purpose: The Strategic Objectives Framework is the backbone of the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP‚Äôs moral recovery model. It consolidates the five objectives ‚Äî Individual Transformation, Family Strengthening, Community Mobilization, National Moral Governance, and Global Replication ‚Äî into one coherent structure that demonstrates how change progresses systematically from the personal level to the international stage. This annex serves several essential functions: 1. Integration of Vision and Practice It ensures that the program‚Äôs overarching vision of Puso at Dang√°l (Heart and Honor) is not left as an abstract ideal, but is translated into operational objectives that guide training, partnerships, governance reforms, and international outreach. 2. Alignment Across Levels of Transformation By laying out the rationale, goals, key actions, and expected outcomes at every stage, the framework guarantees that no level of scaling ‚Äî whether personal or global ‚Äî stands in isolation. Each one builds upon and sustains the next. 3. Roadmap for Implementation and Scaling The annex provides a structured reference for program implementers, volunteers, LGUs, donors, and partner institutions. It acts as both a compass (direction-setting) and a dashboard (monitoring and evaluation), allowing stakeholders to see how activities link to outcomes. 4. Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (MEL) By breaking down objectives into measurable goals and key actions, the framework provides a foundation for continuous tracking and refinement. This ensures that transformation is evidence-driven, transparent, and accountable. 5. Sustainability and Replication Finally, the framework secures the sustainability of results. Transformation is not confined to pilot areas or temporary interventions; instead, it is designed to scale outward and upward ‚Äî first to families and communities, then to governance systems, and ultimately, to global platforms. In essence, Annex E is both a map and a measuring stick. It shows where ABMPD‚ÄìMRP is headed, how progress is made visible, and how every contribution ‚Äî from an individual‚Äôs moral renewal to international partnerships ‚Äî is part of a single, coherent movement for moral recovery. ________________________________________ 1. Strategic Objectives Matrix The Strategic Objectives Matrix translates the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP‚Äôs vision into a structured and measurable roadmap. It aligns each of the five objectives ‚Äî from the transformation of the individual to the replication of the model globally ‚Äî with their corresponding rationale, strategic goals, key actions, and expected outcomes. This matrix serves three purposes: 1. Clarity of Direction ‚Äì clearly mapping how each level of moral transformation contributes to the overall program. 2. Operational Guidance ‚Äì providing concrete actions for implementers, facilitators, and partner institutions. 3. Monitoring and Accountability ‚Äì setting measurable outcomes that can be tracked through the ABMPD Dashboard and other evaluation mechanisms. By consolidating all five objectives into one framework, the matrix ensures that ABMPD‚ÄìMRP is not a collection of isolated activities but a cohesive, values-driven movement. Transformation flows naturally: üëâ Individual ‚Üí Family ‚Üí Community ‚Üí Nation ‚Üí World This cascading model guarantees that the integrity of change is preserved at every stage of scaling ‚Äî from the inner life of a person to international adoption. ________________________________________ üìå Strategic Objectives Matrix Level / Objective Rationale Strategic Goals Key Actions Expected Outcomes 5.1 Individual Transformation True moral recovery begins with the person; without inner renewal, external reforms collapse. 1. Values Formation 2. Character Development 3. Personal Leadership 4. Holistic Empowerment 5. Evidence-Based Tracking ‚Ä¢ Barangay-based values sessions & workshops ‚Ä¢ Mentorship & peer-support programs ‚Ä¢ Integrated training modules (livelihood + life skills + moral formation) ‚Ä¢ Recognition of role models ‚Ä¢ Use of ABMPD Dashboard & RME validation ‚Ä¢ Integrity in daily decision-making ‚Ä¢ Stronger sense of accountability ‚Ä¢ Role models of transformation ‚Ä¢ Measurable progress captured in Dashboard ‚Ä¢ Pool of value-driven citizens 5.2 Family Strengthening The family is the first community; weak families multiply dysfunction, while strong families sustain moral renewal. 1. Value-Centered Parenting 2. Family Cohesion 3. Economic Stability 4. Health & Well-Being 5. Intergenerational Values Transmission ‚Ä¢ Family Values Formation Seminars ‚Ä¢ Parenting, marriage, and youth mentoring modules ‚Ä¢ Faith-based & civic counseling + livelihood assistance ‚Ä¢ ABMPD Dashboard tracking ‚Ä¢ Formation of Family Circles ‚Ä¢ Linkage to microfinance/livelihood partners ‚Ä¢ Parents as moral role models ‚Ä¢ Stronger household unity & resilience ‚Ä¢ Reduction of domestic conflict & poverty ‚Ä¢ Safer barangays and stronger communities ‚Ä¢ Network of value-driven families nationwide 5.3 Community Mobilization Communities bridge family life and governance; organized barangays provide the structural base for nationwide moral recovery. 1. Grassroots Volunteerism 2. Local Governance Partnership 3. Collective Empowerment 4. Sustained Civic Participation 5. Community Resilience ‚Ä¢ Establish BVFAs in barangays, scaling to MVFA/PVFA ‚Ä¢ Deploy BMRPFOs (barangay field offices) ‚Ä¢ Community-wide training on values & governance ‚Ä¢ Volunteer service projects (clean-ups, feeding, disaster response) ‚Ä¢ Dashboard mapping of participation ‚Ä¢ Partnerships with schools, faith groups, cooperatives ‚Ä¢ Renewed bayanihan culture ‚Ä¢ Strong citizen‚Äìbarangay governance partnerships ‚Ä¢ Collective solutions to local issues ‚Ä¢ Increased civic participation ‚Ä¢ Model barangays as replication hubs 5.4 National Moral Governance To scale grassroots moral renewal, principles must be embedded in national policies and institutions. 1. Policy Integration 2. Institutionalization 3. Public Accountability 4. Multi-Sectoral Convergence 5. Leadership by Example ‚Ä¢ Establish NMRPO linked with NGAs ‚Ä¢ Leadership training for public officials ‚Ä¢ Integrate Dashboard for national monitoring ‚Ä¢ Integrity metrics in gov‚Äôt appraisals ‚Ä¢ National awareness campaigns ‚Ä¢ Moral Governance Summits ‚Ä¢ Policy/legislative support for moral governance ‚Ä¢ National adoption of values-based frameworks ‚Ä¢ Unified moral recovery agenda in policies ‚Ä¢ Citizens‚Äô trust in institutions restored ‚Ä¢ Reduced corruption/systemic inefficiency ‚Ä¢ Philippines as model for values-driven governance 5.5 Global Replication Moral crises are global; Filipino Puso at Dang√°l can serve as a framework for international moral renewal. 1. Diaspora Engagement 2. International Partnerships 3. Cross-Cultural Adaptation 4. Knowledge Export 5. Global Advocacy ________________________________________ 2. Overall Flow Diagram The Overall Flow Diagram illustrates how moral recovery cascades systematically from the inner life of the individual to the global stage. This flow ensures that values are not imposed top-down but grow organically, bottom-up, preserving authenticity at every stage of scale. The transformation model is designed to be self-reinforcing: each level strengthens the one before it while providing the foundation for the next. In this way, the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP safeguards coherence, sustainability, and scalability. ________________________________________ üìå Flow Sequence Individual ‚Üí Family ‚Üí Community ‚Üí Nation ‚Üí World ‚Ä¢ Individual ‚Äì Personal values formation, character building, and leadership training. ‚Ä¢ Family ‚Äì Strengthening the household as the first community; transmitting values across generations. ‚Ä¢ Community (Barangay / Municipal / Provincial) ‚Äì Mobilizing barangays through BVFAs, MVFAs, and PVFAs; building civic participation and grassroots resilience. ‚Ä¢ Nation ‚Äì Institutionalizing values through policies, leadership development, and moral governance structures. ‚Ä¢ World ‚Äì Sharing the Philippine model globally through diaspora engagement, partnerships, and knowledge export. ________________________________________ Visual Representation (Conceptual Diagram) ________________________________________ üìå Key Insight: What begins as an inner renewal of conscience scales upward until it becomes a global framework for moral governance. The flow ensures that values planted in one person grow into households, ripple across communities, shape national institutions, and eventually influence the world. ________________________________________ ‚ÄÉ Annex F ‚Äì Phased Implementation Roadmap & Core Activities Mapping________________________________________ 1. Purpose: This annex presents the time-bound operational roadmap of the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP, designed to translate the Program Framework (Section 6) into a structured rollout sequence. It visualizes how activities, milestones, and institutional actors evolve across five implementation phases ‚Äî from training and orientation to global replication. The roadmap serves three functions: 1. Planning Tool ‚Äì Provides a timeline that aligns activities with corresponding outputs and outcomes, ensuring coherence across rollout stages. 2. Role Clarification ‚Äì Maps out which governance units, volunteer associations, and institutional partners are responsible at each stage. 3. Monitoring & Accountability ‚Äì Establishes measurable milestones for tracking progress, enabling adaptive management and timely adjustments. ________________________________________ 2. Linkage to Section 6 Framework ‚Ä¢ 6.1 Phases of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP ‚Üí Provides the narrative description of each phase. ‚Ä¢ 6.2 Theory of Change (ToC) ‚Üí Defines the logical flow of transformation (Individual ‚Üí Family ‚Üí Community ‚Üí Nation ‚Üí World). ‚Ä¢ 6.3 Expected Impact & Scaling Outcomes ‚Üí Identifies the transformational results anticipated at each tier of implementation. Annex F integrates these three subsections into a practical roadmap, consolidating: ‚Ä¢ Phases & Duration ‚Äì Five sequenced stages of implementation. ‚Ä¢ Core Activities ‚Äì Operational tasks aligned with strategic objectives. ‚Ä¢ Key Actors ‚Äì Assigned roles of Holding Company, Subsidiaries, PGOs, VFAs, and institutional partners. ‚Ä¢ Milestones & Deliverables ‚Äì Outputs and indicators that track completion and readiness for scaling. ________________________________________ 3. Tiered Activities by Scaling Level (Progression aligned with Section 6.3: Expected Impact & Scaling Outcomes) This matrix outlines the core activities, responsible actors/structures, and expected outputs at each scaling tier of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP. It ensures that transformation flows systematically from the individual level to the global stage, with each level reinforcing and scaling the outcomes of the previous one. Tier Filipino Title English Subtitle Core Focus Key Actions Quick Outcomes Rollout (Ground Zero / Pilot) Panunumbalik ng Pagmamahal sa Diyos at sa Bayan Foundational Stage of Orientation, Renewal & BVFA Formation Orientation, renewal, and formation of first BVFAs; setup of governance structures and data systems ‚Ä¢ Municipal-wide orientation of FBOs & CSOs‚Ä¢ Formation and mobilization of BVFAs‚Ä¢ Scouting of potential MVFA leaders from ‚ÄúLevel 3 Heroes‚Äù‚Ä¢ Tripartite MOA with participating barangays‚Ä¢ Dashboard enrollment and baseline setup‚Ä¢ Ground-zero pilot with overlapping batches (150 pioneers) ‚Ä¢ First BVFA cohort trained and operational‚Ä¢ Municipal implementing body fully functional (FBOs, CSOs, volunteers)‚Ä¢ Potential MVFA candidates identified‚Ä¢ Baseline MOAs with LGUs signed‚Ä¢ Dashboard live and active Tier 1 ‚Äì Individual Pagsilang ng Bagong Puso Individual Renewal as the Seed of Transformation Moral renewal, discipline, personal integrity, values recovery ‚Ä¢ 4-week values cycles with journaling/devotions‚Ä¢ Peer-mentoring groups‚Ä¢ Recognition & graduation days for completers ‚Ä¢ Behavior change logs established‚Ä¢ Steady graduates emerging‚Ä¢ BVFA peer leaders identified Tier 2 ‚Äì Family / Household Pagkakaisa at Pananampalataya Household Unity Scaling into Barangay Volunteerism Household strengthening, volunteer mobilization, faith-practice integration ‚Ä¢ Family workshops and counseling‚Ä¢ Barangay service projects‚Ä¢ MOAs with CSOs/FBOs‚Ä¢ Quarterly bayanihan activities ‚Ä¢ Stronger family bonds‚Ä¢ Active BVFA volunteer pools‚Ä¢ Visible barangay-level service projects Tier 3 ‚Äì Livelihood & Dignity (Community Empowerment) Pag-angat ng Kabuhayan at Dang√°l Livelihood with Integrity, Prosperity with Dignity Livelihood hubs, skills training, food security, cooperative building ‚Ä¢ 12-week livelihood & skills modules‚Ä¢ Micro-project incubation‚Ä¢ Savings cycles and cooperatives‚Ä¢ TESDA/DTI linkages ‚Ä¢ Household income streams‚Ä¢ Barangay-based cooperatives‚Ä¢ Validated livelihood grants & microenterprises Tier 4 ‚Äì Youth & Family Resilience Kabataang May Puso at Pamilya‚Äôy Matatag Empowered Youth, Resilient Families Youth leadership, intergenerational mentoring, family resilience, education & health access ‚Ä¢ Youth leadership camps‚Ä¢ Parenting workshops‚Ä¢ Family enrichment events‚Ä¢ Scholarships & educational support‚Ä¢ Health & wellness programs ‚Ä¢ Empowered youth leaders‚Ä¢ Resilient households‚Ä¢ Reduced school dropouts‚Ä¢ Stronger family safety nets Tier 5 ‚Äì Community to Nation to World Pamayanang Matatag at Bayaning Nagtutulungan Nation-Building with Global Replication Institutionalized bayanihan, resilience systems, scaling to national and global levels ‚Ä¢ Inter-barangay aid systems‚Ä¢ Disaster resilience councils‚Ä¢ Large-scale cooperatives‚Ä¢ International toolkits & pilot exchanges ‚Ä¢ Institutionalized bayanihan units‚Ä¢ Municipal & national adoption‚Ä¢ First global replications of ABMPD model ________________________________________ 4. Activity Flowchart ‚Äì ABMPD‚ÄìMRP Scaling Pathway The ABMPD‚ÄìMRP progresses through a structured entry-to-global flow, ensuring that transformation is seeded at the personal level, reinforced within families, scaled in communities, institutionalized at municipal‚Äìprovincial‚Äìregional levels, standardized nationally, and finally replicated globally. Flow Sequence: 1. Entry Point ‚Äì Initial orientation, ground-zero rollout, selection of pilot municipalities, and onboarding of volunteers. 2. Individual Training ‚Äì Values formation sessions, Hero‚Äôs Journey workshops, personal mentoring, 4-week renewal cycles. 3. Household Strengthening ‚Äì Family workshops, counseling, livelihood starter kits, intergenerational mentoring. 4. Barangay Mobilization ‚Äì Formation of BVFAs, barangay moral assemblies, community service projects, peer support groups. 5. Municipal Coordination ‚Äì Establishment of MVFAs, cross-barangay collaboration, municipal moral congresses, LGU adoption. 6. Provincial Integration ‚Äì PVFA councils formed, provincial-wide trainings, moral recovery summits, policy integration. 7. Regional Alignment ‚Äì RVFA setup, harmonization workshops, RDC integration, best-practice exchanges across provinces. 8. National Standardization ‚Äì NMRPO-led congresses, national policy adoption, donor-backed programs, nationwide campaigns. 9. Global Replication ‚Äì Diaspora engagement, international pilots, cross-country partnerships, deployment of Puso at Dang√°l model worldwide. ________________________________________ üìå Activity Flowchart ‚Äì Visualization Table Stage Color Code Title One-line Description 0 ‚ö™ Neutral Entry Point Orientation, pilot rollout, and volunteer onboarding. 1 üîµ Blue Individual Training Values formation, mentoring, and Hero‚Äôs Journey workshops. 2 üîµ Blue Household Strengthening Family workshops, livelihood starter kits, and intergenerational mentoring. 3 üü¢ Green Barangay Mobilization BVFA setup, barangay moral assemblies, and community service projects. 4 üü† Orange Municipal Coordination MVFA councils, municipal moral congresses, and LGU adoption. 5 üü† Orange Provincial Integration PVFA councils, province-wide summits, and policy integration. 6 üü† Orange Regional Alignment RVFA councils, RDC harmonization, and inter-provincial best practices. 7 üü• Red Maroon National Standardization NMRPO-led congresses, national policies, and standardized campaigns. 8 üü° Gold Global Replication Diaspora councils, international pilots, and Puso at Dang√°l as a global model. ________________________________________ 6. üîÑ Feedback Loops ‚Ä¢ National ‚Üí Community/Barangay (policy informs grassroots implementation). ‚Ä¢ Provincial ‚Üí Household (provincial frameworks refine family-level programs). ‚Ä¢ Global ‚Üí National (international lessons feed back into national strategies). ________________________________________ 7. Phased Implementation Roadmap (Timeline View) (To be visualized as a Gantt chart in the final document) Phase Timeline Milestones Key Actors Pre-Implementation (Preparation & Structuring) Year 0‚Äì1+ ‚Ä¢ ABMPD Holding governance framework finalized‚Ä¢ Training of trainers (core facilitators, coordinators)‚Ä¢ Pilot BVFA clusters formed‚Ä¢ ABMPD Dashboard & baseline data system set up ABMPD Holding, HR Subsidiary, KDMC Holding Phase 1 ‚Äì Pilot Rollout (Barangay‚ÄìMunicipal Focus) Year 1‚Äì2+ ‚Ä¢ Pilot BVFA‚ÄìMVFA projects launched‚Ä¢ Household/family workshops & barangay moral assemblies‚Ä¢ Municipal-level dashboards operational‚Ä¢ Tripartite MOAs signed with pilot barangays & LGUs BVFAs, MVFAs, Municipal LGUs Phase 2 ‚Äì Expansion & Provincial Institutionalization Years 2‚Äì3+ ‚Ä¢ PVFA councils formed & fully operational‚Ä¢ Integration into provincial LGU frameworks‚Ä¢ Cross-municipality scaling (multiple clusters active)‚Ä¢ Provincial summits for moral recovery convened PVFAs, Provincial LGUs, Subsidiaries Phase 3 ‚Äì Regional Consolidation & National Alignment Years 3‚Äì4+ ‚Ä¢ RVFA structures formalized‚Ä¢ RDC integration & harmonization of provincial frameworks‚Ä¢ Regional moral recovery reports consolidated‚Ä¢ NMRPO adoption as standard national model RVFAs, RDCs, NMRPO Phase 4 ‚Äì National Standardization Years 4‚Äì5+ ‚Ä¢ Nationwide implementation of BVFAs, MVFAs, PVFAs, RVFAs‚Ä¢ National policy adoption and budget integration‚Ä¢ Institutionalization of moral recovery across agencies‚Ä¢ National summits for scaling & replication readiness NMRPO, National Subsidiaries, Partner Agencies Phase 5 ‚Äì Global Replication Year 5+ ‚Ä¢ Diaspora councils mobilized‚Ä¢ First international pilots launched‚Ä¢ Replication toolkits adapted for cross-country use‚Ä¢ Strategic partnerships with global organizations NMRPO, Diaspora Networks, International Partners ________________________________________ 8. Expected Impact Summary per Phase This matrix summarizes the measurable transformation expected at each stage of the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP rollout. It integrates both quantitative (numeric and performance-based) and qualitative (behavioral and perceptual) indicators to ensure a holistic understanding of progress. The table aligns with Section 6.3.F (Impact Measurement Framework) and Annex F‚Äôs activity flow, allowing implementers, LGUs, and partners to track not only the scale of implementation but also the depth of moral and cultural renewal achieved in each phase. This summary provides the evidence base for adaptive learning under the Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (MEL) System, and supports the verification checkpoints found in the Transition Matrix and Dashboard reports. ________________________________________ Phase Core Focus Quantitative Indicators (Numeric) Qualitative Indicators (Behavioral / Cultural) Verification Source ‚ö™ Pre-Implementation (Preparation & Structuring) Organizational readiness, systems setup, pilot onboarding ‚Ä¢ No. of partner LGUs & MOAs signed ‚Ä¢ No. of facilitators trained ‚Ä¢ Baseline data systems operational ‚Ä¢ Readiness of implementing bodies ‚Ä¢ Stakeholder confidence and engagement level ‚Ä¢ Baseline reports / MOA records / Dashboard readiness checklist üîµ Phase 1 ‚Äì Pilot Rollout (Barangay‚ÄìMunicipal Focus) Foundational training, BVFA formation, moral renewal ‚Ä¢ % of participants completing training ‚Ä¢ No. of BVFAs established ‚Ä¢ No. of family/household engagements ‚Ä¢ Observable behavioral change among trainees ‚Ä¢ Community perception of renewed discipline & civic spirit ‚Ä¢ BVFA reports / Training attendance / Post-session evaluations üü¢ Phase 2 ‚Äì Expansion & Provincial Institutionalization Community mobilization, PVFA integration, policy support ‚Ä¢ No. of active BVFAs & MVFAs ‚Ä¢ No. of barangays with moral recovery projects ‚Ä¢ Provincial ordinances adopted ‚Ä¢ Evidence of inter-barangay cooperation ‚Ä¢ Emergence of volunteer leadership and shared accountability ‚Ä¢ Provincial progress reports / LGU policy records / Scorecards üü† Phase 3 ‚Äì Regional Consolidation & National Alignment Alignment of regional systems, harmonization of policies ‚Ä¢ No. of RVFAs formed ‚Ä¢ Regional moral recovery reports consolidated ‚Ä¢ % compliance to national standards ‚Ä¢ Increased regional collaboration ‚Ä¢ Enhanced governance ethics and transparency culture ‚Ä¢ RDC validation / NMRPO assessment / Regional dashboard data üü• Phase 4 ‚Äì National Standardization Institutionalization of moral recovery across agencies ‚Ä¢ No. of agencies with moral recovery programs ‚Ä¢ Budget allocations integrated ‚Ä¢ National summit convened ‚Ä¢ Strengthened moral governance in public institutions ‚Ä¢ Public trust and moral identity indicators improving ‚Ä¢ National MEL dashboard / Agency scorecards / External evaluation üü° Phase 5 ‚Äì Global Replication International partnership, diaspora engagement, model export ‚Ä¢ No. of international pilots ‚Ä¢ No. of partner countries / MOAs ‚Ä¢ Global recognition or awards ‚Ä¢ Positive cross-cultural adoption feedback ‚Ä¢ Philippines recognized as model for moral recovery ‚Ä¢ International reports / Global council documents / External audits ________________________________________ üìå In Essence: This Expected Impact Summary per Phase provides the measurable bridge between strategy and transformation. It ensures that progress is not only quantified through numbers but also qualified through lived moral impact, enabling continuous learning, transparency, and accountability throughout the ABMPD journey ‚Äî from pilot phase to global legacy. ________________________________________ 9. üìå Visualization as Gantt Chart ‚Ä¢ X-axis (Time): Year 1 ‚Üí Year 5+ ‚Ä¢ Y-axis (Phases): Phase 1 ‚Üí Phase 5 (stacked) ‚Ä¢ Bars: Colored progress bars per phase (Blue ‚Üí Green ‚Üí Orange ‚Üí Red ‚Üí Gold, to match the staircase/flow colors) ‚Ä¢ Milestone markers: Diamonds or arrows marking transitions (e.g., PVFA formation, RVFA setup, NMRPO adoption). ________________________________________ üîπ Expected Impact Summary per Phase ‚Äî Sample Illustration To demonstrate how both quantitative and qualitative indicators may be summarized at the program level, the following sample table provides an indicative view of the expected transformation benchmarks per phase. (Actual numbers and metrics will be validated through the MEL Dashboard and reported in Section 8 ‚Äî Expected Impact Summary per Phase.) Phase Key Impact Area Quantitative Indicator Qualitative Indicator 1 Individual Renewal 5 000 graduates certified Increased personal discipline and moral reflection 2 Family Strengthening 2 500 families trained in values Improved family cohesion and communication 3 Community Empowerment 100 barangay projects operational Enhanced community trust and cooperation 4 National Integration Provincial ordinances enacted in 80 % of LGUs Institutional culture of moral governance 5 Global Replication 3 international pilot programs active Recognition in ASEAN / UN platforms üìå Essence: This sample matrix illustrates how the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP balances scale and substance‚Äîmeasuring both the quantitative reach of transformation and the qualitative depth of moral renewal. ________________________________________ üîπ Integration & Monitoring Note To ensure coherence between planning, implementation, and evaluation, all activities and milestones defined in Annex F are directly integrated into the ABMPD Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (MEL) System. Each phase‚Äôs indicators and outputs are tracked through the ABMPD Ecosystem Dashboard, which consolidates data from barangay, municipal, provincial, and national governance offices. Validation is conducted through the Program Governance Offices (PGOs) and reflected in the MEL scorecards and quarterly performance reviews. This integration guarantees that the Phased Implementation Roadmap is not just a schedule of activities but a living governance instrument‚Äîaligned with Section 6.3 (Expected Impact & Scaling Outcomes) for measurable transformation, expanded through Part V (MEL System) for accountability, and operationalized in Part II (Implementation Model) for full-scale execution. ________________________________________ üîπ Transition to Part II ‚Äì Implementation Model The successful realization of the Phased Implementation Roadmap depends on the structured translation of these milestones into executable mechanisms. Part II ‚Äì Implementation Model operationalizes this roadmap by detailing the procedures, institutional arrangements, and financing systems required to execute each phase effectively. It expands upon the linkages established in Section 6.3 (Expected Impact & Scaling Outcomes) and the monitoring pathways defined in Part V (Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning System), transforming strategic plans into coordinated field action. Through this bridge, the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP ensures that moral recovery is not only envisioned and measured, but fully implemented ‚Äî sustained by systems, guided by governance, and proven through collective impact. ________________________________________ ‚ÄÉ Annex G ‚Äì Activities & Focus Areas (Technical Reference)________________________________________ G.0 Introduction Annex G serves as the comprehensive technical reference to Section 7 of the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP document. While Section 7 provides a clear and logical narrative of the program‚Äôs activities and focus areas, Annex G consolidates the detailed blueprints, training flows, and implementation guides that will be used by implementers, trainers, and partner institutions in the field. Purpose of Annex G ‚Ä¢ To document in detail the participants, activities, outcomes, and focus areas for each stage of the transformation process‚Äîfrom Rollout to Tier 5. ‚Ä¢ To provide session guides, facilitator notes, training modules, and activity breakdowns that serve as ready-to-use tools for implementers. ‚Ä¢ To serve as a reference manual for partner agencies, ensuring alignment of roles, responsibilities, and contributions. ‚Ä¢ To function as a repository of standardized templates and tools (e.g., MOAs, monitoring dashboards, federation by-laws, partnership frameworks) that promote consistency across municipalities and barangays. Linkage to the Transformation Flow and Program Stages The content of Annex G is structured in direct correspondence with the Transformation Flow (Individual ‚Üí Family ‚Üí Community ‚Üí Governance ‚Üí Global) and the Program Stages of Engagement (Rollout to Tier 5). Each annex subsection (G.1‚ÄìG.7) elaborates on the detailed mechanics behind the narrative outlined in Section 7, ensuring a seamless flow from vision to implementation. Usage Note Section 7 should be read as the narrative and strategic overview, highlighting what is to be done at each stage of the program. Annex G, in contrast, functions as the technical manual and field guide‚Äîthe working document for facilitators, trainers, and institutional partners. Users are advised to consult Section 7 for the high-level storyline and Annex G for the operational details and implementation roadmaps. ________________________________________ Annex G.1 ‚Äì Pre-Implementation Stage (Municipal Preparation) This annex provides the detailed technical design, activity flows, and institutional setup required before the official Rollout Stage. The Pre-Implementation Stage ensures that all governance commitments, legal instruments, and implementing offices are formally in place to guarantee readiness and legitimacy. By completing this stage, municipalities and barangays secure both organizational and moral grounding prior to training participants in the Municipal Rollout. ________________________________________ 1. Objectives ‚Ä¢ Secure municipal and barangay-level adoption of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP through formal Memoranda of Agreement (MOAs). ‚Ä¢ Establish the Municipal Moral Recovery Program Office (MMRPO) and Barangay Moral Recovery & Program Facilitation Offices (BMRPFOs) as permanent implementing anchors. ‚Ä¢ Orient municipal and barangay staff on their specific roles as program personnel (salaried, not volunteers). ‚Ä¢ Ensure readiness and alignment of all stakeholders (LGUs, line agencies, FBOs, CSOs, and scouted volunteers) before the Municipal Rollout begins. ________________________________________ 2. Participants ‚Ä¢ Municipal Officials & Department Heads ‚Äì Mayor, SB members, and heads of offices (social welfare, health, education, agriculture, etc.). ‚Ä¢ Barangay Officials ‚Äì Captains, kagawads, and committee chairs relevant to ABMPD activities. ‚Ä¢ Line Agencies ‚Äì DILG, DSWD, DOH, DepEd, TESDA, DA, DTI, and others for technical and policy alignment. ‚Ä¢ Faith-Based & Civil Society Leaders (FBOs and CSOs) ‚Äì Initially participants; future co-facilitators during the Barangay Rollout. ‚Ä¢ MMRPO Staff ‚Äì Official municipal employees designated for program management. ‚Ä¢ BMRPFO Staff ‚Äì Official barangay employees designated for program facilitation. ‚Ä¢ Scouted Volunteers (Candidates for New Heroes) ‚Äì Identified during orientation; will undergo the Municipal Rollout training cycle. ________________________________________ 3. Key Activities and Steps Step 1 ‚Äì Proposal & Orientation Meetings ‚Ä¢ Conduct initial presentation of the ABMPD framework to municipal and barangay leadership. ‚Ä¢ Secure alignment with municipal development plans and LGU priority agendas. ‚Ä¢ Orient barangay captains and kagawads for buy-in and commitment. Step 2 ‚Äì MOA Signing (Municipality Level) ‚Ä¢ Formalize partnership between the Municipality and KCI. ‚Ä¢ Create the MMRPO as the official municipal anchor office. ‚Ä¢ Designate staff positions funded by the LGU. Step 3 ‚Äì MOA Signing (Barangay Level) ‚Ä¢ Execute a tripartite MOA among Municipality, KCI, and each participating barangay. ‚Ä¢ Establish BMRPFOs with officially assigned barangay staff. ‚Ä¢ Secure barangay allocations (budgetary or in-kind resources). Step 4 ‚Äì Orientation of Assigned Personnel ‚Ä¢ Conduct an orientation workshop for MMRPO and BMRPFO staff. ‚Ä¢ Clarify that they are salaried employees, not volunteers. ‚Ä¢ Confirm that they will actively participate in the Municipal Rollout training cycle to ensure shared values and operational alignment. ________________________________________ 4. Implementation Design ‚Ä¢ Duration: 2‚Äì3 weeks prior to scheduled Municipal Rollout. ‚Ä¢ Mode: Combination of orientation sessions, MOA signing ceremonies, and preparatory workshops. ‚Ä¢ Batch Size: Entire municipal leadership core plus representatives of each barangay. ‚Ä¢ Documentation: MOAs, attendance sheets, office creation orders, orientation reports. ________________________________________ 5. Institutional Anchors ‚Ä¢ Lead Facilitator: KCI ‚Äì overall coordination, module delivery, and orientation. ‚Ä¢ Municipality: Provides policy legitimacy, office creation, staff designation, and resource allocation. ‚Ä¢ Barangays: Establish and staff BMRPFOs. ‚Ä¢ Line Agencies: Technical alignment and policy oversight (DILG ‚Äì governance, DepEd ‚Äì education/KPIs, DOH ‚Äì health, DSWD ‚Äì welfare, TESDA/DA/DTI ‚Äì livelihood). ________________________________________ 6. Financing and Resources ‚Ä¢ Municipality: Budget allocation for MMRPO staff, office operations, and logistics. ‚Ä¢ Barangays: Budget or in-kind contributions for BMRPFO operations. ‚Ä¢ KCI: Technical framework, modules, and orientation support. ‚Ä¢ Partners: NGOs, FBOs, CSR programs for complementary or bridging support. ________________________________________ 7. Expected Outputs ‚Ä¢ Signed MOAs at both municipal and barangay levels. ‚Ä¢ Fully functional MMRPO and BMRPFOs with designated staff. ‚Ä¢ Stakeholders formally oriented on ABMPD framework and responsibilities. ‚Ä¢ Personnel (MMRPO, BMRPFO staff + scouted volunteers) officially listed as Rollout participants. ‚Ä¢ Municipality fully ready to commence Municipal Rollout (Section 7.3.2). ________________________________________ 8. Transition Assurance ‚Ä¢ MMRPO & BMRPFO offices are operational before Rollout begins. ‚Ä¢ Personnel and scouted volunteers share a common values foundation and operational readiness. ‚Ä¢ Legitimacy and continuity secured through signed MOAs, preventing delays or fragmentation. ________________________________________ üìå Linked Tools (Stored in Annex BT and Annex G.1 reference set): ‚Ä¢ Sample MOA Templates (Municipal & Barangay). ‚Ä¢ Orientation Workshop Agenda & Materials. ‚Ä¢ Checklist for MMRPO/BMRPFO Creation. ________________________________________ G.2 Rollout Stage ‚Äì Panunumbalik ng Pagmamahal sa Diyos at Bayan (Foundational Stage of Orientation, Renewal & Implementing Body Formation) ________________________________________ G.2.1 Phase 1: Municipal Rollout Introduction The Municipal Rollout is the first step in the Rollout Stage, preparing the municipal ecosystem as the backbone for barangay-level implementation. It focuses on orienting leaders, training scouted volunteers, and establishing the groundwork for the Municipal Values Formation Advocates (MVFA). By investing in municipal readiness, this phase ensures that barangay activities are supervised, guided, and supported by a strong and morally grounded leadership core. ________________________________________ Objectives ‚Ä¢ Introduce the ABMPD Framework (vision, tiers, roles, and implementation roadmap). ‚Ä¢ Conduct moral recovery and leadership training for municipal officials, FBOs, CSOs, and scouted volunteers. ‚Ä¢ Scout and prepare MVFA candidates who will eventually serve as the Moral Leg and Community Services Leg of the municipal ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Establish a baseline municipal ecosystem capable of co-facilitating barangay rollouts and mentoring local leaders. ‚Ä¢ Ensure phased legitimacy by formally organizing MVFA officers only after 70‚Äì100% of barangays have established BVFAs. ________________________________________ Participants ‚Ä¢ Municipal Officials and Department Heads ‚Äì provide policy support, endorsement, and coordination. ‚Ä¢ Barangay Officials (early stage) ‚Äì aligned with municipal orientation. ‚Ä¢ Faith-Based Organizations (FBOs) ‚Äì participants and facilitators-in-training for moral recovery; will later serve as co-supporters of KCI in the Barangay Rollout. ‚Ä¢ Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) ‚Äì participants and mobilizers-in-training for community service initiatives; become active co-facilitators during the Barangay Rollout. ‚Ä¢ Scouted Volunteers (Candidates for New Heroes) ‚Äì identified participants who undergo the full training cycle (5-day face-to-face sessions, 4 weeks of daily devotion & reflection, and 4 peer mentoring sessions). üìå They are formally recognized as New Heroes only after completing this program during the recognition ceremony. ‚Ä¢ Future MVFA Officers & Committees ‚Äì interim candidates identified during the rollout; prepared to assume leadership once BVFAs are established across barangays. ________________________________________ Key Activities & Training Flow (5 Parts) 1. Awakening & Orientation ‚Äì Hamon sa mga Bagong Bayani (video series), program introduction, alignment. 2. Moral Recovery (Moral Leg) ‚Äì values formation, integrity, patriotism, and basic facilitation skills. 3. Community Engagement (Community Services Leg) ‚Äì training on service delivery, volunteerism, and barangay support. 4. Skills Deepening & Readiness ‚Äì Training of Trainers (ToT), monitoring, and dashboard reporting. 5. Application & Recognition Preparation ‚Äì pilot barangay simulation, readiness checks, and endorsement for recognition rites. üìå For detailed session guides and facilitator notes, see Annex G.1.a Training Modules. ________________________________________ Activity Tables A summary of each major activity is provided in Annex G.1.b. It includes: ‚Ä¢ Activity description ‚Ä¢ Mode (F2F, online, hybrid) ‚Ä¢ Partner roles ‚Ä¢ Duration / total days ________________________________________ Implementation Design ‚Ä¢ Batch Management ‚Äì Maximum of 100 participants per batch; multiple cycles conducted until full municipal coverage is reached. ‚Ä¢ Two-Leg MVFA Structure ‚Äì Moral Leg (values & leadership) and Community Services Leg (volunteerism & community projects). ‚Ä¢ Hybrid Delivery ‚Äì Blend of face-to-face sessions + 4 weeks of daily reflection (online) + weekly peer facilitation. ‚Ä¢ Readiness Assessment ‚Äì Pilot barangay simulation conducted before recognition to validate participant readiness. ________________________________________ Institutional Anchors ‚Ä¢ Lead Implementor: KCI ‚Äì Program design, delivery of values formation & moral recovery modules through its Moral Leg arm, mentoring, and interim facilitation until MVFA/BVFA structures are in place. ‚Ä¢ Training & Monitoring Partner: DepEd ‚Äì Oversees quality of training; leads orientation on monitoring, reporting, and KPI tracking; observes moral recovery sessions for integration but does not serve as primary facilitator. ‚Ä¢ Policy Alignment: DILG ‚Äì Ensures LGU policy cooperation and adoption of ABMPD structures. ‚Ä¢ Local Anchors: Municipal & Barangay Officials ‚Äì Provide endorsement, logistical support, and integration into governance systems. ‚Ä¢ Support Networks: FBOs & CSOs ‚Äì Participants and facilitators-in-training, to serve as co-facilitators in barangay rollouts. ‚Ä¢ Sectoral Agencies (DOH, DSWD, TESDA, etc.) ‚Äì Provide programmatic integration in health, welfare, livelihood, and technical skills. ________________________________________ Financing & Partnerships ‚Ä¢ Primary Funding ‚Äì Bilateral donors, foundations, and CSR programs. ‚Ä¢ Local Support ‚Äì LGUs, schools, and barangays (venues, logistics, in-kind contributions). ‚Ä¢ Sectoral Partnerships ‚Äì TESDA, DTI, DA for livelihood and training tie-ins. ‚Ä¢ International & Philanthropic Partners ‚Äì UN agencies, Rotary, Lions, church groups, and private foundations. ________________________________________ Expected Outcomes ‚Ä¢ A trained pool of scouted volunteers (to be recognized as New Heroes upon program completion) and interim MVFA candidates. ‚Ä¢ A municipal ecosystem ready to guide barangay rollouts. ‚Ä¢ Moral recovery institutionalized at the municipal level. ‚Ä¢ Dashboard baseline established for monitoring and reporting. ‚Ä¢ Recognition ceremonies conducted, fostering ownership and pride. ________________________________________ Transition Assurance ‚Ä¢ MVFA officers formalized only when 70‚Äì100% of barangays have operational BVFAs. ‚Ä¢ Pilot barangay simulations confirm readiness. ‚Ä¢ Scouted volunteers sustain engagement via daily reflections and peer mentoring until recognition. ‚Ä¢ Municipal oversight ensures continuity and support for barangay-level implementation. ________________________________________ üìå Linked Annexes ‚Ä¢ Annex G.1.a ‚Äì Training Modules (session guides + facilitator notes) ‚Ä¢ Annex G.1.b ‚Äì Activity Tables & Partner Roles ‚Ä¢ Annex G.1.c ‚Äì Financing & Sponsorship Sources ‚Ä¢ Annex G.1.d ‚Äì Institutional Anchors & Governance Flow ________________________________________ G.2.2 Phase 2: Barangay Rollout Introduction & Rationale The Barangay Rollout is the second phase of the Rollout Stage, ensuring that the ABMPD framework takes root at the grassroots level. After the municipal ecosystem is oriented and trained, the focus shifts to forming the Barangay Values Formation Advocates (BVFA). Each BVFA becomes the local implementing body, directly responsible for guiding individuals, families, and communities through the Transformation Tiers. A critical safeguard in this phase is the Moral Recovery Screening, conducted at the start. This step ensures that officers and members of the BVFA are morally upright, values-driven, and service-oriented, preventing self-serving leadership and securing trust within the community. ________________________________________ Objectives ‚Ä¢ Form Barangay Values Formation Advocates (BVFA) with Moral Leg Officers & Members and Community Services Leg Committees & Members. ‚Ä¢ Conduct orientation, moral recovery, and leadership training tailored to barangay-level needs. ‚Ä¢ Mobilize barangay volunteers and recognize them as New Heroes. ‚Ä¢ Establish barangay-level capacity to co-facilitate Tier 1‚Äì5 activities. ‚Ä¢ Integrate barangay operations into the municipal ecosystem for oversight, reporting, and sustainability. ________________________________________ Participants & Batch Structure ‚Ä¢ Part 1 (Scouted Participants): 250 new volunteers per barangay, trained in 5 overlapping batches (~50 per batch). ‚Ä¢ Part 2 (Full BVFA Training): o All Part 1 New Heroes. o Municipal Rollout graduates from the barangay (automatic BVFA members). ‚Ä¢ Additional Participants: Barangay officials, FBOs, CSOs at the local level. This structure guarantees that each BVFA is inclusive, representative, and morally vetted. ________________________________________ Activity Flows Part 1 ‚Äì Orientation & Moral Recovery ‚Ä¢ Hamon para sa mga Bagong Bayani (intro challenge video + reflections). ‚Ä¢ Orientation on ABMPD Vision, Structure, and Roles. ‚Ä¢ Values Formation & Moral Recovery (moral compass, integrity, patriotism). ‚Ä¢ Daily Reflection (online dashboard) ‚Äì 4 weeks. ‚Ä¢ Weekly Peer Facilitation / Kamustahan ‚Äì 4 sessions. ‚Ä¢ Recognition of New Heroes (induction at barangay level). Part 2 ‚Äì Full BVFA Formation ‚Ä¢ Community Engagement & Mobilization (training on bayanihan and service facilitation). ‚Ä¢ Training of Trainers (ToT) for BVFA officers and committees. ‚Ä¢ Monitoring & Reporting (dashboard tools, documentation). ‚Ä¢ Simulation / Pilot Tier 1 Activity. ‚Ä¢ Recognition & Induction of BVFA Officers and Members. ________________________________________ Training Design & Hybrid Model ‚Ä¢ Part 1: blend of face-to-face orientation, moral recovery sessions, and online reflection/peer mentoring. ‚Ä¢ Part 2: intensive face-to-face sessions, simulations, and recognition ceremonies. ‚Ä¢ Hybrid Tools: o ABMPD Dashboard for reflections, tracking, and reporting. o Peer mentoring to ensure accountability and moral grounding. ________________________________________ Institutional Anchors ‚Ä¢ Lead Implementor: KCI ‚Äì overall program design, facilitation, and monitoring. ‚Ä¢ Training Partner: DepEd ‚Äì values facilitation, monitoring, academic alignment. ‚Ä¢ Barangay Officials: logistical support, venue provision, BVFA endorsement. ‚Ä¢ FBOs & CSOs (local level): co-facilitators, mobilizers, and support networks. ________________________________________ Financing & Partnerships ‚Ä¢ Primary Financing: JICA (barangay-level rollout). ‚Ä¢ Local Support: barangay officials, FBOs, CSOs (venues, logistics, manpower). ‚Ä¢ Potential Sponsorship Sources: o Private sector & CSR programs. o Faith-based institutions. o Philanthropic foundations. o OFW/migrant associations. o Educational institutions. o International development agencies. ________________________________________ Expected Outcomes ‚Ä¢ Functioning BVFA with Moral Leg and Community Services Leg. ‚Ä¢ Recognized and inducted New Heroes and BVFA Officers. ‚Ä¢ Established barangay-level dashboards and MOAs with local partners. ‚Ä¢ Barangay ecosystems fully integrated with municipal oversight. ‚Ä¢ Leadership pipeline prepared for Tier 1‚Äì5 implementation. ________________________________________ Transition Assurance ‚Ä¢ Continuity: New Heroes sustain engagement through reflection and peer mentoring. ‚Ä¢ Legitimacy: BVFA leaders morally vetted before induction. ‚Ä¢ Integration: barangay monitoring linked to municipal dashboard. ‚Ä¢ Alignment: barangay-level efforts synced with municipal and provincial priorities. ‚Ä¢ Momentum: no gaps between induction and active implementation of Tier 1. ________________________________________ Linked Annexes ‚Ä¢ Annex G.1.e ‚Äì Training Modules (Barangay-specific). ‚Ä¢ Annex G.1.f ‚Äì Detailed Activity Tables. ‚Ä¢ Annex G.1.g ‚Äì Sponsorship Sources & Partnership Framework. ________________________________________ ‚ÄÉ G.1 Technical Supplements ‚Äì Rollout Toolkits‚Äù G.1.a Pre-Implementation Stage (Municipal Preparation) ‚Ä¢ Objectives, participants, key activities, implementation design, institutional anchors, financing, outputs, transition assurance. ‚Ä¢ üìå Linked tools: Proposal & MOA templates, Orientation agenda, MMRPO/BMRPFO checklist. G.1.b Training Modules (Municipal Rollout) ‚Ä¢ Session guides & facilitator notes for 5 parts (Awakening ‚Üí Recognition). G.1.c Activity Tables & Partner Roles (Municipal Rollout) ‚Ä¢ Tabulated details of activities, delivery modes, partners, and duration. G.1.d Financing & Sponsorship Sources (Municipal Rollout) ‚Ä¢ Breakdown of municipal-level funding, CSR/NGO support, and in-kind contributions. G.1.e Institutional Anchors & Governance Flow (Municipal) ‚Ä¢ Diagram + notes on KCI, LGU, DepEd, DILG roles, plus reporting flow. G.1.f Training Modules (Barangay Rollout) ‚Ä¢ Barangay-level session guides, values formation, BVFA induction modules. G.1.g Detailed Activity Tables (Barangay Rollout) ‚Ä¢ Step-by-step tables for Part 1 (Orientation & Moral Recovery) and Part 2 (Full BVFA Formation). G.1.h Sponsorship Sources & Partnership Framework (Barangay Rollout) ‚Ä¢ Barangay-level budget sources, in-kind contributions, NGO/FBO roles, donor mapping. ________________________________________ ‚ÄÉ G.1.a Training Modules (Municipal Rollout) Session Guides and Facilitator Notes ________________________________________ Purpose of this Toolkit The training modules are designed to guide the Municipal Rollout of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP under the Rollout Stage ‚ÄúPanunumbalik ng Pagmamahal sa Diyos at Bayan.‚Äù These modules serve as the operational manual for facilitators, ensuring: ‚Ä¢ Consistency in delivery across municipalities. ‚Ä¢ Alignment of values (spiritual renewal + civic responsibility). ‚Ä¢ Readiness of participants to co-facilitate the succeeding Barangay Rollout. üìå Important Note on Participants: All volunteers at this stage are scouted participants (candidates for New Heroes). They will only be formally recognized as New Heroes after completing: ‚Ä¢ 5 days of face-to-face training, ‚Ä¢ 4 weeks of Daily Devotion & Reflection (online), and ‚Ä¢ 4 peer mentoring sessions (Kamustahan). Recognition occurs during the Municipal or Barangay Recognition Ceremony. ________________________________________ Training Flow Overview The Municipal Rollout follows a 5-part progression, with each part blending face-to-face training and online reflective practice: 1. Part 1 ‚Äì Awakening & Orientation 2. Part 2 ‚Äì Moral Recovery (Moral Leg) 3. Part 3 ‚Äì Community Engagement (Community Services Leg) 4. Part 4 ‚Äì Skills Deepening & Readiness 5. Part 5 ‚Äì Application, Consolidation & Recognition ________________________________________ Module Details Part 1 ‚Äì Awakening & Orientation Objective: Ignite participants‚Äô sense of moral duty, introduce ABMPD framework, and align stakeholders. ‚Ä¢ Session 1: Opening & Invocation o Activity: Prayer, national anthem, inspirational message. o Facilitator Notes: Set a solemn but uplifting tone. Stress the dual call: love of God and love of country. ‚Ä¢ Session 2: Hamon para sa mga Bagong Bayani (Video Series) o Mode: Video presentation (plenary). o Purpose: Emotional priming to see self as ‚ÄúBagong Bayani.‚Äù o Facilitator Notes: Encourage initial sharing of reflections. ‚Ä¢ Session 3: Orientation on ABMPD Vision & Structure o Mode: Face-to-face briefing with Q&A. o Content: Tier framework, rollout sequencing, participant roles. o Facilitator Notes: Clarify expectations, highlight long-term vision. ‚Ä¢ Session 4: Reflection & Sharing (Kamustahan) o Activity: Small group ‚Äúcheck-in‚Äù sharing. o Notes: Allow space for personal reactions, surface hopes & fears. ‚Ä¢ Daily Reflection Assignment (Dashboard start). ________________________________________ Part 2 ‚Äì Moral Recovery (Moral Leg) Objective: Instill foundational values of integrity, patriotism, and renewal. ‚Ä¢ Session 1: Values Formation & Moral Recovery Workshop o Modules: Honesty, discipline, integrity, patriotism, spiritual renewal. o Mode: Face-to-face small group workshops. o Facilitator Notes: Delivered by KCI (Moral Leg arm); FBO participants join as observers and facilitators-in-training. ‚Ä¢ Session 2: Facilitation Skills (Intro Level) o Content: Basic methods for leading small-group reflection. o Facilitator Notes: Keep interactive, encourage roleplay. ‚Ä¢ Daily Reflection Assignment (Dashboard). ________________________________________ Part 3 ‚Äì Community Engagement (Community Services Leg) Objective: Equip participants to mobilize volunteers and organize bayanihan activities.* ‚Ä¢ Session 1: Community Services & Mobilization Training o Topics: Volunteer management, designing barangay projects. o Facilitator Notes: Highlight bayanihan as Filipino cultural strength. ‚Ä¢ Session 2: CSO-led Practicum o Activity: Group designs a barangay-level service project. o Notes: Should be realistic and replicable at barangay scale. ‚Ä¢ Peer Group Sharing & Planning ‚Ä¢ Daily Reflection Assignment (Dashboard). ________________________________________ Part 4 ‚Äì Skills Deepening & Readiness Objective: Prepare participants to serve as facilitators, mentors, and MVFA candidates.* ‚Ä¢ Session 1: Training of Trainers (ToT 1) o Content: Facilitation, mentoring, servant-leadership. ‚Ä¢ Session 2: Training of Trainers (ToT 2) o Content: Walkthrough of Tiers 1‚Äì5 program structure. ‚Ä¢ Session 3: Monitoring & Reporting Workshop o Content: Use of ABMPD dashboard, documentation, oversight linkages. ‚Ä¢ Daily Reflection Assignment (Dashboard). ________________________________________ Part 5 ‚Äì Application, Consolidation & Recognition Objective: Consolidate learnings, validate readiness, and prepare participants for recognition.* ‚Ä¢ Simulation / Pilot Barangay Rollout o Activity: Participants run a test rollout with observers. o Facilitator Notes: Emphasize learning, not perfection. ‚Ä¢ Debrief & Assessment o Mode: Group reflection, feedback from KCI & DepEd. ‚Ä¢ Recognition Ceremony (Preparation) o Endorsement of participants who completed the cycle for formal recognition as New Heroes; interim MVFA candidates noted. o üìå Formal induction occurs only after full program completion and confirmation at the recognition rites. ‚Ä¢ Closing Message from LGU & KCI. ________________________________________ Facilitator Notes ‚Äì Cross-Cutting ‚Ä¢ Always integrate spiritual grounding with civic responsibility. ‚Ä¢ Use storytelling and testimonies to deepen learning. ‚Ä¢ Track participation via the ABMPD Dashboard (daily reflection + weekly peer mentoring). ‚ÄÉ G.1.b Activity Tables & Partner Roles (Municipal Rollout) Purpose of this Annex This annex provides a detailed breakdown of activities during the Municipal Rollout, including description, mode of delivery, duration, and institutional partners with defined roles. It ensures clarity on ‚Äúwho does what‚Äù for every training component. ________________________________________ Part 1 ‚Äì Awakening & Orientation Activity Description Mode Lead / Partner Roles Duration Opening & Invocation Formal opening: prayer, anthem, inspirational message Face-to-face (plenary) LGU (host); KCI (program lead) 0.5 hr Hamon para sa mga Bagong Bayani (Video Challenge) Emotional priming to see self as ‚ÄúNew Heroes‚Äù Video plenary KCI (content & facilitation) 1 hr Orientation on ABMPD Vision & Structure Introduction of framework, tiers, roles, rollout phases Face-to-face briefing KCI (lead); DepEd (monitoring) 2 hrs Reflection & Sharing (Kamustahan) Small group check-in reflections Small group KCI facilitators 1 hr Daily Reflection (Dashboard Start) Launch of online reflections Online (daily) KCI (content); DepEd (monitoring) 4 weeks (daily) ________________________________________ Part 2 ‚Äì Moral Recovery (Moral Leg) Activity Description Mode Lead / Partner Roles Duration Values Formation & Moral Recovery Workshop Core modules: honesty, discipline, integrity, patriotism, renewal Face-to-face, small group KCI (facilitation); FBOs (participants/observers-in-training) 1 day Facilitation Skills (Intro Level) Training in leading small-group sessions Face-to-face, interactive KCI (lead); DepEd (monitoring) 0.5 day Daily Reflection Guided online reflections Online (daily) KCI (content); DepEd (tracking) 4 weeks (daily) ________________________________________ Part 3 ‚Äì Community Engagement (Community Services Leg) Activity Description Mode Lead / Partner Roles Duration Community Services & Mobilization Training Training on volunteer management and barangay project design Face-to-face KCI (lead); CSOs (participants/trainees) 1 day CSO-led Practicum Participants design barangay service project Workshop CSOs (practice role); KCI (mentoring) 0.5 day Peer Group Sharing & Planning Team discussions and project preparation Small group KCI (facilitation) 0.5 day Daily Reflection Personal discipline and accountability reinforcement Online (daily) KCI (content); DepEd (tracking) 4 weeks (daily) ________________________________________ Part 4 ‚Äì Skills Deepening & Readiness Activity Description Mode Lead / Partner Roles Duration Training of Trainers (ToT 1) Facilitation, mentoring, servant-leadership Face-to-face KCI (lead) 1 day Training of Trainers (ToT 2) Tier-by-tier walkthrough of program Face-to-face KCI (lead); DepEd (monitoring) 1 day Monitoring & Reporting Workshop Use of ABMPD Dashboard, documentation Face-to-face DepEd (lead on KPIs & monitoring); KCI (support) 0.5 day Daily Reflection Online practice for continuity Online (daily) KCI (content); DepEd (tracking) 4 weeks (daily) ________________________________________ Part 5 ‚Äì Application, Consolidation & Recognition Activity Description Mode Lead / Partner Roles Duration Simulation / Pilot Barangay Rollout Test rollout in one pilot barangay Face-to-face, practicum KCI (lead); DepEd (monitoring); LGU (logistics) 0.5 day Debrief & Assessment Group reflection and feedback Plenary discussion KCI (lead); DepEd (support) 0.5 day Recognition Ceremony (Preparation) Endorsement of successful participants for New Hero recognition Face-to-face event KCI (lead); DepEd (observer); LGU (host) 0.5 day Closing Message Inspirational message & next steps Plenary LGU + KCI 0.5 hr ________________________________________ Cross-Cutting Partner Roles ‚Ä¢ KCI (Moral Leg arm) ‚Äì Lead implementor;
