Placement: Annex BT-4 (Outer Ring) under Technical & Donor Partners. ‚Ä¢ Cross-Reference: Annex BS (matrix), Annex BX (document control), Annex BY (closing index). ‚Ä¢ Uniformity: All agreements require notarial acknowledgment and are tracked using status legend üü¶ Planned, üü® Draft, üüß Temporary, üü© Pilot, ‚úÖ Signed, üîÑ Ongoing. ‚ÄÉ üìå BT-T7.1 ‚Äì International NGO Strategic MOA Template (International NGO Strategic MOA Template)________________________________________ ARTICLE I ‚Äì PARTIES & AUTHORITY This Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) is entered into by and between: KDMC Holding Company, the strategic anchor and international engagement arm of the ABMPD Moral Recovery Program (MRP), with authority to negotiate donor agreements and global partnerships, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as ‚ÄúKDMC Holding‚Äù; -and- [International NGO Name], an international humanitarian and development organization duly organized and existing under the laws of [Country], represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as the ‚ÄúINGO.‚Äù ‚Äîwith co-signatory‚Äî Ang Bayaning May Puso at Dang√°l (ABMPD) Holding Company, the institutional custodian of the ABMPD Moral Recovery Program in the Philippines, with full oversight of its subsidiaries, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as ‚ÄúABMPD Holding,‚Äù the domestic custodian and co-signatory. Collectively, the above shall be referred to as the ‚ÄúParties.‚Äù ________________________________________ ARTICLE II ‚Äì PURPOSE & OBJECTIVES The purpose of this MOA is to establish a strategic partnership between KDMC Holding, ABMPD Holding, and [INGO] to secure international program credibility, donor alignment, and grassroots moral recovery impact in the Philippines. Objectives include: 1. Positioning ABMPD‚ÄìMRP as a globally recognized moral recovery and governance reform initiative. 2. Securing international financial, technical, and advocacy support for program rollout. 3. Establishing a dual-anchor partnership: KDMC Holding as the international negotiator, ABMPD Holding as the local custodian and implementor. 4. Ensuring program funds and activities comply with both international donor requirements and Philippine governance frameworks. 5. Enabling scalable and replicable models of moral recovery across Philippine LGUs and regions. ________________________________________ ARTICLE III ‚Äì ROLES & RESPONSIBILITIES KDMC Holding shall: 1. Lead donor negotiations, strategic framing, and global partnership building. 2. Provide international legitimacy and linkage to INGOs, networks, and foundations. 3. Ensure alignment of global donor strategies with ABMPD‚ÄìMRP objectives. ABMPD Holding shall: 1. Serve as the legal custodian of the program in the Philippines. 2. Ensure program rollout, compliance, and accountability within national frameworks. 3. Oversee its subsidiaries in implementing donor-supported activities. 4. Submit periodic narrative and financial reports aligned with donor requirements. The INGO shall: 1. Provide agreed financial, technical, or material support to ABMPD‚ÄìMRP. 2. Align assistance with ABMPD‚Äôs governance, MEL, and sustainability frameworks. 3. Support knowledge exchange, research, and policy advocacy where applicable. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IV ‚Äì GOVERNANCE & OVERSIGHT 1. A Joint Steering Committee (JSC) shall be established, composed of representatives from KDMC Holding, ABMPD Holding, and the INGO. 2. The JSC shall oversee partnership implementation, approve annual work plans and budgets, monitor compliance, and review reports. 3. Disputes shall be resolved amicably through dialogue; unresolved issues shall proceed to arbitration under international development cooperation principles and Philippine law. ________________________________________ ARTICLE V ‚Äì FUNDING & CUSTODIANSHIP 1. Funds from the INGO may be temporarily coursed through DepEd, SUCs, or designated LGU partners as interim custodians. 2. Final custodianship of funds shall transition to the ABMPD Foundation ‚Äì Finance Subsidiary once accredited (SEC, BIR, COA, BSP). 3. KDMC Holding shall maintain international reporting to donors, while ABMPD Holding ensures domestic accountability. 4. All funds shall be subject to annual independent financial audit acceptable to both the INGO and ABMPD Holding. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VI ‚Äì TERM & TERMINATION 1. This MOA shall be valid for [X] years from signing. 2. It may be renewed upon mutual consent of all Parties. 3. Either Party may terminate the agreement with ninety (90) days‚Äô written notice, subject to settlement of pending obligations. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VII ‚Äì COMPLIANCE & LEGAL SAFEGUARDS 1. This MOA shall comply with Philippine laws, donor guidelines, and ABMPD governance protocols. 2. Contributions shall not be used for partisan politics, military purposes, or activities contrary to humanitarian and development principles. 3. Safeguards against misuse of funds, corruption, and conflicts of interest shall be strictly enforced. 4. The Parties commit to comply with international anti-terrorism financing and anti-money laundering regulations. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VIII ‚Äì CONFIDENTIALITY & DATA PROTECTION All records, donor agreements, and personal data shall be managed under international donor protocols, the Philippine Data Privacy Act of 2012, and ABMPD confidentiality policies. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IX ‚Äì EFFECTIVITY & EXECUTION This MOA shall take effect immediately upon signing by the authorized representatives of the Parties. Signed this ___ day of [Month], 20__, in [City], Philippines. FOR KDMC HOLDING ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] FOR ABMPD HOLDING [Name] ‚Äì [Position] FOR [INGO NAME] [Name] ‚Äì [Position] Witnesses: ________________________________________ NOTARIAL ACKNOWLEDGMENT (Template) SUBSCRIBED AND SWORN to before me this ___ day of [Month], 20__, at [City], Philippines, by the Parties who are personally known to me and presented competent evidence of identity. Notary Public ‚ÄÉ üìå BT-T7.2 ‚Äì UN Agency Partnership MOA Template (KDMC Holding + ABMPD Holding ‚Üî UN Agencies)________________________________________ ARTICLE I ‚Äì PARTIES & AUTHORITY This Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) is entered into by and between: KDMC Holding Company, the strategic anchor of the ABMPD Moral Recovery Program (MRP), authorized to negotiate international partnerships and mobilize donor cooperation, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as ‚ÄúKDMC Holding‚Äù; -and- Ang Bayaning May Puso at Dang√°l (ABMPD) Holding Company, the institutional custodian of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP in the Philippines, with oversight of its subsidiaries and governance framework, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as ‚ÄúABMPD Holding‚Äù; -and- [UN Agency Name] (e.g., UNDP, UNICEF, UNESCO, WHO, ILO), an international agency of the United Nations system with mandate under the UN Charter to support development, humanitarian, and governance programs, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as the ‚ÄúUN Agency.‚Äù Collectively, the above shall be referred to as the ‚ÄúParties.‚Äù ________________________________________ ARTICLE II ‚Äì PURPOSE & OBJECTIVES The purpose of this MOA is to formalize collaboration between KDMC Holding, ABMPD Holding, and [UN Agency] to integrate ABMPD‚ÄìMRP into UN-supported governance, education, health, and development frameworks. Objectives include: 1. Aligning ABMPD‚ÄìMRP with the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and Philippine national priorities. 2. Establishing ABMPD‚ÄìMRP as a recognized partner program in UN Agency Country Frameworks and related cooperation strategies. 3. Mobilizing technical and financial support for grassroots implementation through LGUs, CSOs, and academic partners. 4. Ensuring accountability and monitoring, evaluation, and learning (MEL) systems compliant with both UN standards and ABMPD governance. 5. Promoting policy coherence, knowledge sharing, and capacity-building in alignment with UN Country Team (UNCT) priorities. ________________________________________ ARTICLE III ‚Äì ROLES & RESPONSIBILITIES KDMC Holding shall: 1. Lead international negotiations and maintain diplomatic linkage with UN Country Offices and Headquarters. 2. Frame ABMPD‚ÄìMRP as a model governance and moral recovery initiative in donor and UN platforms. 3. Secure commitments for program inclusion in UN Cooperation Frameworks (UNCF) and multi-agency initiatives. ABMPD Holding shall: 1. Serve as the legal custodian of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP in the Philippines. 2. Ensure program rollout, oversight, and compliance with local governance systems. 3. Manage its subsidiaries (Finance, HR, Training, RME) for program implementation. 4. Provide reports, data, and documentation required by the UN Agency and the ABMPD Governance Board. The UN Agency shall: 1. Provide technical, financial, or policy support aligned with its sectoral mandate. 2. Facilitate integration of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP into relevant UN agency programs (e.g., UNICEF for education, UNDP for governance, UNESCO for cultural/values integration, WHO for health-related modules, ILO for labor/skills development). 3. Mobilize linkages with other UN agencies, donors, and government stakeholders. 4. Monitor program contributions in line with UN evaluation standards and report to the UN Resident Coordinator where applicable. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IV ‚Äì GOVERNANCE & OVERSIGHT 1. A Joint Steering Committee (JSC) shall be established, composed of representatives from KDMC Holding, ABMPD Holding, and the UN Agency. 2. The JSC shall meet at least twice a year to review progress, approve annual work plans and budgets, and assess compliance. 3. Policy and strategic issues shall be referred to the UN Resident Coordinator‚Äôs Office (RCO) for alignment with the UN Country Team (UNCT). 4. Subnational coordination may be established through LGU‚ÄìUN‚ÄìABMPD clusters to localize implementation. ________________________________________ ARTICLE V ‚Äì FUNDING & CUSTODIANSHIP 1. UN Agency funding shall be transferred in accordance with UN Financial Regulations and Rules and consistent with ABMPD governance policies. 2. Interim custodianship of funds may be assigned to DepEd, SUCs, or LGUs where program activities are based. 3. Final custodianship shall rest with the ABMPD Foundation ‚Äì Finance Subsidiary once duly accredited (SEC, BIR, COA, BSP if applicable). 4. KDMC Holding shall co-sign for international funder assurance, while ABMPD Holding shall account for domestic utilization of funds. 5. All financial flows shall be subject to annual independent audit recognized by both the UN Agency and ABMPD Holding. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VI ‚Äì TERM & TERMINATION 1. This MOA shall be valid for [X] years, aligned with the UN Cooperation Framework cycle. 2. Renewal may occur upon consensus of the Parties. 3. Either Party may terminate the agreement with ninety (90) days‚Äô written notice, subject to liquidation of funds and completion of ongoing activities. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VII ‚Äì COMPLIANCE & LEGAL SAFEGUARDS 1. This MOA shall comply with Philippine law, UN Agency regulations, and ABMPD governance frameworks. 2. Funds and resources shall not be diverted to political, military, or non-developmental purposes. 3. Safeguards against corruption, fraud, and conflicts of interest shall be implemented in line with UN and ABMPD protocols. 4. The Parties commit to uphold UN Human Rights, Humanitarian Principles, and Do No Harm standards in all joint activities. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VIII ‚Äì CONFIDENTIALITY & DATA PROTECTION All data, records, and program reports shall be governed by the UN‚Äôs data protection policies, the Philippine Data Privacy Act of 2012, and ABMPD confidentiality protocols. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IX ‚Äì EFFECTIVITY & EXECUTION This MOA shall take effect immediately upon signing by the authorized representatives of the Parties. Signed this ___ day of [Month], 20__, in [City], Philippines. FOR KDMC HOLDING ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] FOR ABMPD HOLDING ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] FOR [UN AGENCY NAME] ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] Witnesses: ________________________________________ ________________________________________ ________________________________________ NOTARIAL ACKNOWLEDGMENT (Template) SUBSCRIBED AND SWORN to before me this ___ day of [Month], 20__, at [City], Philippines, by the Parties who are personally known to me and presented competent evidence of identity. Notary Public ‚ÄÉ üìå BT-T7.3 ‚Äì Multilateral Bank Partnership MOA Template (KDMC Holding + ABMPD Holding ‚Üî Multilateral Development Banks ‚Äì ADB, World Bank, etc.)________________________________________ ARTICLE I ‚Äì PARTIES & AUTHORITY This Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) is entered into by and between: KDMC Holding Company, the strategic anchor of the ABMPD Moral Recovery Program (MRP), authorized to negotiate with multilateral institutions and secure development financing, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as ‚ÄúKDMC Holding‚Äù; -and- Ang Bayaning May Puso at Dang√°l (ABMPD) Holding Company, the institutional custodian of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP, with oversight over its subsidiaries and governance framework, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as ‚ÄúABMPD Holding‚Äù; -and- [Multilateral Bank Name] (e.g., Asian Development Bank, World Bank), an international financial institution with development financing, governance reform, and social transformation mandates, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as the ‚ÄúMultilateral Bank.‚Äù Collectively, the above shall be referred to as the ‚ÄúParties.‚Äù ________________________________________ ARTICLE II ‚Äì PURPOSE & OBJECTIVES The purpose of this MOA is to establish collaboration between KDMC Holding, ABMPD Holding, and [Multilateral Bank] for financing, technical support, and policy engagement to mainstream moral recovery and governance transformation in the Philippines. Objectives include: 1. Embedding ABMPD‚ÄìMRP in national and local governance reforms supported by the Bank. 2. Mobilizing development financing for moral recovery, leadership training, and values-based education. 3. Strengthening transparency, accountability, and MEL systems in line with Bank safeguard policies. 4. Leveraging multilateral expertise in institutional development, poverty reduction, and inclusive growth. 5. Promoting long-term sustainability of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP through integrated financial and policy support. ________________________________________ ARTICLE III ‚Äì ROLES & RESPONSIBILITIES KDMC Holding shall: 1. Act as the strategic negotiator with [Multilateral Bank] for program financing and policy support. 2. Represent ABMPD‚ÄìMRP in multilateral forums and ensure global recognition of the initiative. 3. Provide assurances of governance compliance and donor confidence. ABMPD Holding shall: 1. Serve as the legal custodian and implementor of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP in the Philippines. 2. Manage programmatic rollout through subsidiaries (Finance, HR, Training, RME). 3. Ensure compliance with Bank‚Äôs environmental, social, and governance safeguards. 4. Submit periodic narrative and financial reports, including audited statements, in accordance with Bank requirements. The Multilateral Bank shall: 1. Provide financial assistance (loans, grants, or blended financing) aligned with ABMPD‚ÄìMRP objectives. 2. Extend technical expertise in governance reform, education, health, or community development. 3. Facilitate knowledge-sharing and capacity building between ABMPD partners and international peers. 4. Monitor funded initiatives according to Bank safeguard and fiduciary policies. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IV ‚Äì GOVERNANCE & OVERSIGHT 1. A Joint Oversight and Safeguards Committee (JOSC) shall be established, composed of representatives from KDMC Holding, ABMPD Holding, and [Multilateral Bank]. 2. The JOSC shall ensure compliance with Bank safeguard policies, ABMPD MEL framework, and Philippine regulatory standards. 3. Policy issues shall be elevated to the ABMPD Governance Board and the Bank‚Äôs Country Director. 4. All committee proceedings shall be documented and subject to review during annual evaluations. ________________________________________ ARTICLE V ‚Äì FUNDING & CUSTODIANSHIP 1. Financing may be structured as grants, loans, or blended mechanisms in accordance with Bank guidelines. 2. Interim custodianship of funds may be assigned to DepEd, SUCs, or LGUs where applicable. 3. Final custodianship shall transition to the ABMPD Foundation ‚Äì Finance Subsidiary upon full accreditation with SEC, BIR, and COA. 4. KDMC Holding shall serve as guarantor for international financing, while ABMPD Holding shall account for domestic implementation and fund use. 5. All financial transactions shall be subject to annual independent audit, jointly recognized by ABMPD and [Multilateral Bank]. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VI ‚Äì TERM & TERMINATION 1. This MOA shall remain effective for the duration of the Bank-funded project cycle ([X] years). 2. Renewal shall be subject to mutual agreement and project extension approval by the Bank. 3. Either Party may terminate the agreement with one hundred twenty (120) days‚Äô written notice, subject to liquidation of funds and completion of pending activities. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VII ‚Äì COMPLIANCE & LEGAL SAFEGUARDS 1. The Parties shall comply with Philippine law, Bank safeguard policies, and ABMPD governance protocols. 2. Funds shall be used solely for agreed development purposes, with zero tolerance for misuse, fraud, or corruption. 3. An independent audit shall be conducted annually, and audit reports shall be shared with all Parties. 4. All joint activities shall uphold environmental sustainability, social inclusion, and ethical standards. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VIII ‚Äì CONFIDENTIALITY & DATA PROTECTION Program data and reports shall be governed by the Bank‚Äôs disclosure policies, the Philippine Data Privacy Act of 2012, and ABMPD confidentiality protocols. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IX ‚Äì EFFECTIVITY & EXECUTION This MOA shall take effect immediately upon signing by the authorized representatives of the Parties. Signed this ___ day of [Month], 20__, in [City], Philippines. FOR KDMC HOLDING ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] FOR ABMPD HOLDING ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] FOR [MULTILATERAL BANK NAME] ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] Witnesses: ________________________________________ NOTARIAL ACKNOWLEDGMENT (Template) SUBSCRIBED AND SWORN to before me this ___ day of [Month], 20__, at [City], Philippines, by the Parties who are personally known to me and presented competent evidence of identity. Notary Public ‚ÄÉ üìå BT-T7.4 ‚Äì Bilateral Donor MOA Template (ABMPD Holding ‚Üî Bilateral Donors ‚Äì USAID, JICA, KOICA, GIZ, etc.)________________________________________ ARTICLE I ‚Äì PARTIES & AUTHORITY This Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) is entered into by and between: Ang Bayaning May Puso at Dang√°l (ABMPD) Holding Company, the institutional custodian of the ABMPD Moral Recovery Program (MRP), with oversight over subsidiaries and nationwide rollout, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as ‚ÄúABMPD Holding‚Äù; -and- [Bilateral Donor Agency] (e.g., USAID, JICA, KOICA, GIZ), an official international development cooperation agency of [Country], represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as the ‚ÄúDonor.‚Äù Collectively, the above shall be referred to as the ‚ÄúParties.‚Äù ________________________________________ ARTICLE II ‚Äì PURPOSE & OBJECTIVES The purpose of this MOA is to establish a formal partnership between ABMPD Holding and [Donor] to support the implementation of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP through grants, capacity-building, and community-based development projects. Objectives include: 1. Strengthening grassroots governance and moral recovery through donor-supported projects. 2. Mobilizing financial and technical resources for education, leadership, health, and livelihood programs. 3. Enhancing transparency, accountability, and MEL systems to meet donor compliance standards. 4. Promoting mutual learning, cultural exchange, and cross-country sharing of best practices. 5. Supporting long-term sustainability of ABMPD‚ÄìMRP through donor-aligned reforms and institutional capacity. ________________________________________ ARTICLE III ‚Äì ROLES & RESPONSIBILITIES ABMPD Holding shall: 1. Serve as the lead custodian and implementor of donor-funded ABMPD‚ÄìMRP projects. 2. Ensure proper financial management, procurement, and reporting in compliance with donor regulations. 3. Mobilize subsidiaries (Finance, HR, Training, RME) to execute funded projects. 4. Submit quarterly and annual reports, including financial liquidation and program impact assessments. 5. Facilitate donor field visits, evaluations, and independent audits. The Donor shall: 1. Provide financial grants, in-kind contributions, or technical assistance for agreed ABMPD‚ÄìMRP initiatives. 2. Offer technical expertise and advisory support in relevant program areas (education, governance, health, training). 3. Monitor implementation through site visits, program reviews, and audits. 4. Facilitate knowledge-sharing with parallel programs in other partner countries. 5. Recognize ABMPD‚ÄìMRP as an aligned initiative under the donor‚Äôs official development assistance framework. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IV ‚Äì GOVERNANCE & OVERSIGHT 1. A Joint Project Steering Committee (JPSC) shall be established, composed of representatives from ABMPD Holding and [Donor]. 2. The JPSC shall approve project work plans, budgets, and MEL indicators. 3. Oversight shall be exercised through regular reviews, joint monitoring, and compliance with ABMPD and donor standards. 4. Dispute resolution mechanisms shall be guided by both Philippine law and donor country development cooperation agreements. ________________________________________ ARTICLE V ‚Äì FUNDING & CUSTODIANSHIP 1. Donor funds shall be released to ABMPD Holding through agreed disbursement mechanisms (e.g., tranches, performance-based releases). 2. Temporary Custodianship: Where accreditation is pending, funds may be held by DepEd, SUCs, or LGUs as interim custodians. 3. Final Custodianship: Custodianship shall transition to the ABMPD Foundation ‚Äì Finance Subsidiary once fully accredited with SEC, BIR, and COA. 4. ABMPD Holding shall ensure traceability and accountability of all donor funds, with expenditures tied to approved work plans. 5. All fund use shall be subject to annual independent audit acceptable to both Parties. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VI ‚Äì TERM & TERMINATION 1. This MOA shall remain in effect for the donor project cycle ([X] years). 2. Renewal may be negotiated based on performance, donor priorities, and mutual agreement. 3. Either Party may terminate this MOA with ninety (90) days‚Äô written notice, provided all obligations, audits, and fund liquidations are duly settled. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VII ‚Äì COMPLIANCE & LEGAL SAFEGUARDS 1. The Parties shall comply with Philippine law, donor country regulations, and ABMPD governance protocols. 2. All projects shall adhere to donor safeguard policies, including anti-corruption, gender equity, environmental protection, and human rights standards. 3. Independent audits shall be conducted annually or as otherwise required by the Donor. 4. In case of misuse or breach, the Donor reserves the right to suspend or withdraw funding subject to due process. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VIII ‚Äì CONFIDENTIALITY & DATA PROTECTION All records, reports, and personal data generated under this MOA shall be governed by the Philippine Data Privacy Act of 2012, ABMPD confidentiality protocols, and donor country data-sharing agreements. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IX ‚Äì EFFECTIVITY & EXECUTION This MOA shall take effect immediately upon signing by the authorized representatives of the Parties. Signed this ___ day of [Month], 20__, in [City], Philippines. FOR ABMPD HOLDING ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] FOR [BILATERAL DONOR] ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] Witnesses: ________________________________________ NOTARIAL ACKNOWLEDGMENT (Template) SUBSCRIBED AND SWORN to before me this ___ day of [Month], 20__, at [City], Philippines, by the Parties who are personally known to me and presented competent evidence of identity. Notary Public ‚ÄÉ üìå BT-T7.5 ‚Äì Technical Cooperation MOA Template (ABMPD Subsidiaries ‚Üî International Universities / Training Institutes)________________________________________ ARTICLE I ‚Äì PARTIES & AUTHORITY This Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) is entered into by and between: [ABMPD Subsidiary Name] (Finance / HR / Training / Research, Monitoring & Evaluation), a duly constituted functional unit under ABMPD Holding, represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as the ‚ÄúSubsidiary‚Äù; -and- [International University / Training Institute Name], a duly recognized academic or technical institution based in [Country], represented herein by [Name], in his/her capacity as [Position], hereinafter referred to as the ‚ÄúTechnical Partner.‚Äù Collectively, the above shall be referred to as the ‚ÄúParties.‚Äù ________________________________________ ARTICLE II ‚Äì PURPOSE & OBJECTIVES The purpose of this MOA is to establish a technical cooperation framework between the Subsidiary and [Technical Partner] to strengthen academic validation, leadership incubation, and technical capacity-building within the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP. Objectives include: 1. Co-developing training modules, curricula, and research studies on values formation, governance, and moral recovery. 2. Facilitating faculty, trainer, and expert exchanges between the Philippines and [Partner Country]. 3. Accrediting ABMPD training programs and leadership certifications with international academic recognition. 4. Supporting advanced training abroad for ABMPD trainers, VFAs, and coordinators. 5. Promoting joint publications, conferences, and policy research to elevate ABMPD‚ÄìMRP internationally. ________________________________________ ARTICLE III ‚Äì ROLES & RESPONSIBILITIES The ABMPD Subsidiary shall: 1. Provide program design, training requirements, and Philippine contextual frameworks. 2. Coordinate with ABMPD Holding for governance, MEL, and donor compliance. 3. Mobilize participants (trainers, VFAs, local officials, community leaders) for technical programs. 4. Submit regular reports on outcomes, performance, and knowledge transfer. 5. Ensure that training outputs integrate into ABMPD‚Äôs nationwide implementation. The Technical Partner shall: 1. Deliver technical expertise, faculty engagement, and certification support. 2. Host exchange programs, workshops, and joint research initiatives. 3. Provide facilities, online platforms, or academic credit recognition (where applicable). 4. Endorse academic validation of ABMPD modules to ensure global credibility. 5. Facilitate linkages with other international institutions for expanded collaboration. ________________________________________ ARTICLE IV ‚Äì GOVERNANCE & OVERSIGHT 1. Oversight shall be exercised jointly by ABMPD Holding (through the Subsidiary) and the Technical Partner‚Äôs designated office. 2. A Joint Academic-Technical Committee (JATC) shall be formed to guide cooperation activities, approve curricula, and monitor impact. 3. Policy and dispute resolution shall be undertaken through consultation; unresolved matters shall follow arbitration under Philippine and international law. ________________________________________ ARTICLE V ‚Äì FUNDING & CUSTODIANSHIP 1. Funding for joint activities may be mobilized through donors, scholarships, or cost-sharing agreements between the Parties. 2. Temporary Custodianship: Where necessary, program funds may pass through DepEd, SUCs, or LGUs as interim custodians. 3. Final Custodianship: All funds related to technical cooperation shall transition to the ABMPD Foundation ‚Äì Finance Subsidiary once fully accredited with SEC, BIR, and COA. 4. Both Parties shall ensure transparent financial management, with periodic reporting and audit mechanisms. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VI ‚Äì TERM & TERMINATION 1. This MOA shall be effective for a period of [X] years, renewable upon mutual agreement. 2. Either Party may terminate this MOA with ninety (90) days‚Äô written notice, provided that pending activities are duly completed and obligations settled. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VII ‚Äì COMPLIANCE & LEGAL SAFEGUARDS 1. The Parties shall comply with Philippine laws, ABMPD governance protocols, and the legal requirements of [Partner Country]. 2. Intellectual Property (IP) Rights: Co-developed modules, curricula, and research outputs shall be jointly owned, unless a separate IP agreement is signed. 3. Both Parties shall uphold ethical standards, anti-discrimination principles, and academic freedom. 4. Safeguards against plagiarism, conflict of interest, and misuse of research shall be strictly observed. ________________________________________ ARTICLE VIII ‚Äì CONFIDENTIALITY & DATA PROTECTION All academic records, personal data, and research findings shall be governed by the Philippine Data Privacy Act of 2012, ABMPD confidentiality protocols, and applicable international data protection laws (e.g., GDPR). ________________________________________ ARTICLE IX ‚Äì EFFECTIVITY & EXECUTION This MOA shall take effect immediately upon signing by the authorized representatives of the Parties. Signed this ___ day of [Month], 20__, in [City], Philippines / [Partner Country]. FOR ABMPD [SUBSIDIARY NAME] ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] FOR [TECHNICAL PARTNER] ________________________________________ [Name] ‚Äì [Position] Witnesses: ‚ÄÉ 6. Usage & Integration Guide Introduction This section serves as the operational manual for how Annex BT is to be used, updated, and cross-referenced within the ABMPD‚ÄìMRP governance system. It ensures that MOAs are not only stored but also actively managed, monitored, and integrated into program rollout. ________________________________________ 6.1 Purpose of the Guide ‚Ä¢ To standardize how MOAs under Annex BT are accessed and applied during program implementation. ‚Ä¢ To ensure traceability, accountability, and version control of all agreements. ‚Ä¢ To link Annex BT with related annexes and protocols, ensuring consistency across the governance framework. ________________________________________ 6.2 How to Use Annex BT During Rollout 1. Reference Point: During program rollout, Annex BT serves as the master reference for all signed MOAs across ecosystem levels (Core, Government, Civil Society, Technical, Donor). 2. Implementation Alignment: Field teams and subsidiaries must consult Annex BT before launching activities to confirm the existence, scope, and validity of MOAs with partner entities. 3. Strategic Communication: Branding and documentation templates embedded in Annex BT shall be used for all MOA-linked reports, letters, and partner communications to ensure uniformity. 4. Compliance Anchor: No partnership activity may proceed without reference to the applicable MOA listed in Annex BT and cleared under BX (Document Control Protocols). ________________________________________ 6.3 Process for Updating MOA Statuses 1. Initial Entry: Upon signing, the MOA must be logged into Annex BT by the Document Control Team, tagged with: Annex Code, Parties, Scope, Status, Duration, and Signatories. 2. Status Tracking: Statuses (Draft, Planned, Active, Renewed, Terminated) must be updated quarterly or as soon as any change occurs. 3. Responsible Offices: o Subsidiaries update field-level or technical MOAs. o ABMPD Holding validates institutional or donor-level MOAs. o KDMC Holding ensures updates for international MOAs (UN, INGOs, MDBs, Bilateral Donors). 4. Audit Trail: All status changes must include a timestamp, responsible officer, and supporting document (e.g., signed addendum, renewal letter). ________________________________________ 6.4 Cross-Referencing with Related Annexes Annex BT does not stand alone; it must always be read and applied together with the following: ‚Ä¢ BS ‚Äì Subsidiary Operations Annex: For MOAs executed by or requiring subsidiary action. ‚Ä¢ BX ‚Äì Document Control Protocols: Governs how MOAs are drafted, coded, stored, and secured. ‚Ä¢ BY ‚Äì MEL & Reporting Annex: Ensures MOA outputs are linked to monitoring indicators and reporting obligations. ‚Ä¢ BZ ‚Äì Branding & Communications Annex (if applicable): For consistency in partner-facing communications and logos. ________________________________________ 6.5 Reminder: Document Control Protocols (BX) ‚Ä¢ All MOAs, whether draft or final, must pass through BX before recognition and use. ‚Ä¢ Unauthorized or unsigned MOAs are invalid and cannot be used for program activities. ‚Ä¢ BX also provides the archival system, ensuring that terminated or expired MOAs remain traceable for audit purposes.

Reserve ABMPD Ecosystem

I. Roles of Key Players in ABMPD (Foundational/Pre-Implementation Phase) ________________________________________ Note: for inclusions Within the ABMPD Ecosystem, the National Moral Oversight Council (NMOC) functions as the moral counterpart of the combined ethical and governance institutions of the State ‚Äî such as the Civil Service Commission, the Office of the Ombudsman, and the DILG ‚Äî serving as the national custodian of moral integrity standards and the transmitter of conscience-based governance directives.‚Äù Part III ‚Äì System Alignment and Verification Framework ‚û§ Chapter 3 ‚Äì Ethical Verification and Oversight Mechanism 3.2 Structure of Oversight Bodies ________________________________________ 1. ABMPD Holding Company ‚Äì Strategic Anchor (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: ABMPD Holding Company serves as the strategic and governance backbone of the ABMPD Program during the Pre-Implementation Phase. Its primary role is to establish the program‚Äôs institutional credibility, coordinate with high-level partners, and lay the foundation for the full ecosystem rollout. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Strategic Governance & Oversight o Provides institutional identity and legitimacy for ABMPD at the provincial level (Isabela) while preparing the foundation for future national and international expansion. o Ensures alignment of ABMPD with its vision, mission, and long-term theory of change. o Exercises oversight over KCI (as Lead Implementor), providing accountability mechanisms and framework consistency. ‚Ä¢ MOA & Partnership Development o Signs MOAs with national/provincial institutional partners (DepEd, DILG, ISU, AIM, The 700 Club Asia, NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance) to secure policy support, technical expertise, and validation roles. o Serves as the formal legal counterpart for external organizations, creating a central point of coordination. o LGU Engagement: While direct MOAs with municipal and barangay LGUs are executed by KCI, these engagements fall under the oversight of ABMPD Holding to ensure governance alignment, compliance, and consistency with the Masterplan. ‚Ä¢ Seed Funding & Financial Stewardship o Manages initial capitalization, start-up costs, and donor engagement during pre-implementation. o Coordinates with DepEd (as interim custodian of donor funds) until the ABMPD Foundation and Finance & Compliance subsidiary are formally established. ‚Ä¢ Institutional Ecosystem Building o Lays the groundwork for establishing subsidiaries (Finance & Compliance, HR, Research & M&E, etc.), though these remain in planning during pre-implementation. o Prepares governance policies, compliance frameworks, and operational standards for rollout. ‚Ä¢ External Representation o Acts as the program‚Äôs public face when engaging institutional partners, academic institutions, research organizations, and national policy bodies. o Builds relationships with prospective donors, CSR partners, and international collaborators, ensuring ABMPD is presented as a credible, structured initiative. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With KCI: Holds a master MOA with KCI defining roles (Holding = strategic anchor, KCI = lead implementor). o With Partners: Engages DepEd, DILG, ISU, AIM, The 700 Club Asia, and the Unified Faith-Based Council (NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance) at the policy, research, validation, and faith-based levels. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, ABMPD Holding is the institutional brain and backbone of the program. It does not yet manage full subsidiaries but ensures that all external MOAs, governance, and seed funding systems are in place before rollout begins. ________________________________________ 2. Kingdom Chronicles Inc. (KCI) ‚Äì Lead Implementor (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: KCI serves as the operational engine and lead implementor of the ABMPD Program at the community level. It translates the masterplan into action by directly engaging LGUs, barangays, and grassroots stakeholders. KCI pilots the rollout, refines the operational model, and validates implementation strategies through real-world practice. Functions: ‚Ä¢ MOA & LGU Partnership Building o Signs MOAs directly with the 5 municipalities and 1 city identified for the pilot and rollout phases. o Acts as the official operational partner of LGUs, barangays, and community stakeholders. o Ensures alignment of LGU commitments (venues, manpower, logistics, policy support) with ABMPD‚Äôs barangay-to-municipality rollout framework. ‚Ä¢ Pilot Rollout & Barangay Implementation o Commences implementation in 1 municipality ‚Üí 1 barangay first, then gradually expands to full municipal saturation before scaling to other towns. o Tests and refines modules for volunteer formation, values education, and community services at the barangay level. o Serves as the ground-level training hub for volunteers, teachers, and community facilitators. ‚Ä¢ Operational Systems & Refinement o Develops operational templates: barangay engagement protocols, reporting systems, and LGU partnership mechanisms. o Refines processes based on pilot results, ensuring efficiency before multi-municipality expansion. o Provides feedback to ABMPD Holding, ISU, and AIM for validation and system improvement. ‚Ä¢ Community Engagement & Partnerships o While UFBO and UCSO are not yet formally registered, KCI temporarily assumes the function of mobilizing faith-based organizations and civil society groups as community partners during rollout. o Engages barangay leaders, civic groups, schools, and churches as partners in the pilot implementation. ‚Ä¢ Volunteer Development & Mobilization o Leads the recruitment, training, and mobilization of the first set of volunteer formation associations (VFA prototypes) in barangays. o Establishes monitoring systems for volunteer performance, retention, and impact. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With ABMPD Holding: Operates under a master MOA; ABMPD Holding = strategic anchor, KCI = ground-level implementor. o With LGUs: Acts as the direct implementing arm, managing barangay-level and municipal rollout activities. o With Research Partners (ISU, AIM, The 700 Club Asia): Provides field data, reports, and pilot documentation for validation and refinement. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, KCI is the boots-on-the-ground implementor of ABMPD. It builds partnerships with LGUs, pilots the barangay rollout model, trains volunteers, and generates learning that informs the wider provincial expansion. ________________________________________ 3. Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) ‚Äì Government Policy Partner (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: DILG acts as the policy enabler and governance integrator of ABMPD, ensuring that the program‚Äôs rollout aligns with national and provincial frameworks for local governance, barangay development, and community empowerment. Its role is to provide institutional cover, endorse the program to LGUs, and integrate ABMPD into existing governance mechanisms. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Policy & Governance Alignment o Reviews ABMPD‚Äôs framework and modules to ensure alignment with national governance priorities, particularly in moral recovery, citizen engagement, and values formation. o Integrates ABMPD within existing DILG-led initiatives such as barangay governance, participatory governance, and capacity-building programs. ‚Ä¢ Endorsement to LGUs o Provides formal endorsement or circulars to provincial, municipal, and barangay LGUs to legitimize the program. o Encourages LGUs to partner with KCI for rollout, strengthening municipal and barangay ownership. ‚Ä¢ Capacity Support & Monitoring o Assigns DILG provincial and municipal focal persons to monitor ABMPD pilot implementation. o Offers technical assistance to LGUs in passing ordinances, resolutions, or policies institutionalizing ABMPD locally. ‚Ä¢ Institutional Partnership o Partners directly with ABMPD Holding Company at the strategic level via MOA for policy integration and governance support. o Coordinates with KCI indirectly through LGUs, ensuring smooth flow between policy endorsement (DILG) and operational implementation (KCI). ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With ABMPD Holding: Signs MOA as a policy and governance partner, ensuring national-to-local alignment. o With LGUs: Acts as the oversight body encouraging compliance and adoption at the municipal and barangay levels. o With Research Partners: Provides government data and validation linkages useful for ISU, AIM, and The 700 Club Asia research. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, DILG ensures ABMPD has policy legitimacy and integration within the governance system. It acts as the bridge between ABMPD Holding and LGUs, providing institutional authority, endorsements, and monitoring support. ________________________________________ 4. Department of Education (DepEd) ‚Äì Education & Interim Fund Custodian (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: DepEd serves as the technical training partner and interim financial custodian for ABMPD during the pre-implementation and early rollout stages. While student engagement formally begins only in Tier 3, DepEd is already a critical enabler during the pilot through training, monitoring support, and financial stewardship (until the ABMPD Foundation and Finance & Compliance Subsidiary are operational). It also provides institutional credibility to ABMPD by serving as a trusted government steward for donor-linked resources and by aligning values-based training with formal education standards. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Technical Training & Pedagogy Support o Provides expertise in pedagogy, training methods, and instructional design to strengthen KCI‚Äôs capacity in training Values Formation Advocates (VFAs) at barangay and municipal levels. o Assists in preparing Training of Trainers (ToT) modules and standardized teaching-learning materials. o Ensures training modules are contextualized for barangay-level realities while remaining consistent with DepEd‚Äôs quality assurance benchmarks. ‚Ä¢ Capacity-Building for VFAs o Partners with KCI in equipping MVFA and BVFA candidates with skills in facilitation, monitoring, documentation, and evaluation. o Ensures training systems follow recognized education standards, making them scalable and replicable. ‚Ä¢ Interim Fund Custodianship o Acts as a temporary financial custodian for donor or seed funding linked to training, education, and early pilot operations. o Maintains proper accounting, reporting, and fund release mechanisms until the ABMPD Foundation and Finance & Compliance Subsidiary are fully registered and operational. o Provides assurance of transparency and accountability to donors and partners during the pilot phase. o Reports jointly with ABMPD Holding Company to ensure transparency and shared oversight in the handling of interim funds. ‚Ä¢ Monitoring & Evaluation Support o Deploys selected DepEd supervisors/teachers as focal persons for monitoring training quality and documentation. o Helps KCI and ABMPD Holding refine evaluation tools for consistency in data collection and validation. o Channels feedback to research partners (ISU, AIM, CCCI) for evidence-based improvement of training frameworks. ‚Ä¢ Education Sector Integration (Tier 3 Onwards) o Prepares the groundwork for eventual student engagement modules at the high school and tertiary level, including service-learning, leadership development, and youth volunteer formation. o Aligns ABMPD modules with DepEd‚Äôs youth development and values education frameworks once program maturity is reached. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With ABMPD Holding: Formal MOA as a national/provincial partner for training and interim fund custodianship. o With KCI: Operational collaboration in training VFAs, monitoring implementation, and providing school-based venues for capacity-building. o With Research Partners (ISU, AIM, The 700 Club Asia) and Faith-Based Partner (NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance): Coordination for access to school data and validation of training impacts. o With LGUs: Coordinates with municipal and barangay LGUs (via KCI) to facilitate school-based training, community volunteer integration, and barangay-level education activities. üìå Summary: DepEd‚Äôs role in the pre-implementation stage is not yet about student involvement, but rather about being a pillar for training, quality assurance, and financial stewardship. This ensures that the program is transparent, well-documented, and credible to donors and stakeholders while preparing for eventual integration into schools at Tier 3. ________________________________________ 5. Isabela State University (ISU) ‚Äì Provincial Academic & Research Partner (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: ISU serves as the provincial-level academic and research partner of ABMPD, anchoring the program in evidence-based practices, training validation, and localized research. It bridges the gap between theory and implementation by documenting pilot rollouts, evaluating program outcomes, and ensuring that ABMPD modules are academically sound, contextually relevant, and scalable across municipalities. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Research & Validation o Leads the design of monitoring and evaluation frameworks for the pilot stage. o Conducts baseline studies, needs assessments, and post-training evaluations to measure the effectiveness of ABMPD modules. o Ensures that outputs meet academic and policy research standards for credibility and replicability. ‚Ä¢ Academic Integration & Knowledge Development o Aligns ABMPD practices with academic theories in governance, education, social development, and community engagement. o Develops case studies, research papers, and knowledge products based on pilot implementation, contributing to ABMPD‚Äôs thought leadership. o Serves as the primary local research repository for ABMPD data and findings. ‚Ä¢ Capacity-Building Support o Provides resource persons and faculty experts to support training modules delivered by KCI and DepEd. o Assists in the development of localized content, manuals, and evidence-based tools for VFAs, barangays, and LGUs. o Ensures that training design and delivery align with both educational standards and local realities. ‚Ä¢ Policy Linkage & Academic Legitimacy o Engages with provincial government units, DILG, and DepEd to validate findings and ensure integration with governance priorities. o Positions ABMPD within provincial development and education agendas through academic credibility. o Serves as the research backbone for future policy advocacy at provincial and regional levels. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With ABMPD Holding: Formal MOA as academic and research partner, providing technical validation of systems and processes. o With KCI: Field collaboration through documentation, data analysis, and evaluation of pilot rollout results. o With DepEd: Co-develops monitoring tools and validates training methodologies. o With AIM & The 700 Club Asia: Acts as the provincial counterpart for national-level research and policy integration. o With NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance: Collaborates in aligning research and validation with faith-based perspectives and grassroots engagement. üìå Summary: ISU anchors ABMPD at the provincial academic level by providing research, validation, and training support. It ensures that the program is not only operationally sound but also academically credible and aligned with local development realities ‚Äî making it replicable, scalable, and evidence-based. ________________________________________ 6. Asian Institute of Management (AIM) ‚Äì National Academic & Policy Partner (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: AIM serves as ABMPD‚Äôs national-level academic and policy partner during the pre-implementation stage. Its role is to provide advanced research, leadership insights, and policy recommendations that frame ABMPD within broader national development priorities. AIM ensures that ABMPD‚Äôs pilot experiences are translated into strategic models and policy frameworks relevant at the national and international level. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Policy Research & Strategic Analysis o Produces national-level policy briefs and research outputs that situate ABMPD within governance, community development, and values formation discourse. o Synthesizes lessons from the Isabela pilot and positions them as scalable models for replication in other provinces. o Bridges the gap between grassroots implementation (via KCI and ISU) and policy-level adoption (via DILG, DepEd, and national partners). ‚Ä¢ Leadership & Management Frameworks o Provides technical support on leadership, management systems, and governance structures relevant to ABMPD Holding. o Advises on organizational frameworks for sustainability, including risk management, accountability, and scaling strategies. o Helps frame ABMPD‚Äôs ‚Äútheory of change‚Äù into a replicable governance model. ‚Ä¢ Capacity Development & Executive Education o Mobilizes AIM faculty and experts to contribute to leadership training for LGU leaders, VFAs, and ABMPD implementors. o Assists ABMPD Holding in refining executive training modules for high-level governance and management. o Prepares ABMPD leaders for engagement with CSR partners, policy institutions, and international donors. ‚Ä¢ Knowledge Dissemination & Thought Leadership o Publishes and presents ABMPD-related research in academic, policy, and development forums at the national and international level. o Elevates ABMPD as a thought leadership initiative in values-based governance and citizen empowerment. o Acts as a convener for policy dialogues, academic conferences, and roundtables linking ABMPD to wider development networks. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With ABMPD Holding: Signs MOA as the national academic and policy partner, providing intellectual legitimacy and policy frameworks. o With ISU: Serves as the national complement to ISU‚Äôs provincial research, synthesizing and scaling findings. o With The 700 Club Asia: Works jointly on regional media advocacy, public policy awareness, and governance innovations. o With NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance: Partners on integrating faith-based validation and moral governance principles into policy research and advocacy. o With Government Partners (DepEd, DILG): Provides independent validation and policy alignment support. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, AIM ensures that ABMPD is not only a localized initiative but also a nationally recognized, academically grounded, and policy-relevant model. It translates grassroots pilot results into frameworks and recommendations that can influence governance, CSR partnerships, and long-term national adoption, while complementing ISU‚Äôs provincial-level research and validation role. ________________________________________ 7. The 700 Club Asia ‚Äì Regional Media & Advocacy Partner (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: In the pre-implementation stage, The 700 Club Asia ensures that ABMPD is not only locally grounded but also regionally visible through powerful storytelling, documentation, and advocacy. It leverages its established media platforms to disseminate ABMPD‚Äôs vision, pilot results, and success stories across the Philippines and to Asian audiences, positioning ABMPD as both a national reform model and a regional inspiration for values-driven development. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Documentation & Storytelling o Produces high-quality video features, testimonies, and reports on ABMPD‚Äôs implementation and results. o Translates grassroots experiences into compelling narratives for both local and regional audiences. ‚Ä¢ Media Dissemination o Broadcasts ABMPD stories nationwide and to the Asian region through TV, satellite, online platforms, and social media. o Provides visibility to ABMPD initiatives in the wider Christian and faith-based community. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Exposure & Networking o Uses its established links with CBN Asia and partner ministries to connect ABMPD with regional Christian audiences and networks. o Facilitates recognition of ABMPD as a pioneering provincial-to-national-to-regional initiative. ‚Ä¢ Regional Advocacy o Promotes ABMPD in its broadcasts, conferences, and online channels as a model of community-centered, values-driven reform. o Serves as a voice in advocating moral recovery and community transformation to wider Asian audiences. ‚Ä¢ Complementary Role with Research Partners o While ISU and AIM focus on academic research and national frameworks, The 700 Club Asia amplifies these outputs into accessible and inspirational media forms for broader reach. o Strengthens ABMPD‚Äôs legitimacy and influence by bridging scholarly work with public and faith-based awareness. Strategic Partnership Role: ‚Ä¢ With ABMPD Holding: Acts as a regional media and advocacy partner, ensuring ABMPD gains visibility and credibility in the broader Asian context. ‚Ä¢ With KCI: Provides international exposure by disseminating pilot results and grassroots innovations through regional and global Christian media channels. ‚Ä¢ With Research Partners (ISU, AIM): Complements their technical and academic research with wide-reaching media dissemination and advocacy. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, The 700 Club Asia plays the role of Regional Media & Advocacy Partner, ensuring ABMPD‚Äôs vision and results are powerfully documented, widely disseminated, and regionally visible. It transforms ABMPD‚Äôs grassroots and research outputs into compelling narratives, giving the initiative both national credibility and regional inspiration. ________________________________________ 8. Far East Broadcasting Company (FEBC) ‚Äì Regional Radio & Faith-Based Media Partner (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: FEBC serves as ABMPD‚Äôs regional faith-based radio and media partner, extending its reach across Asia through its extensive broadcasting network. With decades of experience in gospel-centered programming, community engagement, and values advocacy, FEBC strengthens ABMPD‚Äôs presence by providing a trusted platform for awareness, moral recovery, and faith-driven development at both the national and Asian regional levels. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Faith-Based Media Outreach o Broadcasts ABMPD values, testimonies, and moral recovery content through radio, online, and partner media channels. o Provides consistent Asian-level exposure for ABMPD‚Äôs advocacy. ‚Ä¢ Community Engagement & Awareness o Promotes ABMPD initiatives across faith-based communities in Asia. o Uses its grassroots listener base to encourage volunteerism, values formation, and civic engagement. ‚Ä¢ Documentation & Story Amplification o Features ABMPD pilot results, volunteer stories, and community transformation in its radio and digital programs. o Ensures ABMPD‚Äôs narratives reach audiences not easily accessed by TV or academic channels. ‚Ä¢ Regional Networking & Partnerships o Leverages its faith-based broadcasting alliances across Asia to introduce ABMPD as a model for community transformation. o Helps position ABMPD within broader Christian mission and development discourses. Strategic Partnership Role: ‚Ä¢ With ABMPD Holding: Acts as a faith-based radio and advocacy partner at the regional level, giving ABMPD a platform across Asia. ‚Ä¢ With KCI: Provides exposure to grassroots pilot work by featuring testimonies and reports in its broadcasts. ‚Ä¢ With The 700 Club Asia: Complements TV and digital advocacy with radio-based and regional community broadcasting. ‚Ä¢ With Research Partners (ISU, AIM): Helps translate academic findings into accessible content for the public. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, FEBC amplifies ABMPD‚Äôs reach by serving as its Regional Radio & Faith-Based Media Partner. It ensures that ABMPD‚Äôs values-driven vision is not only documented and studied but also heard, embraced, and lived out by communities across the Philippines and Asia.________________________________________ 9. Unified Faith-Based Council (NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance) ‚Äì Moral Governance & Faith Integration Partner (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: The NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance functions as the unified moral governance and faith-based validation partner of ABMPD. By bringing together the country‚Äôs two largest Protestant and Evangelical networks, the council provides spiritual legitimacy, values-driven guidance, and faith-based mobilization capacity for the program. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Moral & Faith-Based Validation o Reviews ABMPD‚Äôs framework and modules to ensure consistency with Christian moral governance, ethics, and values-formation principles. o Serves as an independent validator that ABMPD upholds moral and faith-aligned standards in its rollout. ‚Ä¢ Faith-Based Mobilization & Support o Encourages local denominations, congregations, and grassroots faith groups to support barangay rollout and volunteer mobilization. o Serves as the early moral backbone for sustaining volunteer formation and civic engagement. ‚Ä¢ National Legitimacy & Endorsement o Provides national faith-based legitimacy to ABMPD by endorsing it as a program aligned with moral recovery and community transformation. o Uses its stature as a unified council to encourage cooperation among churches, FBOs, and local faith leaders. ‚Ä¢ Research & Knowledge Linkage o Partners with ISU, AIM, and CCCI to contribute faith-based perspectives in research, monitoring, and evaluation. o Ensures ABMPD‚Äôs knowledge products and research outputs integrate moral governance and spiritual renewal. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Faith-Based Advocacy o Represents ABMPD in interfaith dialogues, ecumenical councils, and national-level moral recovery platforms. o Advocates for integrating values-based development approaches into national discourse on governance and civic life. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With ABMPD Holding: Signs MOA as moral governance partner, providing spiritual legitimacy and national-level faith-based support. o With KCI: Supports local mobilization by encouraging denominational churches and congregations to host activities, endorse volunteers, and reinforce grassroots rollout. o With Research Partners (ISU, AIM, The 700 Club Asia): Adds moral and theological validation to academic, policy, and media-integrated research outputs. o With DepEd & DILG: Strengthens alignment of values-based and moral recovery components with governance and education systems. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, the Unified Faith-Based Council (NCCP‚ÄìPCEC Alliance) anchors ABMPD in moral governance, providing legitimacy, grassroots mobilization, and theological validation. It ensures that ABMPD is not just a governance or education program, but also a faith-rooted movement for holistic community transformation. ________________________________________ 10. Local Government Units ‚Äì Municipal/City (5 Municipalities + 1 City) ‚Äì Political & Operational Anchor (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: The Municipal and City LGUs serve as the primary political and operational anchors of ABMPD during the Pre-Implementation Stage. They provide official entry points for the program, ensure local ownership, and mobilize resources to support barangay-level rollout. Their MOAs with KCI represent the first formal commitments to integrate ABMPD into local governance and development systems. Functions: ‚Ä¢ MOA & Policy Commitment o Enter into MOAs with KCI as the lead implementor, representing formal municipal/city-level commitment to ABMPD. o Issue resolutions, ordinances, or executive directives endorsing and supporting the program‚Äôs rollout. ‚Ä¢ Resource Provision & Logistical Support o Provide venues, logistics, and manpower resources to support training sessions, VFA formation, and barangay-level engagement. o Allocate municipal/city-level resources (budget, staff time, facilities) to strengthen implementation. ‚Ä¢ Operational Coordination with Barangays o Ensure alignment between municipal/city and barangay-level participation. o Designate municipal focal persons to coordinate directly with KCI and barangay captains. ‚Ä¢ Community Mobilization o Engage schools, civic groups, faith-based organizations (FBOs), and local interested volunteers under municipal/city jurisdiction to participate in ABMPD activities. o Encourage barangay councils to actively support volunteer formation and values training. ‚Ä¢ Monitoring & Local Oversight o Oversee barangay-level rollout progress, ensuring alignment with municipal/city development plans. o Provide initial reports to KCI and ABMPD Holding regarding local progress, challenges, and support needs. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With ABMPD Holding: Serves as the political partner ensuring local ownership and policy alignment at the municipal/city level. o With KCI: Direct MOA partner and operational collaborator for rollout, resource-sharing, and barangay coordination. o With DILG: Acts as the implementing unit under DILG oversight and national policy endorsement. o With Barangays: Provides oversight and coordination to ensure grassroots rollout is aligned with municipal/city commitments. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, the 5 pilot municipalities and 1 city act as ABMPD‚Äôs formal entry points. They provide political legitimacy, resource support, and operational coordination to ensure barangay-level rollout is feasible, participatory, and locally owned. Their MOAs with KCI anchor ABMPD within the governance structures of local government. ________________________________________ 10. Local Government Units ‚Äì Barangay (Pilot Barangays) ‚Äì Grassroots Governance & Community Mobilization Partner (Pre-Implementation Stage) Core Role: Barangay LGUs act as the grassroots governance and community mobilization partners of ABMPD. They provide direct access to households, volunteers, and community organizations, ensuring that ABMPD is embedded at the ground level. Their role is critical in mobilizing residents, endorsing VFAs, and sustaining program activities at the barangay scale. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Local Policy Endorsement & Entry Point o Pass barangay resolutions endorsing ABMPD and committing support for community-based rollout. o Provide barangay halls, facilities, and staff as official venues and support systems for training and activities. ‚Ä¢ Community Mobilization o Mobilize local faith-based organizations (FBOs), civic groups, and interested volunteers to participate in ABMPD activities. o Endorse candidates for Barangay Volunteer Formation Associations (BVFAs) and encourage youth, women, and sectoral groups to join. ‚Ä¢ Volunteer Engagement & Support o Coordinate with KCI for the recruitment, training, and monitoring of local volunteers. o Provide incentives and recognition (certificates, barangay-level acknowledgement) to sustain volunteer motivation. ‚Ä¢ Resource & Logistical Support o Allocate small-scale resources such as chairs, venues, utilities, and manpower to facilitate ABMPD training and activities. o Assign barangay staff or councilors as point persons for coordination with KCI and municipal focal persons. ‚Ä¢ Local Monitoring & Reporting o Track attendance, participation, and immediate outcomes at the barangay level. o Submit reports to the Municipal LGU and KCI for integration into the larger rollout monitoring system. ‚Ä¢ Strategic Partnership Role o With Municipal/City LGUs: Coordinates and reports upward, ensuring grassroots implementation reflects municipal commitments and policy direction. o With KCI: Provides the ground-level venue, community base, and volunteers for actual ABMPD pilot activities. o With ABMPD Holding/DILG: Serves as the frontliner for policy adoption and grassroots-level legitimacy. üìå Summary: In the pre-implementation stage, Barangay LGUs are the hands-on governance partners that open access to communities, mobilize FBOs and volunteers, and sustain grassroots participation. They ensure ABMPD is not only institutionally endorsed but also locally embraced and practiced by the people. ________________________________________ II. ABMPD Ecosystem (Operational Stage) ________________________________________ 0. KDMC Holding Company (Parent Moral Governance Holding Company) ‚Ä¢ Core Role: Strategic guardian, funding provider, and ultimate IP custodian. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Funding Authority Releases funds (capital + international partner funding) based on approved requests from ABMPD Holding. ‚Ä¢ IP Custodianship Holds all ABMPD intellectual property (modules, curricula, branding, digital platforms, logos, uniforms). ‚Ä¢ Strategic Governance Defines the overarching vision, policies, and governance principles of the ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Compliance & Sustainability Ensures long-term institutional sustainability and compliance with SEC, BIR, COA, and international standards. ‚Ä¢ Oversight Role Retains strategic veto power if ecosystem actions deviate from ABMPD‚Äôs vision, ethics, or sustainability. ________________________________________ 1. ABMPD Holding Company (Sub-Holding) Core Role: Strategic guardian, funding provider, and ultimate IP custodian of the entire moral governance ecosystem. KDMC Holding serves as the parent moral governance entity that anchors, certifies, and sustains all subsidiary transformation systems ‚Äî including the ABMPD Moral Recovery Program (MRP). It ensures that all ecosystem holdings, foundations, and institutes remain aligned with the principles of regenerative morality, ethical leadership, and values-driven governance. ________________________________________ Functions: 1. Strategic Governance ‚Ä¢ Defines the overarching vision, moral standards, and governance principles of the entire KDMC Ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Ensures that all subsidiaries (ABMPD Holding, Foundation, RME, and allied institutes) operate within one unified moral governance framework. ‚Ä¢ Provides policy direction and approves institutional charters, ensuring long-term alignment with the KDMC theory of moral transformation. 2. Funding Authority ‚Ä¢ Serves as the primary source of seed capital and the official channel for international funding, CSR grants, and moral investment flows. ‚Ä¢ Releases funds to ABMPD Holding and its subsidiaries based on approved work plans and validated budget requests. ‚Ä¢ Oversees resource mobilization, endowment management, and impact investment partnerships to sustain the ecosystem‚Äôs long-term operations. 3. Intellectual Property (IP) Custodianship ‚Ä¢ Holds and safeguards all ABMPD and KDMC ecosystem intellectual properties ‚Äî including modules, curricula, branding systems, digital platforms, logos, and uniforms. ‚Ä¢ Issues formal licenses and usage agreements to subsidiaries (e.g., ABMPD Holding, KCI, RME) to ensure consistent, values-aligned application of intellectual assets. ‚Ä¢ Prevents unauthorized use or alteration of proprietary content, preserving the integrity and authenticity of all ecosystem programs. 4. Accreditation and Training Oversight ‚Ä¢ Operates the KDMC Training Institute, the official moral governance and leadership formation arm of the ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Accredits and certifies trainers, program directors, and institutional partners implementing moral recovery programs. ‚Ä¢ Ensures that all training and education modules across subsidiaries meet KDMC‚Äôs standards of moral governance and regenerative development. 5. Compliance and Sustainability ‚Ä¢ Ensures long-term institutional sustainability and regulatory compliance with SEC, BIR, COA, and relevant international standards. ‚Ä¢ Oversees ethical, financial, and environmental accountability across all programs and subsidiaries. ‚Ä¢ Implements corporate governance policies that reinforce transparency, accountability, and moral stewardship. 6. Oversight and Strategic Veto Power ‚Ä¢ Retains strategic veto authority in cases where ecosystem actions or program directions deviate from KDMC‚Äôs moral vision, ethical foundations, or sustainability principles. ‚Ä¢ Functions as the final moral and governance arbiter for disputes or misalignments within the ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Ensures that the moral integrity and original mission of ABMPD and all KDMC-linked programs remain intact across generations. 7. Global Advocacy and Partnership Development ‚Ä¢ Leads international moral governance advocacy, summits, and diaspora linkages under the KDMC global framework. ‚Ä¢ Serves as the Philippine moral governance representative in global networks, think tanks, and interfaith coalitions. ‚Ä¢ Promotes the ABMPD model as a Filipino-born contribution to global moral transformation and regenerative leadership. ________________________________________ üìå Summary: KDMC Holding stands as the moral, financial, and intellectual backbone of the ABMPD Ecosystem. It safeguards the movement‚Äôs integrity through unified governance, resource stewardship, and IP protection, ensuring that all subsidiaries ‚Äî present and future ‚Äî remain faithful to the moral vision of Puso at Dang√°l (Heart and Honor) while scaling toward national and global transformation. ________________________________________ 2. ABMPD Foundation (Fund Custodian & Development Arm) ‚Ä¢ Core Role: Primary fund custodian and development arm of ABMPD, serving as the official conduit for donor, government, and CSR funding, with direct disbursement to program implementation at the ground level. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Receives and manages institutional funds from international agencies (e.g., World Bank, ADB), LGUs, NGAs, NGOs, and CSR partners. o Ensures disbursement of allocations to municipal and barangay levels in alignment with program needs. o Strengthens credibility and partnership with civic, faith-based, and international organizations by operating as a non-profit entity. o Oversees fund mobilization to guarantee sustainability and trustworthiness of the ABMPD ecosystem. ________________________________________ 3. Subsidiaries of the Holding Company ________________________________________ A. Core Management Subsidiary ‚Ä¢ Role: Central consolidation and management arm that validates and organizes all subsidiary and ecosystem requests. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Consolidation of Requests Collects, screens, and validates all proposals, operational needs, and funding requests from subsidiaries and program implementors. ‚Ä¢ Request Endorsement Forwards consolidated and validated requests to ABMPD Holding for review and approval. ‚Ä¢ Operational Coordination Ensures alignment of day-to-day subsidiary activities with ABMPD Holding directives. ‚Ä¢ Performance Monitoring Gathers reports from subsidiaries, evaluates progress, and prepares integrated performance dashboards for ABMPD Holding. ‚Ä¢ Execution Support Provides administrative and technical support to subsidiaries, helping them comply with Holding Company standards. ‚Ä¢ Bridge Role Serves as the key link between subsidiaries (service providers) and ABMPD Holding (program owner & regulator). ________________________________________ B. Finance & Compliance Subsidiary Role: Centralized finance manager and audit authority of the ABMPD ecosystem, ensuring transparency, accountability, and compliance across all subsidiaries, partners, and program operations. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Fund Management Handles all financial inflows from KDMC Holding, LGUs, NGAs, CSR partners, NGOs, and international donors. ‚Ä¢ Disbursement Oversight Manages the release of allocations to municipal and barangay levels, as well as program implementors and partners, based on approved requests from ABMPD Holding. ‚Ä¢ Financial Auditing Conducts audits of all subsidiaries, VFAs, PGOs, and program partners engaged in ABMPD operations, consolidating reports for ecosystem-wide accountability. ‚Ä¢ Compliance Assurance Ensures strict adherence to COA rules, SEC and BIR requirements, international donor regulations, and KDMC Holding‚Äôs financial governance standards. ‚Ä¢ Financial Dashboard Operations Operates the ABMPD Financial Dashboard to provide real-time monitoring of fund flows, disbursement tracking, and audit transparency. ‚Ä¢ Reporting & Accountability Prepares consolidated financial reports for submission to ABMPD Holding and KDMC Holding, serving as the backbone of ecosystem-wide financial integrity. ________________________________________ C. Human Resource & Staffing Subsidiary ‚Ä¢ Role: Manpower recruitment, training, and deployment. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Recruits facilitators, trainers, and municipal/cluster coordinators. o Administers honorariums, stipen ds, and volunteer support allowances. o Provides training and accreditation for BVFA/MVFA leaders. o Works closely with KCI on standards and capacity-building. ________________________________________ D. Software & Systems Development Subsidiary ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ Role: Manages the digital backbone of ABMPD ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Develops and maintains the ABMPD Dashboard (monitoring volunteer hours, household engagement, compliance, financial reporting). o Builds mobile apps and platforms for BVFA/MVFA coordinators, student volunteers, and municipal offices. o Ensures data security, analytics, and system scalability. o Integrates reporting systems for LGUs, NGAs, donors, and international partners. o Provides digital ID/attendance tracking for households and volunteers. ________________________________________ . ________________________________________ üîπ ABMPD Digital Publishing and Donation Platform, Inc. (Subsidiary of ABMPD Holdings) Function: The ABMPD Digital Publishing and Donation Platform, Inc. serves as the official digital infrastructure of ABMPD Holdings dedicated to online publishing, book sales, and donation-based distribution programs. It functions as a secure and integrated platform designed to support authors, readers, resellers, publishing partners, and donor institutions under the ABMPD ecosystem. This subsidiary manages the creation, editing, publication, and distribution of both digital and printed educational materials aligned with the moral, civic, and spiritual formation objectives of ABMPD. It provides the following key services and functions: 1. eBook Publishing and Author Support ‚Äì Offers a digital platform for authors to publish, sell, and distribute books online while maintaining quality standards through partner publishing institutions. 2. Sales and Reseller Management System ‚Äì Provides a structured marketplace for online book sales, with built-in user authentication, commission tracking, reseller incentives, and analytics dashboards for authors and resellers. 3. Donation and Grant Distribution System ‚Äì Enables donors, NGOs, and church partners to sponsor book copies (digital or printed) for distribution to beneficiaries. The system ensures transparency through automated fund-splitting, impact tracking, and testimonial reporting. 4. Publishing Partner Coordination ‚Äì Integrates publishing services such as editing, proofreading, cover design, layout formatting, and ISBN registration within the digital workflow, ensuring that all books meet ABMPD‚Äôs content and ethical standards before release. 5. Transparency and Analytics Hub ‚Äì Monitors all book sales and donation transactions with detailed impact analytics, reading progress tracking, and beneficiary testimonies viewable through authorized dashboards. 6. Technology for Moral Recovery Advocacy ‚Äì Acts as a strategic tool for ABMPD‚Äôs moral recovery and education initiatives by bridging content creators, institutions, and communities through accessible and impactful digital materials. Governance Alignment: The ABMPD Digital Publishing and Donation Platform, Inc. operates under the governance, fiscal policies, and ethical standards of ABMPD Holdings, Inc. It works in close coordination with Kingdom Chronicle, Inc., the BVFA Foundation, and other ABMPD subsidiaries to ensure that all digital publications and donation campaigns contribute directly to the mission of nationwide moral renewal, knowledge empowerment, and values transformation. ________________________________________ E. Proposal & Feasibility Subsidiary ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ Role: Research and development arm for project design, feasibility studies, and budgeting frameworks. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Prepares feasibility studies for new projects and scaling initiatives. o Drafts program and project proposals for LGU funding, CSR grants, NGA partnerships, and international donors. o Develops costing models (per participant, per barangay, per cycle) aligned with ABMPD standards. o Consolidates multi-year budgeting needs for sustainability planning. o Works closely with Finance & Compliance to ensure proposals match donor compliance requirements. o Acts as innovation hub for program adaptation, new modules, and livelihood integration proposals. ________________________________________ F. Training & Capacity-Building Subsidiary ‚Ä¢ Role: Standardizes and delivers all training modules across barangay, municipal, and national levels. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Develops training curriculum for BVFA, MVFA, student volunteers, and community leaders. o Certifies trainers and facilitators in coordination with KCI and DepEd/CHED/TESDA. o Manages continuous professional development of coordinators and staff. o Produces manuals, toolkits, and e-learning materials. ________________________________________ G. Research, Monitoring & Evaluation (RME) Subsidiary ‚Ä¢ Role: Evidence-based monitoring and impact assessment. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Designs and maintains the M&E framework for all tiers of ABMPD. o Conducts household surveys, barangay impact studies, and municipal-wide assessments. o Validates program outcomes (values formation, volunteerism impact, household participation). o Publishes annual reports for LGUs, NGAs, and donors.
