Works with academe and international partners on best-practice sharing. ________________________________________ H. ABMPD Institutions Integrity Office (AIIO) The ABMPD Institutions Integrity Office (AIIO) serves as the moral and ethical compliance arm of the ABMPD ecosystem. It ensures that every program, report, and partnership upholds the principles of truth, transparency, and moral accountability that define ABMPD‚Äôs governance model. The AIIO operates directly under ABMPD Holding, maintaining operational independence while coordinating with the RME Office, KDMC Holding, and ABMPD Academy to ensure all institutional actions align with the national moral governance standards. Core Functions: Integrity Verification: Conducts moral and institutional audits across ABMPD subsidiaries and implementing partners. Ethical Oversight: Monitors adherence to moral governance principles and data ethics standards. Compliance Certification: Issues integrity validation reports that confirm institutional conformity with ABMPD moral protocols. Advisory Support: Provides guidance to partner institutions on moral governance conduct, data ethics, and internal accountability mechanisms. Through the AIIO, ABMPD institutionalizes the principle that governance integrity is both moral and measurable ‚Äî ensuring that every data point and decision reflects the conscience-driven spirit of national renewal. ________________________________________ I. Legal & Governance Subsidiary ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ Role: Provides legal foundation, governance structures, and compliance support for VFAs and ecosystem entities. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Assists BVFA/MVFA in SEC, CDA, and DOLE registration and securing permits/licenses. o Drafts and standardizes Constitution & By-Laws, Memoranda of Agreement (MOAs), and incorporation documents. o Provides legal advisory services on national laws, LGU ordinances, and donor compliance. o Ensures intellectual property (IP) protection and brand identity of ABMPD. Supports governance training for BVFA/MVFA officers to strengthen institutional accountability.________________________________________ J. Infrastructure & Facilities Development Subsidiary ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ Role: Manages physical infrastructure needs of the ABMPD program. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Oversees construction/renovation of community centers, training hubs, and multipurpose halls. o Secures permits and ensures compliance with DPWH, LGU, and safety standards. o Coordinates with LGUs for venue improvement and maintenance. o Sources funding from CSR partners and government infrastructure programs. Ensures facilities are family- and community-friendly (inclusive spaces).________________________________________ K. Security & Safety Services Subsidiary ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ Role: Safeguards ABMPD personnel, participants, assets, and events across all program tiers. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Establishes an in-house security agency accredited by PNP-SOSIA and DOLE. o Deploys trained security personnel for barangay and municipal rollout events, training camps, and community activities. o Provides security escort for logistics movements (materials, financial disbursements, and supply deliveries). o Ensures safety protocols during mass gatherings, recognition ceremonies, and high-profile donor/LGU engagements. o Develops risk management and emergency response systems in coordination with LGUs, MDRRMO, and barangay tanods. o Implements a code of discipline and accountability for security personnel aligned with ABMPD values. ________________________________________ L. International Relations & Donor Engagement Subsidiary ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ Role: Builds, manages, and sustains international partnerships and funding pipelines. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Secures partnerships with UN agencies, bilateral donors (USAID, JICA), and INGOs. o Drafts and negotiates donor agreements, ensuring compliance with global standards. o Facilitates exchange programs, exposure trips, and knowledge-sharing across countries. o Consolidates reporting for international partners with Finance & RME Subsidiaries. o Ensures ABMPD visibility in global volunteerism and community development platforms. ________________________________________ M. Communications & Media Subsidiary ‚Ä¢ Role: Branding, advocacy, and public awareness arm of ABMPD. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Manages ABMPD‚Äôs official brand identity, uniforms, banners, and IEC materials. o Runs awareness campaigns in coordination with LGUs, NGAs, CSOs, and FBOs. o Maintains social media, community radio, and newsletter updates. Handles documentation (photos, reports, videos) for donor compliance and recognition events.________________________________________ N. Operations & Logistics Subsidiary ‚Ä¢ Role: Procurement, supply chain, and logistical coordination. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Standardizes and distributes household volunteer kits, teaching materials, and community supplies. o Manages logistics for camps, feeding programs, tree planting, and community activities. o Ensures barangay and municipal activities are well-supported with materials and transport. ________________________________________ O. Livelihood & Enterprise Development Subsidiary (for later scaling) ‚Ä¢ Role: Transition households and volunteers into sustainable livelihood and cooperative-based enterprises. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Designs family-based livelihood projects linked to Tier 3‚Äì4. o Manages partnerships with TESDA, DOLE, DTI, and cooperatives. o Provides seed capital, mentoring, and market access for family enterprises. Ensures long-term sustainability of ABMPD participants.________________________________________ P. Unified Services & Cooperative Subsidiary ‚Ä¢ Role: Service integration and cooperative mobilization. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Works with local cooperatives to ensure sustainability of activities. o Provides shared services (printing, IT systems, transportation, event management). o Offers livelihood-linked support to families and youth in the program ecosystem. ________________________________________ Q. Resource Mobilization & Sustainability Subsidiary ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ Role: Diversifies and sustains funding and in-kind resources for ABMPD operations. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Designs fundraising strategies (membership schemes, donor clubs, cooperative profit-sharing). o Mobilizes in-kind donations (food packs, school supplies, tools). o Develops sustainability models beyond grants‚Äîcooperatives, microenterprises, social enterprises. o Partners with private sector for resource-sharing (transport, manpower, IT). o Works closely with Livelihood & Enterprise Development Subsidiary for scaling. ________________________________________ R. Health & Social Services Subsidiary ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ Role: Provides health, nutrition, and psychosocial support services integrated into ABMPD programs. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Coordinates with DOH, DSWD, and LGU health offices for medical missions, feeding programs, and mental health support. o Develops health modules for families, solo parents, and elderly participants. o Mobilizes volunteer health workers and partner FBO/CSO health advocates. o Monitors health-related indicators (nutrition, maternal care, elderly wellness). o Ensures alignment with national health and social welfare programs. ________________________________________ S. Staffing Cooperative (Affiliate Manpower Partner) ‚ö†Ô∏è (Distinct: CDA-registered Cooperative, not SEC-registered Corporation) ‚Ä¢ Role: Provides flexible, community-based staffing support for non-regular personnel, directly serving grassroots implementation needs of ABMPD programs. ‚Ä¢ Functions: o Handles recruitment and deployment of volunteer facilitators (with honoraria), job-order trainers, and short-term project hires at barangay, municipal, and provincial levels. o Serves as the direct manpower interface with LGUs and barangay-level implementors. o Ensures staffing availability for rollout activities without long-term employment obligations. o Complements the Staffing & HR Subsidiary by focusing on non-regular, community-based personnel. o Operates under cooperative principles, but integrated into the ABMPD ecosystem as a special affiliate manpower partner. üìå Key Distinction: ‚Ä¢ Subsidiary (SEC-registered): Regular employees, corporate/national/international scope. ‚Ä¢ Cooperative (CDA-registered): Non-regular staff, honoraria/JO, grassroots/community scope. ________________________________________ 4. Program Implementors / Partner Entities 1. Kingdom Chronicles, Inc. (KCI) ‚Äì Kabalikat sa Kinabukasan Initiative Role: Lead Program Implementor and overall ABMPD oversight; primary liaison with LGUs. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Signs MOAs and coordinates directly with LGUs for barangay and municipal rollout. ‚Ä¢ Provides overall program leadership across all tiers of ABMPD. ‚Ä¢ Ensures ABMPD standards, ethics, and program integrity are maintained. ‚Ä¢ Coordinates with internal subsidiaries (HR, RME, Training, Finance) for aligned execution, monitoring, and reporting. 2. Unified Faith-Based Organizations (FBOs) Role: Accreditation, mobilization, and oversight of moral recovery and values formation programs. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Accredits FBOs participating in ABMPD and manages MOAs with them. ‚Ä¢ Leads and supervises all moral recovery and values formation activities. ‚Ä¢ Provides facilitators, mentors, and technical guidance for FBO-led sessions. ‚Ä¢ Monitors compliance with ABMPD standards, ethical practices, and reporting. 3. Unified Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) Role: Accreditation, mobilization, and oversight of community service initiatives. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Accredits CSOs participating in ABMPD and manages MOAs with them. ‚Ä¢ Leads and supervises all community service, civic engagement, and volunteerism activities. ‚Ä¢ Provides facilitators, mentors, and technical support for CSO-led projects. ‚Ä¢ Monitors compliance with ABMPD standards, reporting, and impact measurement. 4. Staffing Cooperatives Role: Volunteer management, recruitment, and deployment at barangay and municipal levels. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Recruits facilitators, trainers, and municipal/cluster coordinators. ‚Ä¢ Administers honorariums, stipends, and volunteer support allowances. ‚Ä¢ Provides training and accreditation for BVFA/MVFA leaders in collaboration with KCI. ‚Ä¢ Supports mobilization of volunteers for household, youth, and community programs. ________________________________________ 5. Volunteer Formation Associations (VFAs) Category: Associations / Volunteer Governance Bodies 1. Barangay Values Formation Advocates (BVFA) o Role: Barangay-level volunteer association organizing households and implementing community service and values programs. o Functions: ÔÇß Coordinates household participation in volunteerism and community initiatives. ÔÇß Mentors families and youth in civic engagement and moral recovery programs. ÔÇß Implements activities aligned with barangay development priorities. ÔÇß Reports household participation, volunteer hours, and outcomes via the ABMPD Dashboard. o Composition: ÔÇß Formed by New Heroes and BVFA Officers. 2. Municipal Values Formation Advocates (MVFA) o Role: Municipal-level association coordinating and supervising BVFAs across the municipality. o Functions: ÔÇß Consolidates BVFA reports and ensures consistent program implementation. ÔÇß Provides mentorship and capacity-building for BVFA leaders. ÔÇß Coordinates municipal-level recognition, scaling, and partnership with LGUs and KCI. o Composition: ÔÇß Formed by MVFA Officers, which include all BVFA Officers, committee heads, and Level 3 KCI Leadership Track Heroes. 3. Provincial Values Formation Advocates (PVFA) o Role: Provincial-level association overseeing MVFAs and standardizing program delivery across municipalities. o Functions: ÔÇß Consolidates municipal reports and provides provincial guidance. ÔÇß Supports training, resource-sharing, and recognition events at the provincial level. ÔÇß Coordinates provincial strategic initiatives with KCI and partners. o Composition: ÔÇß Formed by MVFA Officers and Level 4 KCI Leadership Track Heroes. 4. Regional Values Formation Advocates (RVFA) o Role: Regional-level association ensuring consistency, quality, and monitoring of VFAs across provinces. o Functions: ÔÇß Monitors provincial outcomes and aligns programs with regional goals. ÔÇß Supports program adaptation, leadership mentoring, and capacity-building across the region. ÔÇß Coordinates with KCI, Unified FBOs, and Unified CSOs for regional initiatives. o Composition: ÔÇß Formed by PVFA Officers and Level 5 KCI Leadership Track Heroes. 5. National Values Formation Advocates (NVFA) o Role: National-level association for oversight, policy guidance, and strategic coordination of all VFAs. o Functions: ÔÇß Approves national standards, training curricula, and recognition systems. ÔÇß Consolidates nationwide reports for KCI, government, and donor compliance. ÔÇß Guides nationwide scaling strategies, advocacy, and partnership engagements. o Composition: ÔÇß Formed by all PVFA Officers nationwide. ________________________________________ ‚úÖ Progressive Formation Ladder: New Heroes & BVFA Officers ‚Üí BVFA ‚Üí MVFA Officers ‚Üí MVFA ‚Üí PVFA Officers ‚Üí PVFA ‚Üí RVFA ‚Üí NVFA This structure clearly shows how each higher-level VFA is formed from the officers and leaders of the preceding level, fully aligned with KCI leadership tracks. ________________________________________ 6. Program Governance Offices (PGOs) Category: Administrative / Governance Offices 1. Barangay Moral Recovery Facilitation & Program Office (BMRPFO) o Role: Barangay-level administrative office coordinating and supervising Tier 2 volunteerism and values programs. o Functions: ÔÇß Aligns all household volunteer activities with barangay development plans. ÔÇß Ensures integration of moral recovery, family engagement, and community service activities. ÔÇß Provides direct mentoring and oversight to BVFAs. ÔÇß Maintains barangay-level reporting on participation, volunteer hours, and impact metrics. ÔÇß Coordinates logistics and venue support with barangay officials. 2. Municipal Moral Recovery & Program Office (MMRPO) o Role: Municipal-level administrative office consolidating and supervising barangay-level activities. o Functions: ÔÇß Aggregates BVFA/BMRPFO reports for municipal monitoring. ÔÇß Identifies program gaps, emerging needs, and technical support requirements. ÔÇß Coordinates partnerships with NGAs, HEIs, CSOs, and FBOs for municipal-level initiatives. ÔÇß Ensures uniformity and compliance across all barangays in the municipality. ÔÇß Supports municipal recognition events, resource mobilization, and volunteer tracking. 3. Provincial Moral Recovery & Program Office (PMRPO) o Role: Provincial-level administrative office overseeing municipal programs and VFAs. o Functions: ÔÇß Consolidates municipal reports and provides provincial guidance for program standardization. ÔÇß Coordinates training, capacity-building, and resource-sharing across municipalities. ÔÇß Facilitates collaboration with provincial LGUs, provincial CSOs/FBO networks, and KCI. ÔÇß Supports provincial recognition, scaling initiatives, and donor reporting. ÔÇß Monitors outcomes for alignment with provincial development plans. 4. Regional Moral Recovery & Program Office (RMRPO) o Role: Regional-level administrative office supervising provincial VFAs and program delivery. o Functions: ÔÇß Monitors program progress and ensures consistency across provinces. ÔÇß Coordinates regional-level training, mentorship, and leadership development programs. ÔÇß Provides guidance on adaptation of modules and interventions for regional needs. ÔÇß Consolidates regional reports and liaises with KCI and international partners. ÔÇß Supports advocacy, recognition, and community engagement events at the regional level. 5. National Moral Recovery & Program Office (NMRPO) o Role: National-level administrative office providing oversight, policy guidance, and reporting across all tiers. o Functions: ÔÇß Approves standards, curricula, and nationwide program implementation plans. ÔÇß Aggregates reports from all regional offices and validates nationwide outcomes. ÔÇß Provides strategic guidance to KCI, NGAs, donors, and other partners. ÔÇß Coordinates national recognition events, advocacy campaigns, and inter-regional knowledge sharing. ÔÇß Ensures compliance with national laws, LGU ordinances, and donor standards. ________________________________________ ‚úÖ Progressive Governance Ladder: BMRPFO ‚Üí MMRPO ‚Üí PMRPO ‚Üí RMRPO ‚Üí NMRPO This setup mirrors the VFA hierarchy, ensuring nested oversight from barangay to national level, with clear reporting and program alignment responsibilities. ________________________________________ 7. Local ABMPD Management Team (LAMT) ‚Äì Local Moral Governance Unit Definition The Local ABMPD Management Team (LAMT) is the officially designated municipal/city-level moral governance unit responsible for ensuring that all ABMPD programs, data systems, institutional engagements, and volunteer operations within the locality adhere to ABMPD‚Äôs Moral Governance Architecture. LAMT functions as the local conscience-led authority, integrating institutional leadership from government, faith-based organizations, civil society, cooperatives, education, and youth. ________________________________________ Mandate and Governance Scope LAMT exercises governance authority across: ‚Ä¢ all barangays within the municipality/city; ‚Ä¢ all FBO, CSO, COOP, education, and youth institutions engaged in ABMPD; ‚Ä¢ municipal program governance offices (MMRPO, ISRPTFO, YSFO, etc.); ‚Ä¢ volunteer formations (MVFA, BVFA); ‚Ä¢ local dashboards, moral data pipelines, and recognition submissions. Its role ensures that transformation is governed with integrity, accountability, and community participation. ________________________________________ Core Functions 1. Moral Governance Oversight Ensures local implementation adheres to national moral governance standards. 2. Intersectoral Alignment Convenes LGU, FBOs, CSOs, cooperatives, academe, and youth for unified moral direction. 3. Covenant and Partnership Stewardship Monitors institutional compliance with MOAs, commitments, and moral obligations. 4. Oversight of Local Program Offices and Volunteers Provides governance direction to municipal and barangay program offices and volunteer formations. 5. Data Integrity and Recognition Validation Validates moral data, dashboard reports, and recognition submissions before national endorsement. 6. Public Moral Visibility Leads moral governance ceremonies, public accountability events, and community-level moral engagements. ________________________________________ Institutional Positioning LAMT is the governance bridge that links: ‚Ä¢ ABMPD Holding (National Moral Governance Authority) ‚Ä¢ KCI (National Implementor) ‚Ä¢ Municipal Program Governance Offices ‚Ä¢ Volunteer Formations (MVFA & BVFA) ‚Ä¢ Local Institutions This ensures a unified, morally anchored local transformation ecosystem. ________________________________________ Selection of LAMT Representatives: Ensuring Moral Governance Integrity To uphold the integrity, credibility, and non-political character of local moral governance, LAMT representatives are not chosen through appointment, seniority, or institutional influence, but through a data-driven moral vetting process anchored in ABMPD‚Äôs national standards. A. Institutional Sector Nomination Each sector (LGU, FBO, CSO/COOP, Education/Youth) nominates potential candidates who have demonstrated moral leadership and engagement within ABMPD initiatives. B. Moral Data Screening and Validation KCI conducts a technical moral data verification process using: ‚Ä¢ ABMPD Moral Scorecards; ‚Ä¢ baseline and historical moral performance data; ‚Ä¢ participation and engagement indicators; ‚Ä¢ institutional moral profiles; ‚Ä¢ integrity red flags (conflict of interest, misconduct, violations). Only nominees meeting minimum Moral Performance Thresholds qualify for further assessment. C. Competency Assessment (Annex G.6 ‚Äì Moral Governance Competency Framework) Qualified nominees undergo competency scoring covering: ‚Ä¢ ethical judgment and decision integrity; ‚Ä¢ community trustworthiness and influence; ‚Ä¢ transformational leadership capacity; ‚Ä¢ moral courage and impartiality; ‚Ä¢ ability to govern without sectoral bias. This ensures LAMT members possess the moral governance competencies, not just institutional position. D. National Validation and Confirmation ABMPD Holding reviews the moral score, competency results, and compliance reports to ensure: ‚Ä¢ alignment with national moral governance standards; ‚Ä¢ absence of partisan or political conflict; ‚Ä¢ demonstrated integrity and public trust. Only nominees who meet all criteria are approved. E. Official Commissioning and Registration Approved representatives are: ‚Ä¢ formally inducted into LAMT; ‚Ä¢ registered in the National ABMPD Dashboard as accredited local moral governance authorities; ‚Ä¢ issued a LAMT Commissioning Certificate. This multi-stage, data-driven selection system ensures that LAMT is composed only of morally qualified, ethically verified, and nationally approved leaders, maintaining the credibility and purity of local moral governance. ________________________________________ 1. LAMT Selection Diagram (Text-Based ‚Äì Ready for Agnes.ai or Flowchart Tool) Title: LAMT Moral Governance Selection Flow Institutional Nomination (LGU / FBO / CSO-COOP / Education-Youth) ‚îÇ ‚ñº ABMPD Moral Data Screening (KCI) - Moral Scorecards - Dashboard Moral Baselines - Integrity Indicators - Participation Metrics ‚îÇ ‚ñº Competency Assessment (Annex G.6) - Ethical Judgment - Communal Trustworthiness - Moral Courage - Transformational Leadership ‚îÇ ‚ñº National Validation (ABMPD Holding) - Conflicts of Interest Check - Standards Compliance Verification - Moral Governance Alignment ‚îÇ ‚ñº Official Commissioning - LAMT Charter Signing - National Dashboard Registration - Issuance of LAMT Commissioning Certificate ________________________________________ ‚úÖ ABMPD Local Governance Hierarchy (LAMT ‚Üí PGOs ‚Üí VFAs) Text-Based Visual Governance Chart ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ ABMPD Holding (National Moral Authority) ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îÇ ‚ñº ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ KCI (National Implementor) ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îÇ ‚ñº ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ LAMT ‚Äì Local ABMPD Management Team (Municipal/City) ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Moral Governance Oversight ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Covenant Stewardship ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Data Integrity & Recognition Validation ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Intersectoral Governance ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îÇ ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚ñº ‚ñº ‚ñº ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ MMRPO ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ISRPTFO ‚îÇ ‚îÇ YSFO ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Municipal ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Institutional ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Youth Sector ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Moral Reform ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Reform Program ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Facilitation ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚ñº ‚ñº ‚ñº ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ Municipal VFAs (MVFA) ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Barangay Program Offices ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Youth VFAs ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Municipal Facilitators ‚îÇ ‚îÇ (as applicable) ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Youth volunteers ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Sector implementors ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Barangay moral operations ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Peer facilitators ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îÇ ‚ñº ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ Barangay VFAs (BVFA) ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Household-level facilitators ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Grassroots data & engagement ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ________________________________________ ‚úÖ Meaning of the Chart 1. LAMT sits above all municipal governance structures LAMT = moral governance authority for all municipal and barangay ABMPD operations. 2. PGOs are the technical/administrative bodies ‚Ä¢ MMRPO = Municipal Moral Reform Program Office ‚Ä¢ ISRPTFO = Institutional and Sector Reform Program Technical Facilitation Office ‚Ä¢ YSFO = Youth Sector Facilitation Office They implement operations under the moral supervision of LAMT. 3. VFAs are the operational force ‚Ä¢ MVFA = Municipal Volunteers & Facilitators ‚Ä¢ BVFA = Barangay Volunteers & Facilitators ‚Ä¢ Youth VFAs = young facilitators & values formators VFAs are supervised by PGOs and morally governed by LAMT. ________________________________________ 8. Partners in ABMPD Ecosystem ________________________________________ 8.1 Technical & Policy Partners Primary Role: Provide technical guidance, standards, policy frameworks, and capacity-building support for household, barangay, and municipal volunteerism initiatives under ABMPD. ________________________________________ Roles & Functions by Implementation Level Barangay Level: ‚Ä¢ Provide technical manuals, training guides, orientation kits, and checklists to BVFAs for household and community-level activities. ‚Ä¢ Ensure volunteer programs comply with health, safety, environmental, education, and nutrition standards. ‚Ä¢ Conduct occasional on-site training, mentoring, or technical consultation for BVFA coordinators, volunteers, and households. ‚Ä¢ Assist in implementing values formation, civic engagement, and moral recovery initiatives with proper technical and ethical frameworks. ‚Ä¢ Support data collection and reporting for barangay-level monitoring. Municipal Level: ‚Ä¢ Consolidate barangay-level reports and validate outcomes through MMRPO. ‚Ä¢ Organize municipal-level training sessions, workshops, and skills camps for BVFA and MVFA leaders. ‚Ä¢ Provide technical resources, templates, and standardized operational procedures to ensure consistency across barangays. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate technical guidance on safety, health campaigns, environmental initiatives, and volunteer management. ‚Ä¢ Support municipal planning for scale-up of community service programs. Provincial / Regional / National Level (if applicable): ‚Ä¢ Provide policy guidance and ensure alignment of barangay and municipal activities with national standards. ‚Ä¢ Conduct regional training-of-trainers (TOT) and capacity-building sessions for MVFA, PVFA, and RVFA leaders. ‚Ä¢ Approve and standardize technical manuals, curricula, and operational frameworks for ABMPD programs across municipalities and provinces. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate inter-provincial coordination, knowledge-sharing, and multi-municipal project alignment. Financial & In-kind Support: ‚Ä¢ Provide project-specific grants, materials, or equipment such as health kits, feeding packs, seedlings, learning kits, PPE, and sports/volunteer tools. ‚Ä¢ Mobilize staff, experts, or volunteers to assist in on-site technical activities and program implementation. ‚Ä¢ Offer funding or in-kind support for municipal-level or provincial-level workshops, skills camps, and community service projects. ________________________________________ Entities Included ‚Ä¢ National Government Agencies (NGAs): DENR, DOH, DSWD, DepEd, CHED, DILG, BFP, PNP ‚Ä¢ Technical/Skills Agencies: TESDA, DTI, DOLE ________________________________________ 8.2 Community Engagement Partners Primary Role: Mobilize communities, facilitate volunteer networks, and enhance the reach and impact of ABMPD programs across households and barangays. ________________________________________ Roles & Functions by Implementation Level Barangay Level: ‚Ä¢ Mentor BVFA volunteers in planning and implementing household and community service programs. ‚Ä¢ Provide volunteer manpower, technical guidance, and supplemental materials for civic activities such as clean-ups, feeding programs, tree planting, and values-based projects. ‚Ä¢ Support BVFA in organizing household engagement, intergenerational activities, and youth participation. ‚Ä¢ Assist in monitoring and reporting household participation, volunteer hours, and community service outcomes. ‚Ä¢ Offer mentoring for skill acquisition and values formation at the household level. Municipal Level: ‚Ä¢ Coordinate multiple CSO networks across barangays to ensure program alignment and avoid duplication. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate municipal-wide service programs, youth camps, large-scale volunteer events, and recognition ceremonies. ‚Ä¢ Consolidate barangay-level data, feedback, and program reports for MMRPO oversight. ‚Ä¢ Provide technical support to MVFA and municipal coordinators for effective community mobilization. ‚Ä¢ Assist in scaling best practices across barangays and monitoring program quality. Provincial / Regional / National Level (if applicable): ‚Ä¢ Support inter-municipal and provincial volunteerism initiatives, ensuring regional coordination and knowledge-sharing. ‚Ä¢ Help standardize community engagement protocols, volunteer training, and program reporting frameworks. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate partnerships between local CSOs, national NGOs, and faith-based organizations for integrated service delivery. Financial & In-kind Support: ‚Ä¢ Fund small-scale community service programs or contribute in-kind resources, such as food packs, training manuals, tools, or volunteer kits. ‚Ä¢ Provide expertise in project design, implementation, and volunteer management. ‚Ä¢ Assist in mobilizing resources for municipal or regional volunteer events and recognition programs. ________________________________________ Entities Included ‚Ä¢ Civil Society Organizations (CSOs): World Vision, Save the Children, local NGOs ‚Ä¢ Unified CSOs: Accredited umbrella CSOs overseeing multiple community service programs ‚Ä¢ Local Cooperatives: Provide manpower, materials, and financial support for volunteerism and community-based initiatives ________________________________________ 8.3 Faith-based Organization (FBO) Partners Primary Role: Lead values formation, moral recovery, and volunteer ethics programs, ensuring households and communities internalize ABMPD core moral and civic principles. ________________________________________ Roles & Functions by Implementation Level Barangay Level: ‚Ä¢ Provide moral recovery sessions, spiritual guidance, and values formation programs tailored to households, youth, and elderly participants. ‚Ä¢ Mentor BVFA volunteers on intergenerational engagement, volunteer ethics, household leadership, and community stewardship. ‚Ä¢ Support and co-organize feeding programs, community prayer events, and civic activities with ethical and moral framing. ‚Ä¢ Offer counseling, spiritual mentorship, and life skills guidance to program participants. ‚Ä¢ Promote volunteerism as a values-driven practice among families and barangay residents. Municipal Level: ‚Ä¢ Accredits and supervises multiple FBOs across barangays to ensure program standards and alignment with ABMPD objectives. ‚Ä¢ Coordinate municipal-level faith-based volunteer programs, moral recovery initiatives, and large-scale civic events. ‚Ä¢ Consolidate barangay-level program outcomes, volunteer engagement data, and moral recovery impact reports for MMRPO oversight. ‚Ä¢ Provide technical guidance, resource sharing, and mentorship to BVFA and MVFA leaders on volunteer ethics and moral programs. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate municipal-level recognition events and award ceremonies for outstanding volunteers and households. Provincial / Regional / National Level (if applicable): ‚Ä¢ Standardize moral recovery curricula, training manuals, and ethical guidance protocols across municipalities and provinces. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate inter-municipal or provincial FBO networks for knowledge-sharing, volunteer coordination, and program scaling. ‚Ä¢ Support collaboration with international FBO networks to incorporate best practices and frameworks. Financial & In-kind Support: ‚Ä¢ Provide volunteer networks, training manuals, mentoring programs, and small program grants. ‚Ä¢ Mobilize facilities such as church halls, multipurpose centers, and retreat venues for ABMPD activities. ‚Ä¢ Contribute in-kind resources for moral recovery sessions, youth camps, and community engagement activities. ‚Ä¢ Offer spiritual and ethical advisory support for large-scale community projects and ABMPD events. ________________________________________ Entities Included ‚Ä¢ Unified FBOs: Umbrella organizations overseeing local faith-based volunteer programs. ‚Ä¢ Church-Based Organizations: Local parishes, diocesan programs, and denominational outreach groups. ‚Ä¢ Religious NGOs: Faith-driven organizations supporting community service, moral recovery, and intergenerational volunteerism. ________________________________________ 8.4 Private Sector & CSR Partners Primary Role: Provide funding, in-kind support, volunteer manpower, and public recognition programs to strengthen community engagement, household volunteerism, and program sustainability. ________________________________________ Roles & Functions by Implementation Level Barangay Level: ‚Ä¢ Supply volunteer manpower and technical support for household, youth, and community engagement initiatives. ‚Ä¢ Provide materials, tools, or equipment for local civic activities, feeding programs, environmental projects, and values formation events. ‚Ä¢ Support logistics for barangay-level volunteer initiatives, including transportation, storage, and distribution of materials. ‚Ä¢ Participate in mentoring households or youth volunteers through skill-based or business-related guidance. Municipal Level: ‚Ä¢ Sponsor municipal recognition programs for volunteers, BVFA/MVFA leaders, and outstanding households. ‚Ä¢ Fund or co-organize community events such as youth camps, livelihood workshops, or civic campaigns. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate public-private partnership initiatives to enhance program reach, sustainability, and impact. ‚Ä¢ Provide technical expertise or consultancy support for larger-scale community development projects. Provincial / Regional / National Level (if applicable): ‚Ä¢ Contribute to multi-municipal or provincial programs with funding, technical assistance, and volunteer deployment. ‚Ä¢ Support cross-municipality recognition ceremonies or award programs. ‚Ä¢ Engage in strategic partnerships for program scaling, livelihood initiatives, and social enterprise development linked to ABMPD outcomes. Financial & In-kind Support: ‚Ä¢ Provide grants, food packs, tools, equipment, and transportation support for ABMPD activities. ‚Ä¢ Offer in-kind services such as printing, event management, and logistics for community projects. ‚Ä¢ Fund livelihood and skill-building initiatives for families, youth, and volunteers within the ABMPD ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate public recognition and incentive programs to encourage sustained volunteerism. ________________________________________ Entities Included ‚Ä¢ Corporate Foundations / CSR Programs: San Miguel Foundation, Ayala Foundation, SM Foundation, Globe Telecom CSR programs. ‚Ä¢ Local Banks & Microfinance Institutions: Provide funding support, training, and community-based financial literacy programs. ‚Ä¢ Private Companies: Support large-scale volunteer mobilization, logistics, and in-kind contributions. ________________________________________ 8.5 International Partners / Donors Primary Role: Provide funding, technical frameworks, knowledge-sharing, capacity-building, global best practices, and partnership advocacy to strengthen ABMPD program implementation, sustainability, and scaling.________________________________________ Roles & Functions by Implementation Level Barangay Level: ‚Ä¢ Indirect support through provision of funded programs, training manuals, and technical guidance materials. ‚Ä¢ Deploy volunteer teams or technical experts for exposure visits, pilot programs, or specialized trainings. ‚Ä¢ Provide access to international methodologies for youth engagement, values formation, and community service programs. ‚Ä¢ Support household and youth monitoring frameworks through digital tools or reporting modules. Municipal Level: ‚Ä¢ Fund and facilitate large-scale initiatives such as multi-barangay youth camps, feeding programs, livelihood workshops, or environmental projects. ‚Ä¢ Enable partnerships between LGUs, CSOs, FBOs, and other local stakeholders to maximize program reach. ‚Ä¢ Provide technical assistance for program management, volunteer mobilization, and capacity-building of municipal coordinators. ‚Ä¢ Support training-of-trainers initiatives to ensure alignment with international best practices. Provincial / Regional / National Level (if applicable): ‚Ä¢ Fund province- or region-wide program scaling, exposure trips, and cross-municipal learning events. ‚Ä¢ Offer technical frameworks, monitoring tools, and evaluation methodologies for multi-tiered program assessment. ‚Ä¢ Facilitate knowledge exchange between ABMPD leadership, government agencies, and international organizations. ‚Ä¢ Support partnership & advocacy to establish ABMPD in global volunteerism networks and international recognition platforms. Financial & In-kind Support: ‚Ä¢ Provide grants, project funding, equipment, learning modules, and technical materials. ‚Ä¢ Offer technical assistance for monitoring, reporting, program design, and evaluation. ‚Ä¢ Support development of standardized curricula, M&E dashboards, and program toolkits. ‚Ä¢ Enable multi-year funding and sustainability mechanisms aligned with donor compliance and international standards. ‚Ä¢ Support advocacy and visibility efforts to attract new donors, partners, and global collaborations. ________________________________________ Entities Included: ‚Ä¢ UN Agencies: UNICEF, UNDP, UNESCO ‚Ä¢ Bilateral/Multilateral Donors: JICA, World Bank, Asian Development Bank (ADB), USAID ‚Ä¢ International NGOs: Plan International, Oxfam, Habitat for Humanity, HelpAge International ‚Ä¢ Other Technical/Capacity-Building Partners: Organizations providing global best practice frameworks, evaluation support, knowledge exchange programs, and partnership advocacy channels (e.g., Peace Corps, EU Delegation, KOICA, GIZ) ________________________________________ ‚ÄÉ III. External Partners & Stakeholders (Participation in ABMPD Program) ________________________________________ 1. Technical & Policy Partners for ABMPD ________________________________________ 1. National Government Agencies (NGAs) ‚Ä¢ DILG (Department of the Interior and Local Government) o Policy alignment for barangay and municipal governance. o Provides circulars, monitoring tools, and compliance mechanisms. ‚Ä¢ DepEd (Department of Education) o Values formation integration in schools. o Technical support for youth training modules and teacher mobilization. ‚Ä¢ CHED (Commission on Higher Education) o Integration of ABMPD programs in tertiary institutions. o Accreditation and recognition of volunteerism initiatives. ‚Ä¢ TESDA (Technical Education and Skills Development Authority) o Skills training and certification of livelihood components. o Development of community-based training modules. ‚Ä¢ NYC (National Youth Commission) o Youth development frameworks and alignment with national youth agenda. o Mobilization of youth councils (SK and other bodies). ‚Ä¢ NEDA (National Economic and Development Authority) o Policy direction on socio-economic development programs. o Provides M&E frameworks for sustainable impact. ‚Ä¢ DOH (Department of Health) o Technical support for health-related programs (nutrition, sanitation, mental health). o Barangay health workers training alignment. ‚Ä¢ DSWD (Department of Social Welfare and Development) o Social protection, community-based interventions, and linkages to 4Ps households. o Training and technical guidance on case management. ‚Ä¢ DA (Department of Agriculture) o Policy support for food security, community gardens, and livelihood initiatives. ‚Ä¢ DENR (Department of Environment and Natural Resources) o Frameworks for environmental protection and climate change programs. ‚Ä¢ DOLE (Department of Labor and Employment) o Policies and technical standards for employment and livelihood pathways. ‚Ä¢ PDEA / PNP (Philippine National Police) o Technical guidance for peace and order components, anti-drug and anti-crime programs. ________________________________________ 2. Local Government Units (LGUs) ‚Ä¢ Provincial Government o Oversight, integration of ABMPD into provincial development plans. o Policy direction for resource allocation. ‚Ä¢ Municipal Governments o Implementation of municipal-level technical frameworks. o Capacity-building for barangay implementers. ‚Ä¢ Barangay Governments o Execution of localized policies and ordinances supporting ABMPD. o Monitoring and reporting mechanisms. ________________________________________ 3. Academic & Training Institutions ‚Ä¢ State Universities and Colleges (SUCs) o Research, policy studies, and technical validation. o Resource persons for training and monitoring. ‚Ä¢ Private Universities & Colleges o Volunteer mobilization and values formation programs. o Policy advocacy through academic research and extension programs. ‚Ä¢ TESDA Accredited Training Centers o Skills training aligned with ABMPD livelihood objectives. ________________________________________ 4. Policy & Knowledge Institutions ‚Ä¢ Philippine Institute for Development Studies (PIDS) o Policy research, impact assessment, and recommendations. ‚Ä¢ Development Academy of the Philippines (DAP) o Training of local leaders, governance tools, and public management frameworks. ‚Ä¢ Civil Service Commission (CSC) o Standards for volunteer service recognition. o Policy alignment for LGU personnel participation. ________________________________________ 5. Advocacy & Coordinating Bodies ‚Ä¢ Philippine National Volunteer Service Coordinating Agency (PNVSCA) o Policy on volunteerism. o Standards and guidelines for recognition of volunteers. ‚Ä¢ League of Municipalities of the Philippines (LMP) o Advocacy and policy-sharing across municipalities. ‚Ä¢ League of Barangays of the Philippines o Barangay-level policy support and coordination. ________________________________________ 2. Community Engagement Partners ________________________________________ 1. Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) & NGOs ‚Ä¢ World Vision Philippines ‚Äì Community development, child sponsorship, household engagement. ‚Ä¢ Save the Children Philippines ‚Äì Child protection, education, health, and emergency response. ‚Ä¢ Philippine Red Cross ‚Äì Disaster response, health programs, youth volunteer mobilization. ‚Ä¢ Plan International Philippines ‚Äì Youth empowerment, girls‚Äô rights, community programs. ‚Ä¢ Oxfam Philippines ‚Äì Poverty reduction, disaster resilience, and humanitarian work. ‚Ä¢ Habitat for Humanity ‚Äì Community housing, shelter repair, and barangay mobilization. ‚Ä¢ Local NGOs / People‚Äôs Organizations ‚Äì Direct barangay-level implementation, civic action. ________________________________________ 2. Local Cooperatives & Associations ‚Ä¢ Credit and Savings Cooperatives ‚Äì Livelihood support, household empowerment. ‚Ä¢ Farmers‚Äô Cooperatives / Irrigators‚Äô Associations ‚Äì Food security and barangay agriculture initiatives. ‚Ä¢ Transport Groups / TODA / Fisherfolk Associations ‚Äì Local engagement, support in mobility, logistics, and advocacy. ________________________________________ 3. Youth & Student Organizations ‚Ä¢ SK (Sangguniang Kabataan) ‚Äì Mobilize youth volunteers, lead barangay youth programs. ‚Ä¢ School Clubs & Supreme Student Governments (SSG) ‚Äì Civic and school-based ABMPD engagement. ‚Ä¢ Youth Federations & Peer Groups ‚Äì Camps, trainings, sports, and values-driven volunteerism. ________________________________________ 4. Women & Family Groups ‚Ä¢ Rural Improvement Clubs (RICs) ‚Äì Livelihood and family-focused programs. ‚Ä¢ Mothers‚Äô Clubs / Barangay Women‚Äôs Organizations ‚Äì Family-based values formation and child care support. ‚Ä¢ Parents-Teachers Associations (PTAs) ‚Äì Engagement in schools and community education. ________________________________________ 5. Sectoral & Vulnerable Groups ‚Ä¢ PWD Associations ‚Äì Inclusion of persons with disabilities in household and livelihood projects. ‚Ä¢ Senior Citizens‚Äô Associations ‚Äì Values mentoring, moral recovery, and household leadership. ‚Ä¢ 4Ps Beneficiaries Groups ‚Äì Active participation in barangay projects, moral recovery, and livelihood. ________________________________________ 6. Faith-based Community Groups (Grassroots) (different from formal FBO partners ‚Äì these are local-level faith engagement groups) ‚Ä¢ Barangay-based Prayer Groups ‚Äì Household moral recovery and support circles. ‚Ä¢ Youth Ministries ‚Äì Community service and moral development for youth. ‚Ä¢ Ecumenical & Interfaith Councils ‚Äì Promote unity across different faiths for ABMPD programs. ________________________________________ 7. Volunteer Networks & Civic Clubs ‚Ä¢ Rotary Clubs / Kiwanis / Lions Clubs ‚Äì Small-scale barangay projects, livelihood, feeding. ‚Ä¢ Junior Chamber International (JCI) ‚Äì Youth-led civic action, events, and community programs. ‚Ä¢ Local Volunteer Fire Brigades / Rescue Groups ‚Äì Safety, disaster response, and civic duty. ________________________________________ 3. Faith-Based Organization (FBO) Partners ________________________________________ 1. National & Ecumenical Councils / Umbrella Groups ‚Ä¢ Unified FBOs ‚Äì ABMPD‚Äôs official FBO coordinating body. ‚Ä¢ Philippine Council of Evangelical Churches (PCEC) ‚Äì Covers evangelical denominations nationwide. ‚Ä¢ Catholic Bishops‚Äô Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) ‚Äì Catholic dioceses, parishes, and organizations. ‚Ä¢ National Council of Churches in the Philippines (NCCP) ‚Äì Protestant and mainline denominations. ‚Ä¢ Philippine Council of Interfaith Dialogue (PCID) ‚Äì Promotes interfaith unity. ‚Ä¢ Bishops-Businessmen‚Äôs Conference for Human Development (BBC) ‚Äì Faith and business collaboration. ________________________________________ 2. Major Christian Denominations / Churches ‚Ä¢ Roman Catholic Church (Archdioceses, Parishes, Diocesan Ministries) ‚Ä¢ Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) ‚Ä¢ Seventh-Day Adventist Church (SDA) ‚Ä¢ United Church of Christ in the Philippines (UCCP) ‚Ä¢ Assemblies of God ‚Ä¢ Baptist Churches (various conventions) ‚Ä¢ Church of the Nazarene ‚Ä¢ Victory Christian Fellowship (Every Nation) ‚Ä¢ Jesus Is Lord (JIL) Church ‚Ä¢ El Shaddai DWXI-PPFI ________________________________________ 3. Islamic Faith-Based Organizations ‚Ä¢ National Commission on Muslim Filipinos (NCMF) ‚Äì Coordination and policy. ‚Ä¢ Local Masjid / Muslim Communities ‚Äì Barangay-level Islamic centers. ‚Ä¢ Federation of Bangsamoro Ulama ‚Äì Religious scholars supporting moral recovery. ‚Ä¢ Islamic NGOs (e.g., Al-Amanah Foundation) ‚Äì Education, livelihood, moral programs. ________________________________________ 4. Other Faith & Spiritual Communities ‚Ä¢ Hindu Communities in the Philippines ‚Äì Values and spiritual formation. ‚Ä¢ Buddhist Organizations (Fo Guang Shan, Mahayana, Theravada groups) ‚Äì Meditation, peace, and values programs. ‚Ä¢ Sikh Communities ‚Äì Service-oriented values and feeding programs (Langar). ‚Ä¢ Indigenous Spiritual Organizations (Lumad, IP councils) ‚Äì Cultural and spiritual integration. ________________________________________ 5. Faith-based NGOs & Movements ‚Ä¢ World Vision Philippines ‚Äì Faith-based child and family programs. ‚Ä¢ Compassion International ‚Äì Partner churches for child and household development. ‚Ä¢ Tearfund Philippines ‚Äì Disaster resilience and moral recovery. ‚Ä¢ International Justice Mission (IJM) ‚Äì Christian NGO for justice and protection. ‚Ä¢ Caritas Philippines (CBCP arm for social action) ‚Äì Relief, development, and moral engagement. ________________________________________ 6. Local/Grassroots Faith Groups ‚Ä¢ Parish Pastoral Councils / Basic Ecclesial Communities (BECs) ‚Äì Parish-based household formation. ‚Ä¢ Barangay-level Prayer Groups / Cells ‚Äì Weekly values and faith gatherings. ‚Ä¢ Interfaith Barangay Councils ‚Äì Promote peace and unity among faiths locally. ‚Ä¢ Faith-based youth ministries ‚Äì Church-based youth volunteer mobilization. 4. Private Sector & CSR Partners ________________________________________ 1. Corporate Foundations (Philippines) ‚Ä¢ San Miguel Foundation ‚Äì Community development, education, feeding programs. ‚Ä¢ SM Foundation ‚Äì Health, education, and relief operations. ‚Ä¢ Ayala Foundation ‚Äì Education, leadership, digital inclusion. ‚Ä¢ JG Summit / Gokongwei Brothers Foundation ‚Äì Education and youth empowerment. ‚Ä¢ Metrobank Foundation ‚Äì Education, culture, disaster relief. ‚Ä¢ BDO Foundation ‚Äì Financial literacy, community building. ‚Ä¢ PLDT-Smart Foundation ‚Äì Digital inclusion, education, disaster response. ‚Ä¢ Globe Telecom CSR (Globe Bridging Communities) ‚Äì Digital education, volunteerism. ‚Ä¢ MVP Group Foundation ‚Äì Education, livelihood, community development. ________________________________________ 2. Corporate CSR Arms / Conglomerates ‚Ä¢ Aboitiz Foundation ‚Äì Education, enterprise development, environment. ‚Ä¢ Lopez Group Foundation ‚Äì Knowledge sharing, disaster relief, sustainability. ‚Ä¢ DMCI Homes Foundation ‚Äì Housing, community development. ‚Ä¢ Megaworld Foundation ‚Äì Scholarships, youth programs. ‚Ä¢ Robinsons Land Foundation ‚Äì Education and community engagement. ‚Ä¢ Metro Pacific Investments Foundation ‚Äì Community health and services. ________________________________________ 3. Banks and Financial Institutions ‚Ä¢ Bank of the Philippine Islands (BPI Foundation) ‚Äì Financial literacy, environment. ‚Ä¢ Security Bank Foundation ‚Äì Education, scholarships. ‚Ä¢ UnionBank Foundation ‚Äì Digital inclusion, youth entrepreneurship. ‚Ä¢ Philippine National Bank (PNB CSR Programs) ‚Äì Community support. ‚Ä¢ Land Bank of the Philippines (LANDBANK CSR) ‚Äì Rural development and agri-support. ‚Ä¢ Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP CARES) ‚Äì Infrastructure and education support. ________________________________________ 4. Industry & Business Associations ‚Ä¢ Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PCCI) ‚Äì Nationwide network for CSR and volunteer initiatives. ‚Ä¢ Employers Confederation of the Philippines (ECOP) ‚Äì Workforce and livelihood partnerships. ‚Ä¢ Go Negosyo ‚Äì MSME and livelihood empowerment. ‚Ä¢ Business for Social Progress (PBSP) ‚Äì Collective CSR platform for big companies. ‚Ä¢ Rotary Clubs of the Philippines ‚Äì Volunteer service, youth, health, environment. ‚Ä¢ Lions Clubs International (Philippines) ‚Äì Health and community service projects. ‚Ä¢ Junior Chamber International (JCI Philippines) ‚Äì Youth leadership and civic projects. ________________________________________ 5. Utilities, Energy, and Infrastructure ‚Ä¢ Meralco Foundation (One Meralco Foundation) ‚Äì Electrification, education, volunteerism. ‚Ä¢ Petron Foundation ‚Äì Livelihood and education. ‚Ä¢ Shell Philippines Foundation ‚Äì Livelihood, environment, community health. ‚Ä¢ Chevron Philippines CSR ‚Äì Environment and livelihood programs. ‚Ä¢ Maynilad Water Foundation / Manila Water Foundation ‚Äì Health, sanitation, clean water access. ________________________________________ 6. Media & Technology CSR ‚Ä¢ ABS-CBN Lingkod Kapamilya Foundation ‚Äì Relief, environment, children‚Äôs programs. ‚Ä¢ GMA Kapuso Foundation ‚Äì Relief, education, health. ‚Ä¢ Google Philippines CSR Initiatives ‚Äì Digital literacy, youth programs. ‚Ä¢ Microsoft Philippines Philanthropies ‚Äì Digital inclusion, training. ‚Ä¢ Facebook/Meta Philippines CSR ‚Äì Community training and digital skills. ________________________________________ 7. Local Enterprises & Cooperatives ‚Ä¢ Local Microfinance Institutions (CARD MRI, ASA Philippines) ‚Äì Family and livelihood support. ‚Ä¢ Regional Chambers of Commerce ‚Äì Local CSR initiatives. ‚Ä¢ Transport groups (e.g., Grab Philippines CSR) ‚Äì Logistics and volunteer mobility. ‚Ä¢ Agricultural cooperatives / agri-business firms ‚Äì In-kind food donations, livelihood training. 5. International Partners / Donors ________________________________________ 1. United Nations Agencies ‚Ä¢ UNICEF ‚Äì Child protection, education, health, youth engagement. ‚Ä¢ UNDP ‚Äì Governance, community resilience, livelihoods, digital innovation. ‚Ä¢ UNESCO ‚Äì Education, cultural heritage, intergenerational learning. ‚Ä¢ WFP (World Food Programme) ‚Äì Feeding programs, food packs, nutrition. ‚Ä¢ WHO (World Health Organization) ‚Äì Health modules, community health workers training. ‚Ä¢ FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization) ‚Äì Agriculture, family livelihood, nutrition. ‚Ä¢ UN Women ‚Äì Gender equity, women‚Äôs empowerment, livelihood support. ‚Ä¢ ILO (International Labour Organization) ‚Äì Skills development, youth employment, cooperatives. ‚Ä¢ UNHCR ‚Äì Protection and inclusion of vulnerable groups (if relevant). ________________________________________ 2. Bilateral Donors (Government Agencies of Other Countries) ‚Ä¢ USAID (United States Agency for International Development) ‚Äì Education, health, disaster response, livelihood. ‚Ä¢ JICA (Japan International Cooperation Agency) ‚Äì Capacity-building, disaster resilience, infrastructure, training. ‚Ä¢ KOICA (Korea International Cooperation Agency) ‚Äì Education, ICT, youth programs. ‚Ä¢ GIZ (German Cooperation) ‚Äì Environment, governance, renewable energy. ‚Ä¢ DFAT (Australia‚Äôs Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade) ‚Äì Education, child protection, humanitarian assistance. ‚Ä¢ CIDA (Canada International Development Agency / Global Affairs Canada) ‚Äì Gender, livelihood, youth empowerment. ‚Ä¢ UK Aid / FCDO (Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office) ‚Äì Governance, education, humanitarian assistance. ‚Ä¢ European Union (EU Delegation to the Philippines) ‚Äì Governance, youth programs, community resilience. ‚Ä¢ Embassies (US, Japan, South Korea, Germany, Australia, Canada, EU, UK, etc.) ‚Äì Direct small grants for barangay or municipal projects. ________________________________________ 3. Multilateral Development Banks / International Finance Institutions ‚Ä¢ World Bank ‚Äì Social services, governance, education, community-driven development. ‚Ä¢ Asian Development Bank (ADB) ‚Äì Livelihood, skills training, infrastructure, health. ‚Ä¢ International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) ‚Äì Family-based livelihood and agricultural projects. ________________________________________ 4. International NGOs & Humanitarian Orgs ‚Ä¢ Plan International ‚Äì Youth, child protection, education, livelihood. ‚Ä¢ Oxfam International ‚Äì Livelihood, disaster response, community service. ‚Ä¢ World Vision ‚Äì Values formation, education, child protection, feeding. ‚Ä¢ Save the Children ‚Äì Education, health, nutrition, emergency response. ‚Ä¢ Habitat for Humanity ‚Äì Housing, community infrastructure. ‚Ä¢ CARE International ‚Äì Disaster response, livelihood, gender. ‚Ä¢ Catholic Relief Services (CRS) ‚Äì Faith-linked values formation, livelihood. ‚Ä¢ HelpAge International ‚Äì Elderly support, intergenerational programs. ‚Ä¢ Red Cross / IFRC (International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies) ‚Äì Disaster response, health, youth volunteerism. ________________________________________ 5. Foundations & Philanthropic Organizations (Global) ‚Ä¢ Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation ‚Äì Health, education, innovation. ‚Ä¢ Ford Foundation ‚Äì Social justice, education, community empowerment. ‚Ä¢ Rockefeller Foundation ‚Äì Livelihood, resilience, health. ‚Ä¢ Clinton Foundation ‚Äì Health and community programs. ‚Ä¢ Global Fund ‚Äì Health, TB, HIV, malaria. ‚Ä¢ Children‚Äôs Investment Fund Foundation (CIFF) ‚Äì Youth and child-focused initiatives. ‚Ä¢ Mastercard Foundation ‚Äì Financial inclusion, youth livelihoods. ‚Ä¢ Bloomberg Philanthropies ‚Äì Health, environment, local governance. ________________________________________ 6. International Faith-based Organizations ‚Ä¢ World Council of Churches (WCC) ‚Äì Interfaith values formation. ‚Ä¢ Islamic Relief Worldwide ‚Äì Community service, livelihood, education. ‚Ä¢ Caritas Internationalis ‚Äì Relief, livelihood, family programs. ‚Ä¢ The Salvation Army International ‚Äì Feeding, livelihood, youth development. ________________________________________ 7. Overseas Filipinos & Diaspora Communities ________________________________________ 1. Government-Linked Agencies & Councils ‚Ä¢ Commission on Filipinos Overseas (CFO) ‚Äì mobilizes diaspora philanthropy and balikbayan programs. ‚Ä¢ Department of Migrant Workers (DMW) ‚Äì oversees OFW affairs, reintegration, and welfare. ‚Ä¢ Overseas Workers Welfare Administration (OWWA) ‚Äì has reintegration programs and family support projects. ‚Ä¢ Philippine Overseas Labor Offices (POLO) ‚Äì field offices abroad for coordination. ‚Ä¢ Philippine Embassies & Consulates ‚Äì formal link to diaspora groups and donors. ________________________________________ 2. Global Diaspora Councils & Federations ‚Ä¢ Global Filipino Diaspora Council (GFDC) ‚Äì umbrella network of diaspora leaders worldwide. ‚Ä¢ Global Council of Overseas Filipinos (GCOF) ‚Äì connects OFWs and Filipino migrants for development projects. ‚Ä¢ Philippine Global Diaspora Council (PGDC) ‚Äì policy advocacy and collective funding. ________________________________________ 3. Regional Federations of Filipinos Abroad ‚Ä¢ Middle East Filipino Communities Network (Saudi Arabia, UAE, Qatar, Kuwait, Bahrain). ‚Ä¢ Europe Filipino Organizations Federation (Italy, Spain, UK, Germany, France). ‚Ä¢ North America Filipino Federations (Filipino-American Communities, Canada-wide associations). ‚Ä¢ Asia-Pacific Filipino Federations (Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Australia, New Zealand). ________________________________________ 4. Country-Specific OFW & Filipino Organizations ‚Ä¢ Filipino American Community Organizations (Fil-Am Associations, US). ‚Ä¢ Filipino Canadian Associations (Fil-Can groups, Canadian provinces). ‚Ä¢ United Filipino Associations in Europe (UFAE). ‚Ä¢ United Filipinos in the Middle East (UNIFIL). ‚Ä¢ Federation of Filipino Associations in Japan (FFAJ). ‚Ä¢ Filipino Community Councils in Australia (FCCAs). ________________________________________ 5. Sectoral & Professional Diaspora Groups ‚Ä¢ Overseas Filipino Professionals Networks (nurses, engineers, teachers, seafarers, IT). ‚Ä¢ Filipino Entrepreneurs Abroad (business councils in Dubai, Singapore, New York, Toronto). ‚Ä¢ Filipino Faith-Based Overseas Networks (Catholic charismatic groups, Evangelical Filipino churches abroad). ________________________________________ 6. Philanthropy & Support Networks ‚Ä¢ Atikha Overseas Workers & Communities Initiative ‚Äì specializes in diaspora philanthropy and reintegration. ‚Ä¢ Philippine Humanitarian Coalition (PHC) ‚Äì US-based, mobilizes diaspora for relief and recovery. ‚Ä¢ Filipino Diaspora Foundations (ex. Ayala Foundation USA, ABS-CBN Foundation International). ‚Ä¢ Remittance-linked Giving Programs (BPI, PNB, and other banks with ‚Äúpadala-for-donation‚Äù programs). I. Internal Ecosystem (Core Implementors & Governance) Ito ang ‚Äúofficial ABMPD structure‚Äù na palaging nariyan at mandated: ‚Ä¢ Company A (Holding Company) ‚Ä¢ Company B, C, D‚Ä¶ (subsidiaries for specific roles) ‚Ä¢ Volunteer Formation Associations (BVFA ‚Üí NVFA) ‚Ä¢ Program Governance Offices (BMRPFO ‚Üí NMRPO) üîë Purpose: Establishes ownership, accountability, and delivery mechanisms. ________________________________________ II. Government Partners (Policy & Technical Alignment) ‚Ä¢ National Agencies (DILG, DepEd, TESDA, DSWD, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Local Government Units (Provincial, Municipal, Barangay) ‚Ä¢ Policy & Knowledge Institutions (PIDS, DAP, CSC, PNVSCA, etc.) üîë Purpose: Ensure ABMPD is aligned with national and local policies, has government legitimacy, and taps public programs. ________________________________________ III. Community & Civil Society Partners (Grassroots Engagement) ‚Ä¢ CSOs/NGOs (World Vision, PRC, Save the Children, Habitat, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Cooperatives & People‚Äôs Orgs (farmers, fisherfolk, TODA, microfinance) ‚Ä¢ Youth, Women, Family, PWDs, Seniors, 4Ps groups ‚Ä¢ Volunteer & Civic Clubs (Rotary, Lions, JCI, brigades, rescue) üîë Purpose: Strengthen local ownership, inclusivity, and civic action. ________________________________________ IV. Faith-Based Partners (Moral Recovery & Values Formation) ‚Ä¢ National/umbrella faith councils (CBCP, PCEC, NCCP, PCID, Unified FBOs) ‚Ä¢ Major denominations (Catholic, INC, SDA, Baptist, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Islamic orgs (NCMF, Ulama, Masjid networks) ‚Ä¢ Other religions (Buddhist, Hindu, Sikh, Indigenous) ‚Ä¢ Faith-based NGOs & grassroots ministries (Caritas, IJM, World Vision, BECs) üîë Purpose: Serve as values formation backbone, moral recovery facilitators, and community credibility anchors. ________________________________________ V. Private Sector & CSR Partners (Resource Mobilization) ‚Ä¢ Corporate Foundations (SM, Ayala, San Miguel, Metrobank, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Conglomerate CSR Arms (Aboitiz, Lopez, DMCI, Megaworld, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Banks & Finance Institutions (BPI, UnionBank, LandBank, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Business & Industry Orgs (PCCI, ECOP, PBSP, Go Negosyo) ‚Ä¢ Utilities & Infra (Meralco, Shell, Chevron, Maynilad, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Media & Tech (ABS-CBN, GMA, Google, Microsoft, Meta) ‚Ä¢ Local Enterprises & Cooperatives üîë Purpose: Provide funding, infrastructure, skills, and CSR programs. ________________________________________ VI. International Partners & Donors (Strategic & Long-Term Support) ‚Ä¢ UN Agencies (UNICEF, UNDP, UNESCO, WFP, WHO, FAO, UN Women, ILO, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Bilateral Donors (USAID, JICA, KOICA, DFAT, EU, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Multilateral Dev Banks (World Bank, ADB, IFAD) ‚Ä¢ International NGOs (Oxfam, Plan, Save the Children, CARE, CRS, etc.) ‚Ä¢ Foundations & Philanthropies (Gates, Ford, Rockefeller, Clinton, Bloomberg, CIFF, etc.) ‚Ä¢ International Faith-based (Caritas Internationalis, WCC, Islamic Relief, Salvation Army) üîë Purpose: Bring in large-scale funding, technical expertise, global credibility, and innovation. ________________________________________ üìä How to Present in the Masterplan 1. Main Body (Partnership Strategy section) ‚Äì Use the 6 categories above with short descriptions. 2. Annex (Detailed Partner Matrix) ‚Äì Full breakdown (like your big list), showing: o Category o Name of partner o Role (policy, funding, training, grassroots, etc.) o Potential contributions (cash, in-kind, manpower, legitimacy) ________________________________________ üëâ Suggestion: gawin nating Annex E ‚Äì Partner Ecosystem Matrix yung full detailed list mo. Sa main Masterplan, concise lang (1‚Äì2 pages), then refer to Annex E for details. üìå Core Fit for ABMPD Rollouts ‚Ä¢ Barangay Level: Training manuals, family and youth engagement modules, feeding/nutrition programs, livelihood kits, health programs, small-grant funded pilot initiatives. ‚Ä¢ Municipal Level: Multi-barangay youth camps, livelihood programs, recognition ceremonies, infrastructure (multipurpose halls, training centers), cross-barangay service programs, technical assistance for coordinators. ‚Ä¢ Financial & In-kind: Grants, food packs, school supplies, training resources, equipment, technical experts, digital monitoring tools, cross-learning exposure trips. ‚ÄÉ üïäÔ∏è Alliance of Prophetic Builders for ABMPD Global Mission (APB-ABMPD) Tagline: ‚ÄúTogether, we prepare the way of the Lord.‚Äù Overview The Alliance of Prophetic Builders (APB) is an official non-governmental organization (NGO) under the covering and partnership of ABMPD Foundation Philippines, dedicated to all individual donors, partners, and prophetic supporters who are called to take part in the Prophetic Destiny Fulfillment of ABMPD ‚Äî in the Philippines and throughout the nations. APB serves as the community of givers, intercessors, and builders who stand together for the divine purpose of establishing God‚Äôs Kingdom agenda on Earth ‚Äî ‚ÄúThy Kingdom come, Thy will be done.‚Äù All proceeds, offerings, and support mobilized through APB are channeled directly to the ABMPD Foundation to fund its moral, spiritual, and prophetic nation-building programs, ensuring full alignment with the ABMPD Vision and Mission. ________________________________________ Vision To unite all prophetic builders and supporters under one divine purpose ‚Äî to prepare the way of the Lord and fulfill the prophetic destiny of the Philippines as a beacon of righteousness and transformation to the nations. ________________________________________ Mission 1. To mobilize and inspire donors, partners, and intercessors who share the prophetic vision of ABMPD. 2. To create a global network of prophetic builders who support ABMPD programs financially, spiritually, and missionally. 3. To hold celebrations, recognition events, and fellowship gatherings for supporters and donors ‚Äî giving glory to God for every milestone in the prophetic fulfillment journey. 4. To build transparency and trust through open reporting, testimonies, and unified prayer for the continued expansion of ABMPD‚Äôs Kingdom works. 5. To strengthen unity among the chosen people of God, both in the Philippines and abroad, who are called to advance His Kingdom purposes in this generation. ________________________________________ Core Purpose The Alliance of Prophetic Builders exists to: ‚Ä¢ Unite God‚Äôs chosen people and supporters of ABMPD‚Äôs prophetic vision. ‚Ä¢ Create a community where every giver becomes a builder of the Kingdom. ‚Ä¢ Provide a platform for celebration, recognition, and collaboration among national and international supporters. ‚Ä¢ Ensure that all funds and activities are directed toward the prophetic destiny fulfillment of the ABMPD Global Mission. ________________________________________ Organizational Linkage ‚Ä¢ Mother Organization: ABMPD Foundation Philippines ‚Ä¢ Official Program Beneficiary: ABMPD Prophetic Destiny Fulfillment Program ‚Ä¢ Partner Networks: ABMPD Global Partners, KCI, BVFA, and other affiliated institutions ________________________________________ Membership ‚Ä¢ Open to all individuals, families, institutions, and international partners who pledge moral, spiritual, or financial support to the ABMPD prophetic cause. ‚Ä¢ Members are recognized as Prophetic Builders ‚Äî individuals who contribute to the moral and spiritual rebuilding of nations through their giving and participation. ________________________________________ Activities ‚Ä¢ Annual Prophetic Builders Fellowship and Thanksgiving Celebration ‚Ä¢ Recognition Ceremonies for national and international supporters ‚Ä¢ Cultural and Worship Gatherings celebrating Kingdom unity ‚Ä¢ Updates and Mission Reports from ABMPD‚Äôs ongoing prophetic projects ‚Ä¢ Special Prayer and Dedication Events for partners and supporters ________________________________________ Declaration ‚ÄúThe Alliance of Prophetic Builders (APB) stands as a divine movement of Kingdom partners, whose hearts, hands, and resources are consecrated for the fulfillment of the Lord‚Äôs prophetic plan through the ABMPD. Together, we prepare the way of the Lord ‚Äî until His Kingdom reigns in every sphere of society.‚Äù ‚öñÔ∏è Legal Formation and Institutional Accreditation Subsidiary (LFIAS) Institutional Library and Governance Custodian of the ABMPD Ecosystem ________________________________________ üèõÔ∏è I. Core Mandate The Legal Formation and Institutional Accreditation Subsidiary (LFIAS) functions as the official legal formation, compliance, and documentation arm of the ABMPD Holdings OPC, ensuring that every entity within the ABMPD Ecosystem ‚Äî from the Holding Company to Foundations, NGOs, Cooperatives, and Technical Subsidiaries ‚Äî is legally registered, properly accredited, and compliant with all governance and regulatory requirements. It also acts as the Institutional Library ‚Äî a central repository for all legal documents, registration certificates, MOAs, permits, accreditations, and governance templates, serving as the institutional memory and compliance audit reference of the ABMPD Moral Recovery System. ________________________________________ ‚öôÔ∏è II. General Roles and Functions of the LFIAS Functional Domain Role / Function Expected Output 1. Institutional Formation Oversees the legal creation of all ABMPD-related entities ‚Äî from drafting incorporation documents to processing SEC, CDA, DSWD, and BIR registrations. Fully registered ABMPD institutions (Holding, Foundation, NGO, Cooperative, Subsidiaries). 2. Compliance and Accreditation Ensures all institutions maintain good standing with SEC, DSWD, PCNC, and other agencies; handles renewals and accreditation tracking. Up-to-date certificates, accreditation records, and legal renewals. 3. Governance Documentation Develops governance manuals, compliance handbooks, and standardized MOA/MOU templates for all institutional levels. Unified Governance & Compliance Manual for ABMPD Ecosystem. 4. Legal Support & Advisory Provides legal opinion, contract review, and policy guidance for all subsidiaries, partner FBOs/CSOs, and LGUs. Cleared contracts, MOAs, and policy advisories. 5. IP Protection & Documentation Registers all ABMPD intellectual properties (branding, modules, systems, dashboards, and publications). Secured IP portfolio under ABMPD Holdings OPC. 6. Institutional Mentoring Guides partner entities (CSOs, FBOs, Cooperatives) through legal formation and governance training. Accredited and legally compliant local partner organizations. 7. Institutional Library Management Maintains a secure archive of all legal and governance records (digital + physical), integrated into the ABMPD Beta System. Centralized Institutional Library accessible to authorized partners. ________________________________________ üß© III. Ecosystem Entities Under LFIAS Oversight and Support Below are the entities and institutions to be established as part of the ABMPD Ecosystem, with their individual roles and functions, and how the LFIAS supports each one. ________________________________________ 1. üß† ABMPD Holdings OPC (One-Person Corporation) Role: Central governance brain and strategic custodian of the entire ABMPD Program. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Oversees all subsidiaries, foundations, and partner networks. ‚Ä¢ Sets national policy, standards, and moral economy protocols. ‚Ä¢ Approves program budgets, donor frameworks, and moral credit systems. LFIAS Support: Drafts and maintains corporate documents, Articles of Incorporation, By-Laws, MOAs, and SEC renewals. ________________________________________ 2. üèõÔ∏è ABMPD Foundation Philippines, Inc. Role: Non-stock, non-profit development and implementation arm. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Custodian of grants, donations, and CSR funds. ‚Ä¢ Implements national development and moral recovery projects. ‚Ä¢ Coordinates donor accountability and fund transparency. LFIAS Support: Secures DSWD Permit to Solicit, PCNC accreditation, and BIR Tax-Exempt status. ________________________________________ 3. üïäÔ∏è APB‚ÄìABMPD (Alliance of Prophetic Builders for ABMPD Global Mission) Role: Official crowdfunding and mobilization NGO under ABMPD. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Leads fundraising and volunteer sponsorship campaigns. ‚Ä¢ Facilitates public engagement, rewards, and moral economy credits. LFIAS Support: Handles SEC registration, NGO accreditation, and internal crowdfunding compliance documentation. ________________________________________ 4. ü§ù Unified Faith-Based Organizations (UFBOs) Role: Faith-based mobilizers for moral renewal and dissemination. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Organize interfaith volunteerism, moral formation, and community outreach. ‚Ä¢ Serve as the moral compass and ethical validation arm in the ecosystem. LFIAS Support: Guides UFBO registration, MOA drafting, and interfaith council accreditation at municipal and provincial levels. ________________________________________ 5. üèóÔ∏è Staffing Cooperative System (CDA-Registered) Role: HR and volunteer deployment cooperative for barangay operations. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Recruits, accredits, and manages facilitators and barangay-level staff. ‚Ä¢ Handles manpower pooling, benefits, and honorarium systems. LFIAS Support: Prepares CDA registration documents, cooperative bylaws, and HR compliance templates. ________________________________________ 6. üí∞ Finance & Stewardship Subsidiary Role: Central audit and financial management arm. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Manages all funds, donations, and transparency protocols. ‚Ä¢ Implements the 20‚Äì20‚Äì20‚Äì40 stewardship allocation scheme. LFIAS Support: Drafts fund-handling MOAs, ensures BIR compliance, and verifies custodial account legality. ________________________________________ 7. üíª Systems & Data Development Subsidiary Role: Digital backbone of the ABMPD ecosystem. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Develops and manages the ABMPD Beta Dashboard, accreditation system, and participant registry. ‚Ä¢ Integrates finance, training, and moral data. LFIAS Support: Registers software IP, data protection compliance, and cybersecurity policies. ________________________________________ 8. üìö Research, Training & M&E Subsidiary Role: Research and evaluation think tank. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Designs evaluation tools and monitors moral transformation impact. ‚Ä¢ Partners with HEIs (e.g., ISU, AIM) for evidence-based validation. LFIAS Support: Drafts MOAs with HEIs and oversees ethics compliance and research permits. ________________________________________ 9. üì¢ Media & Communication Subsidiary Role: National advocacy and storytelling arm. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Handles publicity, documentation, and brand consistency. ‚Ä¢ Produces moral awareness campaigns and national events coverage. LFIAS Support: Registers media licenses, contracts, and copyright documentation. ________________________________________ 10. üßæ Proposal & Feasibility Office Role: Donor engagement and project expansion arm. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Prepares feasibility studies, project proposals, and scaling plans. ‚Ä¢ Interfaces with LGUs, NGAs, CSR partners, and donors. LFIAS Support: Drafts partnership contracts and legal frameworks for funding proposals. ________________________________________ 11. üë• Human Resource & Staffing Subsidiary Role: Personnel welfare and HR systems administrator. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Maintains staff records, training certificates, and performance data. ‚Ä¢ Manages HR policy compliance and staff welfare systems. LFIAS Support: Ensures labor law compliance, creates standardized HR policies and contracts. ________________________________________ 12. üñãÔ∏è Digital Publishing & Donation Platform, Inc. Role: Publishing and reflection engagement hub. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Publishes ABMPD books, devotionals, and reflection materials. ‚Ä¢ Operates donation and e-engagement portals. LFIAS Support: Secures publishing rights, IP registrations, and online compliance documentation. ________________________________________ 13. ‚öôÔ∏è Legal & Governance Subsidiary Role: Internal compliance and oversight arm. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Monitors governance adherence, MOA enforcement, and institutional performance audits. ‚Ä¢ Serves as the internal audit partner of LFIAS. LFIAS Support: Collaborates for data sharing, policy updates, and legal reviews. ________________________________________ 14. üåê ABMPD International Relations & Donor Engagement Office Role: Oversees linkages with global partners and funding institutions. Functions: ‚Ä¢ Manages international MOUs, donor protocols, and embassy engagements. ‚Ä¢ Coordinates moral economy linkages with diaspora and global agencies. LFIAS Support: Drafts and notarizes international agreements, verifies cross-border compliance. ________________________________________ üìö IV. Institutional Library Function The Institutional Library maintained by the LFIAS will: ‚Ä¢ Serve as the central archive for all ABMPD legal, institutional, and accreditation documents. ‚Ä¢ Contain digital folders for each entity, accessible via the ABMPD Beta Dashboard. ‚Ä¢ Maintain searchable indexes of templates (Articles of Incorporation, MOAs, Manuals, IP Certificates, DSWD/PCNC permits, etc.). ‚Ä¢ Support audit, renewal, and transparency reporting across all subsidiaries and partner organizations. ________________________________________ üß≠ V. Key Deliverables Before Pilot Rollout 1. SEC, CDA, DSWD, BIR, and PCNC registration for all ecosystem entities. 2. Completed Unified Governance and Compliance Manual. 3. Digitized Institutional Library integrated into the ABMPD Beta System. 4. Registered Intellectual Property portfolio (brand, software, materials). 5. Legally compliant partner CSOs, FBOs, and Cooperatives across pilot municipalities. ________________________________________ üåü VI. Strategic Impact The LFIAS ensures that the ABMPD Ecosystem is: ‚Ä¢ Legally grounded ‚Äî every arm properly registered and protected. ‚Ä¢ Governance-aligned ‚Äî guided by one unified compliance framework. ‚Ä¢ Sustainably documented ‚Äî all records preserved in the Institutional Library. ‚Ä¢ Internationally credible ‚Äî compliant with national and global accreditation standards.
